    Setting Up Your Environment

    Installing Software

    Browsers - We will be working with multiple browsers for testing websites. You can't force your audience to use your favourite so get familiar with them all. Test your webpages in all of them. They don't all work the same. Here are the ones that represent 99% of the desktop market:

    OSX - Safari, Chrome, Firefox, Opera

    Windows - Chrome, Firefox, Opera, MS Edge

    That covers the desktop/laptop market. If the statistics from every company that collects browser statistics are to be believed, over 50% of all website visits happen on Mobile. Here are the mobile browsers that you should install on your phone to test your websites.

    Safari(on iOS), UC Browser, Chrome, Android(comes on Android), Firefox Mobile, Opera mobile.

     

    Code Development Tools for Web - There will be a variety of tools that we need this semester. The first tool you will need is Brackets - https://brackets.io/ (Links to an external site.) (version 1.7) Along with Brackets, I recommend you install the Emmet plugin and the Advanced New File plugin.

    There are other options for IDEs for doing web development - Dreamweaver which comes with your Creative Cloud licence, Sublime Text, Atom, and others. We will be using Brackets in class.

    Filezilla FTP Client - for uploading files to our external web server.

    Eventually we will also be installing Ruby, SASS, Git, and a Git desktop client but there is no rush for these.

     

    Saving Files

    When you are doing work in class or working on assignments it always helps to have a common place to save your files for class. The file structure that we recommend for your course work is:

    Documents/code/mad9013/
                   mad9014/
    Documents/mad9010/
              mad9111/

    Inside your Documents folder create a folder called code. Inside that create a folder for each course that has programming. I prefer to use the course codes because they are shorter to type, but you can use any name you want. In the first semester MAD9013 and MAD9014 are the two courses where you will be programming consistently. 

    For the non-programming courses like MAD9010, MAD8010, and MAD9111 just create a folder with the course name or code.

    Repeat this process in both Windows and OSX and you will always know where your files are.

     

    Folder and File Names

    With non-programming course this is not as critical but having a common standard will make things easier for you down the road. When creating files to use for all your web programming please use the following guidelines:

    1. Only use lowercase

    2. Never start a filename with a number

    3. If a filename needs multiple words then put a hyphen between them.

    4. NEVER put spaces in a file name.

     

     

    HTTP, HTML, and CSS

    Three words that you will hear over and over in web development are HTTP, HTML and CSS.

    HTTP

    Those letters at the beginning of every web site address in the location bar of your browser. They stand for HyperText Transfer Protocol. This is the standard method that web servers and browsers use to communicate with each other. It is their agreed standard for passing Requests and Responses to each other. 

    All Requests and Responses are made up of two parts - a HEADER and a BODY. The HEADER contains all the important information about the request - where it is being made from and going to, the type and size of file being requested, etc. The BODY is the actual file or data bundle being sent between the two computers.

    HTML

    HTML stands for HyperText Markup Language. This is the way that all web pages are built. If you view the source code for any webpage what you will see is HTML. 

    Imagine any webpage with all the colours, text sizes, and decoration removed so all you can see is a block of text. If you took that text and around each part of the page you added an indicator for what that piece of text represented - that is Markup.

    <h1>This is a Heading</h1>
    <p>This is a paragraph</p>
    <a>This is an anchor (link)</a>

    These are examples of HTML elements (or tags). Notice that the tag at the start and end of the block of text is the same except for the backslash, which indicates the end of the block.

    In an HTML file there are certain elements that every page must have, like <html>, <head>, and <body>. The tags are always nested inside of each other. What you are left with is a type of tree structure like the image above. Inside each tag there is either another tag or some text. Sometimes there are multiple things nested inside like the paragraph inside the body.

    <p>This is a <i>simple</i> document</p>

    This is what that tree structure would look like written out as HTML.

     

    CSS

    CSS stands for Cascading Style Sheets. This is a styling language used to control the presentation of all the content on the web page. Every browser will have default styles that it uses for every element. However, these are pretty plain.

    If you really want to control things like the amount of space around your paragraphs, colours for background and text, images and icons, alignment, font sizes, and borders then you need CSS. Here is a sample piece of CSS

    There is a selector, in this example it is an h1 tag. Then a set of curly braces. Inside the curly braces we create a list of properties and values. Between the property and value you put a colon. At the end of each value you put a semi-colon.

    Using style declarations like this we can control the appearance of every element on any webpage.

      HTML Tag Reference

      Basic Required Elements

      <!doctype html> - doctype declaration

      <html> - root tag

      <head> - container for all metadata

      <body> - container for all visible content

       

      Document MetaData Elements

      Elements inside the <head>

      <meta> - metadata about the page like the language, charset, and viewport information

      <link> - link to external related documents like stylesheets and shortcut icons

      <style> - container for embedded styles

      <title> - title displayed in the browser tab

       

      Content Sectioning Elements

      <article> - a container for an article. Typically includes a title, references and paragraphs.

      <aside> - secondary content on the page, like a sidebar.

      <header> - typically the masthead for the page

      <footer> - the container for additional links and information about the page that will be displayed to the user

      <section> - used to bundle parts of the page together, like groups of articles

      <div> - a semantic free block-level container

      <nav> - the container for navigation menus

      <main> - the container for the main content of the page

      <h1>..<h6> - all the headings with different levels of importance

       

      Text Content Elements

      <p> - paragraphs are all wrapped in this, the most common tag.

      <ol> - an ordered list

      <ul> - an unordered list

      <li> - a list item, the ONLY tag allowed as a child of <ol> or <ul>

      <dt> - a dictionary term in a dictionary list

      <dd> - a dictionary definition in a dictionary list

      <pre> - a block of preformatted text. Carriage returns are displayed.

      <blockquote> - a container for a block of text which is a quote.

      <hr> - horizontal rule, a line across the width of its containing element, meant to visually separate content.

      <figure> - a container around an <img> and <figcaption>

      <figcaption> - always nested inside a <figure> as the label for the image.

       

      Inline Semantic Elements

      <a> - Anchor elements are the links between webpages and other online resources.

      <abbr> - abbreviations

      <br> - a line break, used if you need to end a line of text in the middle of a paragraph or other block of text.

      <cite> - used to cite a creative resource

      <code> - wrapped around a block of programming code

      <em> - text that needs to be emphasized, displayed as italicized text

      <kbd> - keyboard input, a representation of what a user could type in a tutorial or set of instructions

      <mark> - a small inline block of text to be highlighted through CSS

      <small> - reduces the wrapped text by one relative size

      <span> - a semantic free inline wrapper for any text to be styled

      <strong> - text that is marked as more important, displayed as bold text

      <sub> - sub text, which is small text lowered half a line from other text

      <sup> - super text, which is the small raised text like exponents

      <time> - used to wrap any date or time

      <wbr> - used to indicate a location in a word for a possible word break

       

      Images and Media

      <img> - an image element

      <picture> - the new HTML5 image container which allows for different image based on device specs

      <source> - used inside <picture>, <audio>, and <video> elements to load alternate file versions

      <audio> - container for audio files. An audio player will be displayed in the browser

      <video> - container for video files. A video player will be displayed in the browser

       

      Scripting

      <script> - used to link to JavaScript files to add interactivity and behaviours to a web page

      <noscript> - a container for content that will be displayed when scripting is disabled in the browser

      <canvas> - a container for displaying images and drawings that can be controlled with JavaScript

       

      Table Elements

      <table> - the main container for a table on a webpage

      <thead> - the container for the heading rows of a table

      <tfoot> - if a table has a footer row, this is the container

      <tbody> - container for the main data of the table

      <caption> - the label for the table

      <col> - element used to create control over a column in the table, mostly used for styling

      <colgroup> - a grouping of columns

      <tr> - a table row

      <td> - a table data cell

      <th> - a table heading cell

       

      Form Elements

      <form> - container for any form on a webpage

      <input> - nearly all form elements for collecting data use this

      <label> - a label for any form element

      <fieldset> - a box drawn around a group of form elements and labels

      <legend> - a label added to a fieldset

      <button> - buttons that can be used inside forms or outside of forms

      <select> - a container for a dropdown list

      <option> - a single entry in a dropdown list

      <optgroup> - a grouping of option elements appears as an extra heading inside the list

      <textarea> - a multiline text entry area

      <progress> - a progress loading bar

       

      13 HTML Tags on Every Site

      As much diversity as there is across websites, the underlying structure of these pages is remarkably similar.

      Nearly every page has headings (page level and others), a navigation section, links, paragraphs of text, lists, a footer, images, and some time or date references. From this list of features we can create a list of 13 tags that you will use on nearly every page.

      Learn this List of Tags and everything about them.

      <h1>

      Heading Level One. The most important heading level on your page. Typically this is used to hold the web site title in the header.

      <h2>

      Heading Level Two. The second most important headings on your page. Typically the heading for your main content.

      <p>

      Paragraph. Most of the text on your web pages will be wrapped in paragraph tags.

      <header>

      The masthead for your page. If you have branding for your page, a company logo, or a website title then these things will appear inside the header element.

      <nav>

      The container for a navigation menu. Navigation menus are usually made up of unordered lists with anchors.

      <main>

      The main container for your content. The main content for your page will be found here. Sometimes the content inside the <main> element is broken up into different <section> or <div> elements.

      <footer>

      The Footer section of your page. copyright notices and secondary navigation can often be found here.

      <ul>

      An Unordered List. A list of items on your page with bullets or icons to the side by default. It is called unordered because the sequence of elements doesn't matter.

      <ol>

      An Ordered List. Also a list of items on your page but the order of the items does matter. For this reason there are numbers or letters beside each item indicating the sequence.

      <li>

      A List Item. Each of the items in an <ol> or <ul> will be wrapped in an <li> tag. The <li> is the ONLY element allowed as a child of the <ol> or <ul>.

      <a>

      Anchors. These are both the link to and the target of links. They can have an href attribute which makes them a link pointing to another location (URL). If they do not have an href then they need to have an id attribute. This makes them the target of some other link or links.

      <img>

      Images. This is the original image element. HTML5 also added a <picture> element which allows for loading alternate versions of the images based on the device loading the image. When <picture> elements are used the <img> becomes the fallback image.

      <time>

      A Time or Date reference. To add semantic value to any time or date reference, the <time> element is used. This way other programs, like search engines can recognize and classify the time information.

       

       

      Basic HTML Page Structure

      The basic HTML used to create a webpage looks like this:

      <!DOCTYPE html>
      <html lang="en">
        <head>
         <meta charset="UTF-8">
         <title>In Class Demo</title>
         <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width" /> 
        </head>

        <body>
          <header>
            <h1>The Page Title</h1>
          </header>

          <nav>
            <ul>
              <li><a href="#">link 1</a></li>
              <li><a href="#">link 2</a></li>
              <li><a href="#">link 3</a></li>
              <li><a href="#">link 4</a></li>
              <li><a href="#">link 5</a></li>
            </ul>
          </nav>

          <main>
            <h2>The Content Title</h2>
            <p>Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipisicing elit. Nulla deleniti voluptas quam enim autem optio rerum, pariatur veritatis laborum, perspiciatis at, nemo error, quos illo quia. Vitae ad nesciunt, voluptates.</p>
            <p>Officiis labore iure ab, enim corrupti in eum totam, recusandae aliquam, explicabo nihil minima architecto. Laboriosam pariatur obcaecati odio asperiores praesentium impedit tempora eligendi, ab autem sit doloremque consequatur, quibusdam!</p>
          </main>

          <footer>
            <p>&copy; <time datetime="2016">2016</time></p>
          </footer>
        </body>
      </html>

      The <head> contains all the meta information about the page.

      The <body> contains all the content which will be visible in the browser.

      Inside the body we will typically have:

      <header>

      <nav>

      <main>

      <footer>

      There may be a few other tags like <div>, <section>, <article>, or <aside>. The order of these tags may var slightly from site to site. However, this will be our main structure.

      The <header> will contain an <h1> and sometimes an <img>

      The <nav> will contain an unordered list of anchors (linking to the other pages in the site).

      The <main> is your main content for this page.

      The <footer> is the secondary navigation or meta information about the site.

       

      Previous Previous: 13 HTML Tags on Every Site Next Next: Colours in CSS

      Colours in CSS

      CSS supports a wide variety of color values (Links to an external site.). A quick and simple way to get a nice range of shades of any colours is the HSL value.  With a range of percentages we have a range of light to dark shades of a particular colour.  Here's a quick little app that demo's the range of HSL.

      Colours in CSS

      Colour can be added in several ways through CSS. It can also be written in multiple ways.

      The CSS properties which allow you to set a colour are:

      color - text colour

      background-color - colour behind the text

      border-color - colour of the border drawn around elements

      outline-color - similar to a border but doesn't create any space on the page. Outlines are drawn over top of the padding.

      text-shadow - A shadow placed on every letter. You can control the colour of the shadow.

      box-shadow - Similar to the text-shadow except this will be around the edges of the content box for the element.

      Remember to use the American spelling for color.

       

      Colour Values

      There are many different ways to write a colour value in CSS. Any of these are acceptable in all modern browsers. http://caniuse.com/#search=hsla (Links to an external site.)

      1. Named Colours. Values can be any of the 127 named colours. Eg: Black, white, red, blue, salmon, khaki, goldenrod, etc.
      2. Six-digit HEX values. Starting with a number sign and followed by six hexidecimal digits. The first two digits are red, the second two are green, and the last two are blue. Each value ranges from 00 to FF. In decimal values these are the equivalent of 0 - 255. Eg. #34FF72
      3. Three-digit HEX values. If the first and second digit of each HEX value are the same then you can use a three-digit version of the colour. #44FF66 could be written as #4F6. You have to use either six or three digits. Any other number will fail.
      4. rgb( ) function. If you have the red, green, and blue values as decimal numbers instead of HEX values then you can use the rgb( ) function. Each of the three numbers can be between 0 and 255. Eg: rgb(45, 255, 0)
      5. rgba( ) function. If you want to include an alpha channel (degree of transparency) with your colour then use the rgba( ) function. The first three values will be the red, green and blue values. The fourth value will be the percentage of alpha. eg: rgba(45, 255, 0, .50) - 50% transparent version of the previous colour.
      6. hsl( ) function. The Hue, Saturation, Lightness values for a colour. This is a different way of looking at colour. The first value is HUE - a number between 0 and 360 which represents where on the colour wheel the colour would appear. Second value is saturation and it represents the amount of or lack of colour intensity with a value between 0 and 100. The third value is the lightness. It is a value between 0 and 100 that represents the amount of white or black added to the colour. zero would be all black and 100 would be as much white as possible. Eg: hsl(120, 100%, 50%) - this would be a redish hue with as much colour intensity as possible and no extra white or black.
      7. hsla( ) function. This is the same as the hsl( ) function except there is an alpha value added at the end. Eg: hsla( 120, 100%, 50%, .5) - Same as the previous example except at 50% alpha.

      CSS Font/Text Properties I

      There is a long list of text and font properties that you can use to modify the appearance of your content on a webpage.

      This codepen - http://codepen.io/mad-d/pen/ALWVBV?editors=1100#0 (Links to an external site.) will allow you to edit the text and CSS to experiment with these properties.

      Each paragraph element has the name or names of the properties being used on that paragraph.

      The font-size is being controlled globally with this CSS:

      html{
       font-size: 20px;
       line-height: 1;
      }

      And the alignment of all the paragraphs is being controlled with this CSS:

      p{
       float:left;
       width: 21%;
       box-sizing: border-box;
       background-color: #e4e4e4;
       padding: 0 1rem;
       margin: 2%;
      }

      Each of the paragraphs has 1rem of space added on the left and right but nothing on the top or bottom.

      The margin is creating space between the paragraphs.

      Every fourth paragraph is also given this CSS declaration:

      clear:left;

      Which makes sure it appears on the next line and lines up with the other three paragraphs in it's row.

       

      Here is the list of properties demonstrated on the page

      color - The colour of the text

      font-weight - use keywords like bolder, bold, normal, light, and lighter or numbers 100, 200, 300, ... 900

      font-style - normal or italic

      font-family - A comma separated list of all the fonts, in order of preference, that you want the browser to try and apply

      font-size - The height of the text in px, em, rem, % or other units.

      font-stretch - A fairly new property that the browser to expand or condense a font's appearance.

      font-variant - convert the text to smallcaps if possible.

      line-height -  The height of each line of text. Without units this is proportional to the font-size for the element.

      text-indent - How much to indent or outdent the text

      text-decoration - underline, overline, or strike-through.

      text-transform - Capitalize, UPPERCASE or lowercase.

      text-align - left, right, center, or justify

      text-shadow - apply a shadow to each letter. adjust the horizontal distance, vertical distance, blur radius and colour.

      direction - The actual direction of the text rtl or ltr.

      unicode-bidi - Allows control of BiDirectional writing Left-to-Right or Right-to-Left

      writing-mode - used with text-orientation to control orientation of text (eg: vertical writing)

      text-orientation - used with writing mode to control orientation of text (eg: vertical writing)

      word-spacing - control the spacing between words

      letter-spacing - control the spacing between individual characters

      ::first-letter - A pseudo-element selector which lets you target the first letter of text in any element

      ::first-line - A pseudo-element selector which lets you target the first line of text in any element.

      whitespace - How extra whitespace, like carriage returns, should be displayed.

       

      MDN reference for CSS properties

      https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/Reference (Links to an external site.) 

      All these properties can be found in that list

      Linking to CSS Files

      <link>

      The first and most common way to attach a CSS file to your webpage is with a <link> tag.

      <link rel="stylesheet" href="main.css" type="text/css" />

      The <link> tag must have an href attribute which points to the CSS file to attach and a rel (relationship) attribute that explains to the browser the purpose of the link, which in this case is a stylesheet.

      The type attribute is a common best practice but is technically not required.

       

      @import

      The second way to load a CSS file is to use the @import operator either inside your <style> element or from inside your CSS file. With either approach you should always put the @import at the top of the file.

      @import url("http://www.example.com/css/main.css");

      This example would import the file main.css from a folder called "css" which sits on the www.example.com (Links to an external site.) domain.

      If you want, you may also import a CSS file that sits on the same server as your HTML or CSS file.

      @import url("./css/main.css");

      The above example would start looking in the same folder as the current HTML file and from there, go into a folder called css and then locate the file called main.css.

      A 404 error on an imported file will not prevent the other CSS from being applied.

       

      Previous Previous: CSS Font/Text Properties I Next Next: HTML Images

      HTML Images

      The Basics

      We will leave the discussion of the <picture>, <figure>, and <source> elements for later. Mainly because we can get images appearing on our pages with just the <img> element.

      <img src="http://www.example.com/assets/balloons-and-kittens.jpg" 
        alt="The text for screen readers and for the user when the image fails to load" 
        title="The mouseover text description of the image" />

      This example of an HTML image element shows the two required attributes - src and alt as well as the useful attribute title.

      src - (source) the absolute path or relative path from the HTML file's location to load the image.

      alt - (alternate text) You must always provide alternate text for your image. When people with visual impairments visit your website it is with a screen reader program which will read out the contents of your page. If you have images on your page, the screen reader will read out the alternate text. The text should describe the image in some detail. Sometimes, image files get moved or deleted or renamed. When this happens, they will fail to appear on your page. The alternate text will be displayed in place of the missing image. The alternate text will also be display while the image is loading. If the user has a slow connection or the image is really large then they will also see the text and know to wait for the image.

       

      Examples

      At any time we can add an image to our webpage.  If the images is hosted online, other's will be able to see it.  Let's take a look at how this works.

       

      <img>

      The HTML Tag is the IMG Element, and the source(src) of the element is the url of an image of meekrats hosted on wikipedia.

       

      alt=""

      We can describe this image of meekrats to assisted technologies which can read this (alt)ernative text increasing the quality of content for everyone.

       

      Title Tooltip

      We can also describe the image with a tooltip if the mouse is held over it for a few seconds.  The tooltip text is populated from the title attribute.

       

      Widths and Height

      We can also set explicit widths and heights of an image overriding it's size of the image dimensions.  We have to note however this does not affect image file size and we will discus alternative image loading strategies later in this semester.

      The image dimensions are rendered at 150 x 150, these attributes are rendered in pixels and have overridden the images native 600 x 400 dimensions

      Previous Previous: Linking to CSS Files Next Next: Absolute and Relative Paths

      Absolute and Relative Paths

      Resources to Load

      There are lots of resources that you will want to load from an HTML file.

      Images can be loaded using <img>, <picture> or <source> elements.

      Audio files can be loaded using <audio> or <source> elements

      Video files can be loaded using <video> or <source> elements

      CSS files can be loaded using <link> elements or @import operators

      JavaScript files can be loaded using <script> elements

      Icons can be loaded using <link> elements too.

      Here are a few examples of these being loaded.

      <link rel="stylesheet" href="main.css" />
      <link rel="shortcut icon" href="/favicon.png" />
      <script src="app.js"></script>

      <picture>
        <source src="puppiesx2.jpg" />
        <img src="puppies.jpg" />
      </picture>

      <a href="../folder/cats.jpg">Click to see Cats</a>

      Notice that some of these elements use an src attribute and others use an href attribute.

      Anchor elements also use paths to point to other resources. The examples above will all automatically load the resource. The <a> element will point to a resource but will only load it into the browser when the user clicks on the displayed text.

       

      Types of Paths

      An Absolute path is one that can be used from any location at any time. It won't matter from which web page the resource is being loaded. It will always work (as long as the resource has not be removed).

      Examples of Absolute paths

      http://www.example.com/index.html (Links to an external site.) - starts with http or https
      https://www.example.com/folder/products.css (Links to an external site.) - can have a folder as part of the name

      /main.js - starts with a forward slash, which represents the root folder of the domain
      /assets/robots.png - can contain folder names too

      A Relative path is one that works within a certain context. A relative path is a path that starts with the location of the current webpage.

      advertising.css - just a file name, needs to be in the same folder as current file
      ./advertising.css - exact same as the line above. period represents the current folder

      ./assets/gorilla.jpg - start in the current folder, then folder called assets to find gorilla.jpg
      assets/gorilla.jpg - exact same as the line above

      ../scripts/main.js - start in the current location then go up one level in the directory structure to find a folder called scripts. main.js should be inside the folder called scripts
      ./../scripts/main.js - exact same as line above

       

      Linking from CSS, HTML, and JavaScript

      Linking to an asset from HTML or CSS will work the exact same way. BOTH will use the same relative path - relative to the current folder of the HTML file.

      Linking to an asset or loading an asset from JavaScript, the relative path with be relative to the location of the JavaScript file.

        Keyboard Shortcuts Brackets & Emmet

        Brackets

        Brackets is a great tool for quick and easy web development. While not as full-featured as Dreamweaver, for typical development cases it has all you need.

        There are a bunch of keyboard shortcuts that you can use to make your development even faster. If you click on the Edit menu in Brackets you will see the list of common keyboard shortcuts.

        This image shows the OSX version but Windows has the same shortcuts. Just replace the Command key with the Control key in most cases.

        The symbols are:

        ⌘ - Command

        ⇧ - Shift

        ⎇ - Option

        ^ - Control

        Experiment with these shortcuts if you are not sure what they do.

         

        Emmet

        Emmet is a great plugin for Brackets that you can add through the extension manager. Just search for "emmet".

        With Emmet installed you can speed up your code entry in HTML and CSS. All the shortcuts are activated by hitting the tab key immediately after you type the macro. Here are a few common macros:

        html:5   - this will create a new HTML5 page structure. Great for starting your file.

        li*5>a[href="#"]>{link $} - this will create 5 list item tags with an anchor tag nested inside each one. Each anchor tag will have an href attribute with "#" as its value and then the word "link" followed by a number.

        p*4>lorem - this will create 4 paragraphs and add the lorem ipsum text inside each one.

        header>h1+h2 - this will create a header with both an h1 and h2 tag inside it.

        Actually, Emmet will let you write long chains of content using almost any CSS selector. Have a look at the official documentation to see all the possibilities.

        http://docs.emmet.io/ (Links to an external site.) 

        Then go back and look again after you have learned some more CSS.

        Emmet will also have its own menu in Brackets. Many of the keyboard shortcuts are listed there.

         

         

        Extension Folders

        It's important to note that all the extensions are things that you can copy and edit too. Many have parameters and settings that you can change. Emmet's folder is located here on OSX:

        /Users/griffis/Library/Application Support/Brackets/extensions/user/brackets-emmet

        If you look at the official Emmet documentation it will tell you what you can customize in the .json files.

        The snippets.json file is a few folders deeper. Starting from the folder above go to:

        ./node_modules/emmet/lib/snippets.json 

        You can edit the snippets.json file to create new shortcuts for yourself.

        http://docs.emmet.io/customization/ (Links to an external site.)

        Here is the original snippets file used in Emmet

        https://github.com/emmetio/emmet/blob/master/lib/snippets.json (Links to an external site.)

        Just be careful when creating your own or editing the live one. Make sure you create a backup of the original.

        Block vs. Inline Elements

        Page Flow

        Browsers are designed to read through your HTML in order from top to bottom of the file and then render them in that same order - Top to bottom and left to right (or right to left depending on the unicode-bidi and direction value of the language)

        There are certain elements that make up the structure of the page and other elements only lend semantics to the text content. Some elements are only allowed to exist within others. The <li> list item is a good example. The only place it is allowed to exist is immediately inside an ordered or unordered list.

        The browser reads through your HTML and will try to place elements on the screen in the order that you have specified. Some elements must be nested inside others, some will spread out and fill the width of the screen and others will collapse to a smaller size and happily sit beside other elements.

        Block Elements

        These are the elements which expand and fill the width of their containing element. <p>, <header>, <h1>, <nav>, <section>, <main>, <div>, and <footer> are all good examples of block elements. The browsers all follow these guidelines for rendering block elements:

        1. Whenever possible, expand to fill the width of your containing element.

        2. Always jump to a new line to start displaying content.

        3. Whatever element follows the block element must start on a new line.

        Inline Elements

        Inline elements are the ones that wrap tightly around their content and will happily sit beside other elements. Examples of inline elements include <a>, <em>, <strong>, <time>, <code>, and <mark>. If you think about it the inline elements make sense in how they render. You wouldn't want to add a link inside the middle of a paragraph and have the link force all the other text off the same line as the link. The link text could be part of a sentence. The same logic applies to all the inline elements.

         

        Sample

         

        Previous Previous: Keyboard Shortcuts Brackets & Emmet Next Next: CSS Box Model

        CSS Box Model

        The Box Model (Links to an external site.) is all about spacing and measurements of an element. When we want to add space between things we add that space with a CSS property known as margin.  We can also add space inside known as padding and a decorative border.

         

        CSS Box Model 

        In this image we will see a border being applied to the paragraph.  The space between the text and the paragraph well be expanded to 1em and the space around the border will be pushed out 2em.

         

        Box Model as Picture Frame

        Centering Layout -  Margin: 0 auto;

        The margin property can also be used to centered layout. the auto value automatically calculates the remaining space in between.

        https://www.sitepoint.com/atoz-css-screencast/ (Links to an external site.)

         

        Previous Previous: Block vs. Inline Elements Next Next: CSS height vs. line-height

        CSS height vs. line-height

        In CSS height and line-height are two different properties that can sometimes lead to conflicts in your display if you don't understand how they work.

        height - is the height of the entire element. Your paragraph, heading, link, list item, time reference, etc.

        line-height - is the height of each and every line of text. It is the display area allowed for your text. 

        Both properties work independently of each other. If you were dealing with a paragraph that had four lines of text, the line-height values could add up to more than the amount given for the height. They could actually spill out over the edges of the paragraph. The line-height could create an invisible amount of space above or below your paragraph if the line-height values exceed the paragraph height. This is one of the reasons we avoid giving a fixed height to elements.

        When dealing with an inline element like an anchor (link) we only have one line of text. Yet the height and line-height still work independently of each other. Either one can be bigger than the other and create extra space above or below the element.

         

        Line-height and font-size

        There is also a relationship between font-size and line-height. The line-height creates the space in which your font-size is displayed. If your font-size is bigger than the line-height then your multiple lines of text can actually overlap each other. While not usually something you want, this effect can be used to create interesting type design for your titles.

         

        Previous Previous: CSS Box Model Next Next: CSS ClassNames and IDs

        CSS ClassNames and IDs

        Every HTML element supports a variety of attributes. Some of the common attributes (Links to an external site.) we can use to style our elements are:

        1. Element Selector - Style any HTML Element p{}
        2. Id Selector - A unique id that should only be used once.
        3. Class Selector - A style we can use on more than one element.
        4. Attribute Selector - More unique attribute contions.
        5. nth-child Selector - Odd or even, every first, second, third..

        Attribute Selector Styles

        Reference to targeting elements with a variety of selectors in CSS.

        As we progress further along we will most commonly use the class selector. This helps avoid specificity issues for instance an id overriding the styles of the class. 

        Previous Previous: CSS height vs. line-height Next Next: CSS Specificity and Rendering Order

        CSS Specificity and Rendering Order

        CSS has a variety of rules that define what styles override and triumph in the final render.

        The first rule we'll see is the cascade, CSS is applied TOP -> DOWN. The last class read in the CSS will be the final rendered output.

        This is true for whatever set of elements are not conflicted by other sets of specificity (Links to an external site.) in the CSS. Classes have equal importance and it does not matter the order of the attributes on the paragraph element. Reversed (three two one) the last class in the css file is still the rendered output.

        Certain attributes however take priority over other attributes regardless of the order it appears in the CSS file.  

        For example: An id attribute will override any class attributes.

        And an Inline style attribute on the HTML tag will overide both a class and an id.

        And in rare cases if you absolutely need a style to stay consistent the !important declaration. 

         

        CSS Specificity

        When the browser is reading the CSS and applying it to various elements on the page, it needs to have a way of deciding which styles are applied first, second, third, and so on. Specificity is the way it does that.

        The simple version of the system is this - tag styles are applied first, then class styles, and then id styles.

        While the simple version is technically correct it does not help us when we start to combine selectors or use things like attribute selectors.

        So, what happens is the browser assigns levels of importance to different types of selectors and then adds up the values. After adding up all the values then you have a total number which can be used to rank all the styles so that they can be applied in order.

        Still not clear? Probably not. Here is a good article that explains it as well as I can - http://css-tricks.com/specifics-on-css-specificity/ (Links to an external site.)

        Here is another article covering the same topic - http://www.sitepoint.com/web-foundations/specificity/ (Links to an external site.)

        If neither of those is to your liking then here is another one which uses analogies from Star Wars to help drive the point home.

        http://www.stuffandnonsense.co.uk/archives/css_specificity_wars.html (Links to an external site.)

         

        Sample Chart showing application of the idea:

         

         

        Note: Pseudo-classes and attribute selectors have the same weight as classes. Pseudo-elements have the same weight as tags. The asterix in the above example refers to inline styles. Eg: <p style="color:red"> - which we want to avoid at all times, as a best practice.

         

        Table 6. Selector Specificity Results
        Selector Inline Style IDs Classes, Attributes, and Pseudo-classes Element Types and Pseudo-elements
        body#home div#warning
        p.message        		 0 2 1 3
        * body#home>div#warning
        p.message        		 0 2 1 3
        #home #warning
        p.message        		 0 2 1 1
        #warning p.message 0 1 1 1
        #warning p 0 1 0 1
        p.message 0 0 1 1
        p 0 0 0 1

         

         

        Important!

        Once you have all the styles ranked by specificity according to the rules outlined above you would think that we are done.

        Actually there is one more rule to learn. Sometimes, despite our best efforts to write our selectors in a way that makes them rank the way we expect, there might be one property that is misbehaving. 

        If you ever want to take one single property inside of one style and solve a conflict (or potential one) then we can add the !important modifier to that one line of CSS.

        p span.red{ 
          font-family:Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; 
          font-size:20px; 
          color: red; 
        }

         

        So, lets say that there is some other selector which is overriding that red color that we really wanted to use. We can alter our CSS to make sure that the red colour is used despite any other CSS in our file.

        p span.red{ 
          font-family:Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; 
          font-size:20px; 
          color: red !important; 
        }

         

        Previous Previous: CSS ClassNames and IDs Next Next: Colour Schemes

        Colour Schemes

        When creating a colour scheme for your website you are trying to create a combination of colours that give an appropriate atmosphere for the subject matter.

        Different colours effect your user's psychology in different ways.

        Different colours have cultural meaning.

        Like sound, colour is made up of wavelengths. For both, you need wavelengths that fit together mathematically.

        A great website to help you creating your colour scheme is https://color.adobe.com/ (Links to an external site.)

        There are different types of colour schemes, including:

        1. Analogous - colours that are all derived from within a small group of angles around the colour wheel.

        2. Monochromatic - colours that all have the same hue but different values for Saturation and/or Lightness.

        3. Complementary - colour combinations that use Hues that are opposite each other on the colour wheel. Be careful with using these for foreground background combinations.

        On the Adobe Color site you can drag the circles for each colour and see how the others move in concert with them to create an appropriate scheme. Custom will let you do whatever you like.

        Some Sites About Colour Schemes

        HTML Validation

        It's always a good idea to validate your HTML. Make sure you haven't made any errors that may cause odd things to happen with your CSS or content in the browser.

        W3C has an HTML and a CSS validator. You can enter your URL (if the page is available online) or upload a file, or copy and paste your file contents and then press the validate button.

        HTML validator - https://validator.w3.org/ (Links to an external site.) 

        CSS validator - https://jigsaw.w3.org/css-validator/ (Links to an external site.) 

        You will get a pass or fail message along with the details. Most of the time you will get a list of things. Some will be indicated as an ERROR and some will be a WARNING.

        Some warnings can be ignored. All Errors should be addressed. 

        There will be a few instances where you get a warning or an error because you have used something that your browser supports but that technically is not part of the HTML standard. It is better to be practical about what you are building rather than worry solely about the HTML standard.

        Brackets

        Brackets has a great plugin called w3cvalidation by Raymond Camden. It allows for w3c validating your HTML right in Brackets.

        Click the Extension Manager button on the right side of the interface and search for w3cvalidation.

        Click the Install button and add it to Brackets.

        Now in the Edit menu you will see a new option at the bottom - F9 to refresh validation.

        Click F9 and look in the bottom right of your IDE interface.

        See the golden triangle with the exclamation mark? That is my indicator telling me that I have some errors in my page.

        Click on the triangle to see a list of your validation errors.

        More About HTML Semantics

        There are a variety of elements in HTML that are used for providing structure to content in articles.

        HTML formats and describes structure for things such as this Superscript and these bold words.

        The semantics and hierarchical structure (Links to an external site.) of the HTML document is important for a variety of reasons

        1. The content is organized in a well formated way.
        2. It's accessible without the need of vision
        3. Optimized for search engines
        4. Responsible development etiquette, if our styles fail, and the html is well formatted, the content is still accessible.

        We can be confident that if all else fails, and our HTML is formatted correctly, the content will still be strong enough to share the intended information.

        Our first introduction to HTML illustrates a basic article. The text is Latin placeholder known as Lorem Ipsum. There is the main heading, some content, a subtitle more content, and a list. Try re-sizing your browser, by default, the web is responsive.

        HTML Lorem Ipsum Article

        By default all browsers give HTML some style.  These include increased font size and boldness on headers, spacing for the indentation of quotes and the items in the numbered list, and the space between each of these things. 

        This default styling can be different across browsers and screen sizes and is usually in relation to the base line font size.

        Also by default we see that HTML scales to any screen size and can be served to many devices and systems.

          CSS Background Images

          Alternatively to the HTML Image tag we can apply background image to any HTML element.  This includes divs that act as banner as well as custom icons for submit buttons.

          In the CSS Media Queries module you can also see an example of how we can use CSS Background Images to load different sized images for different sized breakpoints.  This can help with an effective strategy in minimizing the file-size for mobile devices.

          The one thing to consider with Images vs CSS Background Images are if the image should be view-able if the CSS cannot render, if the image serves a higher purpose and the content is better because of it we can use the HTML Image tag, if the image is more presentational, we can do a few cool tricks with the background image property.

          By default there is a couple things to observe here.  Background images will automatically repeat, and text and other elements can be layered over top of the background.

           

          Background Repeat

          We can prevent the repeating background with the CSS property background-repeat (Links to an external site.).

          There is also repeat-x and repeat-y if we wanted to repeat the image horizontally or vertically.

           

          Background-image on body

          We can also add a full sized background (Links to an external site.) image on the body and we can layer our other elements over top of that.

           

          Background-position

          We can also change the position of the background image both horizontally and vertically. 

           

          Sometimes you want to have a background image behind your text. BE CAREFUL WHEN DOING THIS.

          It is very easy to get a background image that prevents the user from reading the text. This codepen has an example as well as some guidelines for you to follow when creating your background - text combination.

           

          Previous Previous: Week 4 References Next Next: Image Optimization

          Image Optimization

          Best Practices for Images (including optimization)

          1. Give your images filenames that are descriptive and in Plain English

          2. Use hyphens instead of spaces in your filenames.

          3. Use descriptive words in your Alt attributes. Remember about screen readers.

          4. Plan your Image Dimensions for all devices and create multiple versions of each image.

          5. Reduce the file sizes of your images using software like Photoshop. 

          6. Know which image File Type to use for the right situations (png, jpg, gif)

          7. Beware of decorative images that serve no purpose other than bloating the size of your page.

          8. Remember that you can use radial blur on non-focal, unimportant areas of your image to further reduce filesize.

          9. Make sure that your server is setup to use gzip to compress image files.

          10. Learn to crop your images to draw attention to important elements.

           

          Here is a great short article on comparing image formats and saving size - http://www.sitepoint.com/saving-bandwidth-by-using-images-the-smart-way/ (Links to an external site.) 

           

          Previous Previous: CSS Background Images Next Next: CSS Shorthand Properties

          CSS Shorthand Properties

          The most common CSS shorthand properties are padding, margin, font, border, and background. Each lets you combine several other CSS property declarations into a single line.

          The order of your property values is important. Keep this in mind when writing them.

          Padding or Margin

          The padding or margin for any element can be written four different ways with the padding or margin property.

          padding: 4px;              All four sides get 4px padding
          padding: 2px 4px;          Top and bottom get 2px, left and right get 4px
          padding: 3px 1px 4px;      Top gets 3px, left and right get 1px, bottom gets 4px
          padding: 3px 1px 4px 2px;  Top 3px, right 1px, bottom 4px, left 2px

           You can replace the word padding with the word margin to get the different values set. They work the same way.

          The values are applied in clockwise order from the top. It will always be top, right, bottom, left.

          The browser applies the first number to the top and then looks for a second number. If the second number is not there it goes back and applies the first number to all the other sides.

          If there are two numbers, the first one is read and applied to the top, then the second is read and applied to the right. Next the browser looks for a third number for the bottom. If the third is missing it goes back and looks for the opposite side (the top) to get the value. Then the fourth number being missing, the opposite value (the right) is used for the left side.

          For three numbers it follows the same order. first number for the top, second number for the right, third number for the bottom and then go to the opposite side for the left value because the 4th number is missing.

          For four numbers it just reads them in order - top, right, bottom, left.

          Font

          The font property lets you combine font-style, font-variant, font-weight, font-stretch, font-size, line-height, and font-family all in one property.

          You are allowed to omit properties as long as the ones you use follow this order.

          font: italic smallcaps bold 2.0rem/1.6 Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;

          In this example I skipped font-stretch.

          You can always tell the font-size and line-height apart because of the forward slash between them. The font-family is always the list at the end. Everything else has keywords for the browser to recognize.

          Here is another valid but simpler example.

          font: 2.0rem Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; 

          Border

          The border has a similar approach to padding and margin. When you use border-color, border-style, or border-width then you can list one, two, three, or four values.

          border-color: red, blue, goldenrod, fuschia;

          The one, two, three, or four values will be applied the same way as the padding or margin would to the four sides.

          However, it is rare to use different values for the four sides of a border.

          It is much more common to use the same values for two, three or four sides. So, we apply the same border to all the sides and then delete the one or ones we don't want.

          border: 1px solid black;

          The border property wants three values, in this order, border-width, border-style, border-color. It will apply these values to all four sides automatically. Then you can remove the side(s) you want.

          border-left: none;
          border-top: none;

          If you just really love typing CSS and want to be specific about all the different values then you can use the full names.

          border-left-color: red;
          border-left-width: 2px;
          border-left-style: dotted;
          border-top-color: black;
          border-top-width: 1px;
          border-top-style: dashed;
          ... and so on...

          Background

          The background is a shorthand property that has evolved over time to include more and more values. For this reason I often break it up into several properties. It just makes it easier to edit. The full background property uses these properties in this order:

          background-image, background-position, background-size, background-repeat, background-origin, background-clip, background-attachment, background-color

          Again, properties can be skipped as long as they follow this order. Some browsers will allow for a different order.

          background: url(../img/cat.jpg) center top 500px 400px no-repeat padding-box border-box scroll blue;

           Here is a simpler more typical example:

          background: url(../img/cat.jpg) center center cover no-repeat blue;

          This one sets a blue background, centers one copy of the image horizontally and vertically and then stretches or squashes it while maintaining the aspect ratio, to make sure that the whole element has its entire background covered.

          Here are the references for all the background properties:

          background - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/background (Links to an external site.) 

          background-image - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/background-image (Links to an external site.) 

          background-position - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/background-position (Links to an external site.) 

          background-size - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/background-size (Links to an external site.) 

          background-repeat - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/background-repeat (Links to an external site.) 

          background-origin - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/background-origin (Links to an external site.) 

          background-clip - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/background-clip (Links to an external site.) 

          background-attachment - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/background-attachment (Links to an external site.) 

          background-color - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/background-color (Links to an external site.) 

          Previous Previous: Image Optimization Next Next: CSS Font Stacks

          CSS Font Stacks

          When you are creating the values for the CSS font-family property, we always have to keep in mind that group of people who are still using old versions of Internet Explorer, Windows XP, Mac OS 9, and other marginal browsers.

          The font stack is your list of desired fonts in descending order of preference. We want to make sure that everyone gets a font that you have purposefully selected.

          p{
            font-family: Tuscaloosa, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
          }

          In the example above we start with a custom font that we picked from thousands - Tuscaloosa.

          Then Arial that will exist on 99% of copies of Windows and Helvetica which will appear on nearly every copy of Mac.

          Finally, the generic family name sans-serif - for the 5,472 people out there who refuse to upgrade and the 98,963 people who don't know how to upgrade.

          How to Pick a Fallback Font

          In your CSS you will be entering a value for the height of your font. However, different fonts are designed differently and have widely varied widths for each character.  They also have different dimensions for different parts of the letters. We want something that closely mimics our original font, as much as possible. 

          There are lots of parts to each letter to consider when finding a match.

          Getting a close match means that your layout will retain similar dimensions when the font changes. The most important parts for a good match are the Counter, the Bowl, and the X-height. If these parts match closely then you will have a good match.

          Good & Poor Matches

           

          This is a screenshot from Google Fonts showing the same text in three fonts - Lato, Monserrat, and Roboto. Lato and Roboto would be fairly good alternatives to each other. Monserrat has a different width and a different feel to it. It would not make a good fall back font for either Lato or Roboto.

           

          Serif and Sans-serif

          What's the difference?

          The font being used for the body text on this page is sans-serif. None of the characters have serifs. 

          Serifs are the small decorative flairs at the ends of the letters.

           

           

           

          Previous Previous: CSS Shorthand Properties Next Next: Web Fonts

          Web Fonts

          @font-face

          When you want to use a specific font that you know will not likely be available on most user's computers then you need to dynamically load that new font to their browser. We can do this using the @font-face at-rule.

          Here is a simple example of an @font-face entry.

          @font-face{
            font-family: 'Fantastico';
            src: local(fantasticoFont),
                 url('http://www.example.com/fonts/fantastico.ttf') format('truetype'),
                 url('http://www.example.com/fonts/fantastico.eot (Links to an external site.)') format('embedded-opentype');
          } 

          Inside the @font-face at-rule you must have a font-family declaration. This will tell the rest of your CSS page what to call your imported font.

          The next declaration is the src. These are all the possible variations that you want the browser to try and load. Think of this like a font-stack. The first possible value is local(fantasticoFont). That means the browser should check the user's computer for an installed font called fantasticoFont. If that is not found then the browser will run through the possible url values looking for a match. There is also an optional format( ) indicator after the URL. These are recommended to help the browser decide which font it can render.

          Not all browsers can render every type of font. Here is a reference for which browsers can render which types.

          EOT - http://caniuse.com/#feat=eot (Links to an external site.)

          WOFF - http://caniuse.com/#feat=woff (Links to an external site.)

          WOFF 2 - http://caniuse.com/#feat=woff2 (Links to an external site.) 

          TTF/OTF - http://caniuse.com/#feat=ttf (Links to an external site.)

          SVG - http://caniuse.com/#feat=svg-fonts (Links to an external site.) 

          When you have the option to include multiple types it is always better to do so.

          You are allowed to have multiple @font-face at-rules in your CSS in order to import multiple fonts or font variants.

          Each one needs to have a unique name and you should include other font style properties for each font.

          @font-face{
            font-family: Fantasico;
            font-weight: normal;
            font-style: normal;
            src: url('http://www.example.com/fonts/fantastico.woff') format('woff');
          }
          @font-face{
            font-family: FantasticoBold;
            font-weight: bold;
            font-style: normal;
            src: url('http://www.example.com/fonts/fantasticoBold.woff') format('woff');
          }

          This example loads a normal and a bold version of the font. Well designed fonts are often broken up into different font files and each file has a different weight, style, or variant.

          You can just import the normal version and then use the bold or italic or smallcaps values with them... However, you will have a lower quality version of that on your webpage. The browser will be guessing about how to alter the font. It will not be the same as the designed bold version.

          Once you have imported you font versions then you can use that font family name in your CSS.

          h1{
            font-family: FantasticoBold, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
            font-weight: bold;
          }
          p{
            font-family: Fantastico, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
            font-weight: normal;
          } 

          Note the use of the full font stack.

          Have a look at these references to see more examples:

          https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/@font-face (Links to an external site.) 

          https://css-tricks.com/snippets/css/using-font-face/ (Links to an external site.) 

          https://css-tricks.com/whats-deal-declaring-font-properties-font-face/ (Links to an external site.) 

           

          Sometimes when you are choosing a font you will find one that has a limited number of characters or you might only want a few of the characters from the font. You can limit the amount of the font which is downloaded and used by defining the unicode-range of the characters you want.

          https://developer.mozilla.org/en/docs/Web/CSS/@font-face/unicode-range (Links to an external site.) 

           

          Google Fonts

          Google and TypeKit have a set of free fonts that has become quite substantial over the last few years. I highly recommend using these when possible.

          The really great thing about using the fonts through Google is that you can simply link to a CSS file on Google's server. Google will determine, based on the request for the file, which browser is being used and will only send back a font that the browser will support.

          https://fonts.google.com/ (Links to an external site.) - Visit the site.

           

          On the right hand side you will see lots of search criteria to narrow down the list of available fonts. Try starting by deselecting the boxes for Display, Handwriting, and Monospace. Then choose to keep either Serif or Sans-Serif. This will give you a much smaller list to start with.

          Then you can toggle and play with the sliders near the bottom right. These will help you narrow down the styles.

          You can click on the text and enter your own words for the preview.

          Once you find a font you like, click the Red plus sign by it's name. This will add the font to your collection and a box will appear at the bottom of the screen with your selections so far.

          Repeat the process with other fonts. Try finding a pair of serif and sans-serif that you like. Add several if you want. You can remove them from the collection later.

          When you are done picking your fonts click on that black box at the bottom.

          There are two red icons near the top right of this box. A download button and a preview button. The download button will give you a zip file with the fonts. You can download it and unzip the file. Then install the fonts to use them locally or move the font files into your web project. Create a font folder and save your font files in there.

          The preview button will let you view both fonts side by side. Example:

          https://fonts.google.com/selection?category=Sans+Serif&stylecount=3&thickness=3&selection.family=BioRhyme:300|Raleway (Links to an external site.)

          If you are happy with your choices (not the ones I picked here) then you can use the <link> or @import provided to the right side of the screen to add them to your HTML or CSS file.

          HTML (inside the <head>)

          <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/css?family=BioRhyme:300|Raleway" rel="stylesheet"/>

          CSS (at the top of your file)

          @import 'https://fonts.googleapis.com/css?family=BioRhyme:300|Raleway';

           

          Font Stacks

          As you saw in the examples at the top of this page, when you import fonts you should still have a full font-stack with fall back fonts for each OS as well as a generic font. There are still devices and browsers out there which cannot download and use custom fonts. For the sake of a little extra typing you can ensure that they have a better interface for the app or website.

           

           

          Previous Previous: CSS Font Stacks Next Next: Safe Fonts

          Safe Fonts

          Safe Fonts

          Older browsers have very limited support for fonts. If a font is not installed on the user's computer then it can't be displayed in the browser. CSS 3 addressed this problem by officially supporting Web Fonts. However, there are still quite a few older browsers out there that don't. 

          So, how do we address the problem of limited font families? The older browsers will only render fonts that already exist on the Operating System.

          http://www.ampsoft.net/webdesign-l/WindowsMacFonts.html (Links to an external site.)

          The above link takes you to a site that provides a list of fonts that are available across the common versions of Windows and their Mac OS equivalents.

          Many computers will have versions of MS Office installed as well which greatly expands the list but we cannot be guaranteed of the user having those.

           

           

          Previous Previous: Web Fonts Next Next: Typographic Rhythm

          Typographic Rhythm

          Strong typography can have a big impact on the perceivable quality of a website.

          Let's look at some examples of strong typography:

          • Best examples of typgraphy (Links to an external site.) - awwwards (Links to an external site.)
          • A journey through beautiful typography (Links to an external site.) - Smashing Magazine (Links to an external site.)
          • Responsive Typography The Basics (Links to an external site.) - ia.net (Links to an external site.)

           

          In CSS, we have a variety of font based styles we can apply to our CSS. The line-height, font-size and margins are the most commonly associated styles with vertical rythym.

          To quote Improving Layout with Vertical Rythm (Links to an external site.):

          If you have a line-height of 1 then your line-height will also be 16px. However, line-heights are usually best sitting between 1.4-1.6 times the size of your font (visually, this just seems to work with most fonts - though don’t take that as a rule, just play around with it). If we then look at having a line-height right in the middle of that, of 1.5, our line-height will be 24px - and that is our baseline number. From here on out, we want to make sure that all the content and typographical elements on our design match or add up to this 24px figure.

          Typecast (Links to an external site.) dives a little deeper into the math of the alignment of ideal text.

           

          font-family - The choice of font used for the element(s).

           

          font-size - The size of the font

          A great site for creating your font-sizes is http://type-scale.com/ (Links to an external site.)  

           

          line-height - The space between the lines of text

           

          font-weight - The Boldness of fonts

           

          text-transform - Uppercase, lowercase

           

          Example: Dissecting A List Apart (Links to an external site.)

          By default, the HTML elements will have their own styles.

          By examining the styles of the H1, H2, and P elements we've copied the styles into our default example and explore the spacing and font styles for these elements. It's a big improvement.

          Previous Previous: Safe Fonts Next Next: Pairing Fonts

          Pairing Fonts

           

          When it comes to great typography online you can spend years learning how to create great typography and how to combine fonts in a manner that best suits the content of your website.

          We are not that course or that program. 

          What we are aiming to do is have you make safe choices while you learn more about design.

          Below are some great tools for picking pairs that work. There are also some good guides and explainations on how typography online works. Don't try to memorize this content. Read a few articles and gradually you will come to understand more about this mystical topic. In the meantime, use the tools and keep your choices limited.

          Start with these guidelines. As you gain experience, start to experiment.

          1. Only use one or two font families on any page. You still need a proper font-stack though - http://www.cssfontstack.com/ (Links to an external site.) .

          2. Pick one serif and one sans-serif.

          3. Use one of the matching guides below to determine whether or not they fit together and provide the necessary feel to your content. 

          4. Limit the number of font sizes on your page to 5.

          5. Limit the number of variations of font-weight, font-style, letter-spacing, and font-variant as much as possible.

           

          Your viewers will use the differences in your fonts to determine a level of importance for every bit of content on your webpage. Don't make it difficult for them.

           

          Think of it this way - If you were building a website for the Royal Bank you wouldn't use comic-sans in hot pink as the font for the body text. That's an obvious one. Now you are starting to learn the more subtle rules for picking fonts.

           

          Pairing Google Fonts

          CSS Units of Measurement

          There are a variety of unit's that we can use to build our websites.

          The primary ones that we will be focusing on are:

          % - Percentage based measurements for layout.

          PX - Pixel based measurements are ideal for layout and media queries.

          REM - Relative measurements are best for fonts and spacing.

           

          REM Relative units of measurement are important because of the diversity of screen sizes and devices our web applications need to support.  With a relative unit of measurement we rely on the default font size of the device.  

          Not all devices will render a default font size of 16px.  16px however is arguably the most common font size but it could very well be 14px on a smaller device.  These two pens illustrate the relationship with PXs and REMs.

           

          REM

          10px / 16px = 0.625REM

          PX (10px)

          Just as a side note about the CSS Box Model, Notice the red and yellow backgrounds and the white spaces? The text inside the red and yellow areas has padding around it to keep the text away from the edges of the background. The white space above, below, and to the sides of the headings is the margin.

          Typography Cheetsheet

          Open Typography Cheatsheet in a new window

          Shortcut Icons & Favicons

          FavIcon

          FavIcon is an icon associated with a URL that is variously displayed, as in a browser's address bar or next to the site name in a bookmark list.

           

          favicon.ico. is not a PNG renamed to favicon.ico. Although some browsers are easygoing enough to forgive this mistake, ICO is a different format, one that supports multiple versions of an image.

          https://css-tricks.com/favicon-quiz/ (Links to an external site.)

           

          There are apps available for creating FavIcon online such as:

          http://www.favicon.cc (Links to an external site.)

          http://www.favicon-generator.org (Links to an external site.)

           

          Link Types for Images

          When you want to create an icon for your website that appears on the tab, beside the page title, as well as in the bookmarks and favourites menus, you need to use a link tag.

          <link rel="icon" href="/favicon.ico" />

          Note: Apple's iOS does not use this link type, nor the sizes attribute, like others mobile browsers do, to select a webpage icon for Web Clip or a start-up placeholder. Instead it uses the non-standard apple-touch-icon and apple-touch-startup-image respectively.

          <link rel="apple-touch-icon" href="/favicon.ico" />

          These samples both point to .ico files that are at the root of the website's directory structure. This is the default location for the icon file. If you create an .ico file and put it at this location then the web browser will ask the web server for it automatically. 

          However, we can also use a .png file and call it anything we want. The image for the icon can be place anywhere we want as long as the path from the current HTML file to the image is correct in the href attribute.

          http://devdocs.io/html/link_types#icon (Links to an external site.)

          https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Link_types (Links to an external site.)

          Later, we will discuss lots of other types of link tags and icons.
