            Setting Up GitHub

            GitHub is an online code repository. It is a place where you can upload and save your code with a team, the world, or just yourself. https://github.com/ (Links to an external site.) 

            Each project you make will be saved as a repo (repository).

            Inside the project repo you can have multiple versions of the code. These are called branches.

            Getting an account is free. Creating public repositories is free. Private repositories require paid accounts but you can sign up to get free paid accounts from - https://education.github.com/discount_requests/new (Links to an external site.)  (this can be done later)

             

            Please sign up for a GitHub.com account now, using your @algonquinlive.com email address 

             

            To understand how to work with GitHub please watch at least the first four videos from this play list.

            https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P6SOVdNVylY&list=PLWjCJDeWfDdfSZOQYvsy_jJiAvx4uaJLB (Links to an external site.)

            Eventually you will want to watch all of them.

            Previous Previous: Week 5 References Next Next: CSS Browser prefixes

            CSS Browser prefixes

            With the advent of CSS3 there came an agreement on how the various browser companies would implement their experimental CSS features. When a company decided to add support for a new CSS feature into the browser it would usually go through a couple browser versions as an experimental feature.

            While it was in this state or if the browser was supporting a non-standard syntax for the feature, a prefix would be added to the name of the property. The prefix would indicate that is was experimental support as well as the specific browser it was for.

            p{
              -ms-border-radius: 20px;
              -o-border-radius: 20px;
              -webkit-border-radius: 20px;
              -moz-border-radius: 20px;
              border-radius: 20px;
            }

            This is an old example of what used to be quite common. For new CSS properties you would have to add a series of prefixes, one for each browser and then add the real property name that everyone would eventually use at the bottom of the list.

            -ms-     Internet Explorer / MS Edge (Microsoft)
            -o-      Opera (older versions)
            -webkit  Chrome, Safari, newer versions of Opera
            -moz-    Firefox

             

            Not every CSS property got a prefixed version in every browser. For example, -o-border-radius never actually existed.

            Not every property was used with a prefix for very long. In many cases only one or two versions of the browser needed the prefix. For browsers like Chrome that could have been a time frame of only 2 - 4 months. 

            Today, many of these prefixed properties have been standard for so long that almost no browser uses them any more.

             

            Tools for Helping

            No one wants to keep track of all the prefixes and manage them in their code. That is why there are tools to help us keep track of them. Write your CSS the way you want without prefixes and then use a tool to add the required ones.

            https://css-tricks.com/autoprefixer/ (Links to an external site.) - an article talking about how to use - https://github.com/postcss/autoprefixer (Links to an external site.) 

            There is also a plugin for Brackets that can do this for you too - Autoprefixer by Mikael Jorhult

             

             

             

            Previous Previous: Setting Up GitHub Next Next: CSS box-sizing

            CSS box-sizing

            The default setting for the box model has the widths and heights of HTML elements calculated by the combined values of the border, width, and padding.

            With this default setting, we've set a width and height of 100px on the box.  There's a 5px wide border and 10px for the padding.  When we click on the buttons we'll see the total calculated value is 130px. 

             

            Breaking down the measurements it looks like this:

            1. Width and Height = 100px
            2. Padding = 10px + 10px = 20px (Left and Right) and (Top and Bottom)
            3. Border = 5px + 5px = 10px (Left and Right) and (Top and Bottom)

            These values give us a width and height of 130px each.

             

            box-sizing: border-box

            Because of great browser support, we are safe to rely on leveraging a css property to change the box-sizing model to calculate everything from the root width.

            When we click the buttons to display the total calculated width now - the box stays at 100px and the border and padding are calculated inside the width.

            Paul Irish, a developer at google recommends assigning the box-sizing: border-box style to all of our HTML elements (Links to an external site.).

            As we progress further along with our layouts we'll see the benefits of having these extra calculations done for us. It's a great advantage to have the total calculated width set by the width style.

             

            Previous Previous: CSS Browser prefixes Next Next: CSS display property

            CSS display property

            CSS Display (Links to an external site.) provides powerful layout and content control capabilities through CSS.  As we explore navigation and layout more we'll see this property used more often.  In the lessons coming up we will see primary differences between inline and block styled elements (Links to an external site.).

             

            Display: Block/inline

            We can see the way these styles exist already. The links above haven't broken these sentences apart but the paragraphs wrapping these lines have.

             

            Unordered List

            Similarly, Ordered and Unordered list items are block level elements like the paragraph above. We will explore HTML navigation later in the module, this can help as a reminder for what might seem like unexpected layout problems we will encounter as we progress further into layout and aligning html elements on various screen sizes.

             

            Display: none

            Two common styles both block and inline elements share are that they are visible and the content is read by screen readers.  If we want to remove content from the flow of the document we can set it's display to none.  This is helpful in setting mobile and desktop specific styles. When there is enough room, there will be more of a greeting from our friend below.

            Previous Previous: CSS box-sizing Next Next: CSS position property

            CSS position property

            By default every HTML Element is given this:

            position: static;

            This is the default value for every element and it allows things to flow left to right and top to bottom based on whether elements are display:block; display:inline;, display:inline-block; and so on.

            There are three other values for position that we can use to control the way elements are stacked and how they are placed relative to each other.

            position: relative;
            position: absolute;
            position: fixed;

            Here is a codepen that shows various combinations of position property values. Fork it and play around.

            Absolute Elements

            When you set an element to position: absolute it will be removed from the normal flow of the page. The browser sets it aside as if it didn't exist. Then it builds the rest of the page. When the rest of the elements are placed on the screen then the browser comes back and places the absolute element on top of it's original position. It will likely be sitting on top of other content that filled in it's original position.

            If you add values for top, right, bottom, or left then the browser will align the element with those values.

            #myDiv{
              position: absolute;
              top: 200px;
              left: 80px;
            }

            With the values in the above example, this element would be placed on the screen with it's top edge 200px from the top of the page and it's left edge 80px away from the left edge of the screen.

            It's also important to note that it will no longer be a true block element. It's width will collapse to wrap around the content that is provided. You can provide a width but by default it will shrink to the width of it's content box.

             

            Relative Elements

            Relatively positioned elements, like absolute ones,  will also be removed from the page while other content is being laid out. The difference is that the original space it would have occupied is left. The following content does not slide up to fill that space. So, when the relative element is put back on the screen as the last item, it will be floating on top of the blank space.

            When you provide values for top, right, bottom, and left then those values will be measured from the original four sides of the relative element.

            #myDiv{
              position: relative;
              top: 20px;
              left: 20px;
            }

            The example above would effectively just push the element down 20px and 20px to the left.

            If you do not provide any values for top, right, bottom, or left then the element will appear as if it is position: static.

             

            Fixed Elements

            Fixed elements behave the same as absolutely positioned elements. The values for top, right, bottom, and left are measured from the edges of the screen.

            The difference is that they will remain in the exact same position as they are originally loaded as you scroll the screen.

             

            Absolute Element inside a Relative Element

            There is one interesting situation that you get when you put an absolute element inside a relative one. Take this HTML as the reference for this example.

            <li><span></span> <img src="img/cat.png" alt="cat" /></li>

            Let's say that we want to create the illusion of a piece of tape holding our cat image on the page. We will display a background image inside the span of a piece of tape.

            If we use just position: relative on the span then the original space for the span will be left behind. If we use position:absolute to position the tape then it will be measured from the edges of the screen and we lose our reference to where the image will appear.

            The solution? Use a combination of the properties.

            Make the parent element (the <li>) position:relative but don't give it any values for top, right, bottom, or left. It will look the same as if it were static.

            Next, make the <span> position: absolute. Normally this would position it relative to the sides of the screen. However, because the <span> is a child of the <li> and the <li> is position: relative, all the top, right, bottom, and left values will be measured from the edges of the <li>.

            li{
              list-style-display: none;  /* get rid of the bullet */
              position: relative;
            }
            li>span{
              position: absolute;
              width: 40px;
              height: 80px;    /* the size of our tape image */
              top: -60px;   /* top edge of span will be 60px above the li edge */
              left: 40%;    /* left edge of span will be 40% the width of the li */
              z-index: 20;
              background-image: url(../img/tape.png);
              background-repeat: no-repeat;
            }

            The tape image will be overlapping the top of the content area of the <li>. This means it will be overlapping the top of the image by 20px. The z-index will make sure it is stacked above the image and between the image and the viewer.

             

            z-index to Control the Stacking Order

            The z-index allows us to move elements towards the user or away from them. If you think of the web page <body> as street level and you are in the sky looking down on the page, then each increase in the z-index will be like going up another floor in a building and getting closer to the user.

            By default, everything on the page is at z-index 1. The stacking order is just controlled by the order that you write things in your HTML. The last thing you have inside the <body> will be placed on the page last.

            The exception to this is anything with the position values relative, absolute, or fixed. They are all removed from the page while it is being built. After all the static content is placed on the page then the relative, absolute, and fixed elements are added, in the order that they appear in your HTML. 

            If you add an integer as the z-index value to any element with a position value of relative, absolute, or fixed, then the z-index will change the order that they are placed back on the page. The highest number gets placed last.

            You can use any value from 1 to 9999.

            If you use -1 as the value then the browser will attempt to put this element behind all the other content at it's location. There can be some quirks with this though. 

             

            References & Resources

            Guide to z-index - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/CSS_Positioning/Understanding_z_index (Links to an external site.) 

            MDN display reference - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/display (Links to an external site.) 

            MDN position reference - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/position (Links to an external site.) 

            MDN z-index reference - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/z-index (Links to an external site.) 

            Previous Previous: CSS display property Next Next: CSS Overflow

            CSS Overflow

            The browser has a great engine for calculating the size of elements and how much space is required by text and images. To allow the browser to do it's work best we try to avoid giving height to any element that is position: static. We can alter the width and the browser will adjust the height to allow all the content to be seen.

            That is the best practice: Set the width and allow the content to flow and adjust the height.

            However, there are cases where you need to set a fixed width and height on an element. There are cases where you need to use the float property. Float also has an effect on the height of the element. Height is ignored for floated elements.

            The overflow property tells the browser to handle situations where the content doesn't fit inside the content box. When this situation arises we have four options - hidden, visible, scroll, or auto.

            Hidden

            #myDiv{
              width: 200px;
              height: 200px;
              overflow: hidden;
            }

             

            Visible

            Let the content spill out of the content box if it needs to. This means that it will be overlapping other content on your page potentially.

            Scroll

            Add scrollbars in both directions just in case.

            You will lose a little more of your content space as the scroll bars are added on the right and bottom edges of the content box.

            Auto

            This is the default value. Let the browser decide how it wants to handle the situation. (usually with scrollbars).

             

            Here is a CodePen with four divs demonstrating the 4 values of overflow:

            CSS Overflow

            Blockquotes and Code Samples

            The HTML <blockquote> Element (or HTML Block Quotation Element) indicates that the enclosed text is an extended quotation. Usually, this is rendered visually by indentation (see Notes (Links to an external site.) for how to change it). A URL for the source of the quotation may be given using the cite attribute, while a text representation of the source can be given using the <cite> (Links to an external site.) element.

            Useful Links

            https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/blockquote (Links to an external site.)

            http://devdocs.io/html/element/blockquote (Links to an external site.)

             

            Example

            <blockquote cite="http://developer.mozilla.org">
  <p>This is a quotation taken from the Mozilla Developer Center.</p>
</blockquote>

             

            Pull Quotes

            There is a practice in publications to try and draw readers into an article by taking interested short passages and duplicating them as a large box of decorative text with a larger font. They hope that readers will see the block of large text and be interested in the article.

            These are known as Pull Quotes.

            Here is a CodePen sample that draws on some content from http://www.sitepoint.com/ (Links to an external site.) to demonstrate the HTML and CSS involved in creating a pull-quote.

            http://codepen.io/mad-d/pen/xwqpWg?editors=110 (Links to an external site.)

            The styles used here are not mandatory ones, just a good example of what you could do.

            Previous Previous: CSS Overflow Next Next: Handling Long Text and Hyphens

            Handling Long Text and Hyphens

            When working with small displays, like mobile phones, or with small areas on your layout you will often come across situations where there is a reeeeeaaaaalllly long word that you wish you could cut into smaller parts so it didn't mess up your interface.

            The solutions to this problem are:

            1. Edit the HTML and manually add hyphens to the words so that the browser can split the word. This leaves you with hyphens even when not required.
            2. Use the &shy; shy hyphen solution to give the browser hints about where to add hyphens in long words. A lot of work, not supported in all browsers, and often you are not the one who is adding the content to the site.
            3. Use CSS to cut off the word at a certain length and then add the elipsis. Both can be done through CSS with reasonably good CSS support. Good solution if you just can't let the text create another line in the interface.
            4. Use CSS to try and automatically inject hyphens. Support for this is getting better. Probably the best solution if it is ok for words to wrap to a second line.

            Here is a great article about the implementation of items 3 and 4. https://justmarkup.com/log/2015/07/31/dealing-with-long-words-in-css/? (Links to an external site.) 

             

            Just the Code

            If you have already read and understand the article above and just need the code to use in your page then here is the TL;DR section.

            Cut off the text and add an elipsis with CSS.

              /* assuming that a width is already set */
  overflow:hidden; 
  white-space: nowrap;
  text-overflow: ellipsis;

             

            Inject hyphens with CSS

              overflow-wrap: break-word;
  word-wrap: break-word;
  -webkit-hyphens: auto;
  -ms-hyphens: auto;
  -moz-hyphens: auto;
  hyphens: auto;

              normalize.css

              Since there is a variation between how different browsers implement their default styles, it has become common practice for people to apply some additional CSS or an extra stylesheet to their web pages which will override these default values. There are different names for these styles - reset and normalize are common ones.

              The most basic and minimal overriding style that people add to their stylesheets is this:

              html{
                box-sizing: border-box;
              }
              *, *:before, *:after{
                box-sizing: inherit;
                padding: 0;
                margin: 0;
              }

              This style sets the calculation of widths and heights on all elements to a default value of border-box instead of content-box.

              It also sets padding and margin on all elements to zero. This way you can be guaranteed that any spaces you add will be your own. You can remove this as you wish to avoid problems if you are using frameworks. Just be aware that you may have spacing issues to solve in your own CSS.

               

              Normalize.css

              There are a variety of normalize.css files out there to choose from. Nearly all of them are licenced to be free for distribution.

              Here is one: - normalize.css

              It comes from this GitHub repo - https://github.com/necolas/normalize.css (Links to an external site.) 

               

               

              Previous Previous: Week 6 References Next Next: CSS float property

              CSS float property

              The most commonly used and well supported layout pattern is the CSS float property.  It does have a distinct characteristic associated with it that makes it difficult to understand at first.  In the next article CSS Clearfix we will explore this problem specifically with it's fix to keep in mind.  For now, we will have lots of fun putting things beside each other.

              CSS Float's origin comes from a time when browsers first began supporting images in the content. Let's look at this newspaper article (Links to an external site.) to get a sense of what float was originally designed for. In the first paragraph of the article the text wraps around the image.  The image is floated right to that paragraph.

              Let's take a look at how something like this is done in HTML.

              1. There's a container div that centers both the paragraph and image at 500px wide.
              2. The image (img) is targed by the css and a float: right style is assigned to it.

               

              Float Left, Float Right

              Floating an image left and right of the paragraph of content.

               

              Float Beside Eachother

              In this example, we have three divs with the class "box", we set a width and height on all the elements with "box" of 100px.  Using an alternative class for color we've colored each of these boxes differently. Because all three divs share the "box" class they all float left to eachother.

               

              Clear

              Elements that have elements floated next to them can stop that float from happening.  Take a look at how we can use the css clear property on the second blue box to stop it from being affected by the float on the red box above it.

               

              Float Basic Layout

              As we progress with layout we will learn how to future proof this pattern and learn about alternative CSS3 layout properties.  As a very quick reference we can see how a mobile layout can come together quite quickly for larger displays.

              *Toggle both CSS and HTML Tabs to simulate the larger screen size (larger than 650px)

              Previous Previous: normalize.css Next Next: CSS Clearfix

              CSS Clearfix

              The most common problems associated with float in our layouts is the lost height on the container element that's grouping the floated items.

              Automatic Height

              In this example we've given the container div a red border.  This container has grown to accommodate the size of all the elements with the class box inside.

               

              Lost Height

              When we float the elements with the class box inside the red border collapses and the height no longer calculates the height of the elements inside. The red border no longer surrounds the boxes and if we were ask it it's height it would be 0.

               

              CSS Clearfix

              CSS clearfix (Links to an external site.) has a long history in web development. The important thing to remember is when you want to have elements aligned beside eachother with float. Apply a clearfix class on the containing element to properly format the height.

               

              Without Clearfix

              We can encounter some unexpected layout issues.

               

              With Clearfix

              The height of the container is properly calculated and the paragraph stays below the container as we would expect.

              Previous Previous: CSS float property Next Next: CSS Floats and Columns

              CSS Floats and Columns

              Creating Columns with CSS Floats

              With the CSS Float property we can make block elements sit side by side.

              When a browser is trying to decide what fits on a line it looks at the totals of the margin, border, padding, width, padding, border, and margin for each element. All the totals get added together and it they fit inside the width of the parent container then the browser will let it happen. If they are block elements then they also need to be floated left or right. 

              We can use this to our advantage to create columns.

              If our container has say a 960px width and we want to have two columns inside it then we can split the 960px and give the two partial widths to the inner <section>s. As long as we have no padding or margin or border on the <section>s then it is all width.

              <div class="wrapper">
                <section class="one">
                  <p>&nbsp;</p>
                </section>
                <section class="two">
                  <p>&nbsp;</p>
                </section>
              </div>

               

              With the above HTML we can use the following CSS to create columns out of the two sections.

              .wrapper{ 
                width:960px; 
              } 
              .one{ 
                width: 720px; 
                float:left; 
                padding:0; 
                margin:0; 
              } 
              .two{ 
                width: 240px; 
                float:right; 
                padding:0; 
                margin: 0; 
              }

               

              The only remaining issue is how to handle backgrounds and borders for your columns. Clearfix works if you have a containing block element wrapped around your columns.

              There are a few other solutions that we can look at on the next page.

              Here is a code sample that shows a page with three columns. You will have to create a "css" folder for the css file and an "img" folder for the image in order to see everything properly.

              columns.tar

               

              Previous Previous: CSS Clearfix Next Next: CSS Column Backgrounds

              CSS Column Backgrounds

              Backgrounds & Borders for Columns

              When we are creating columns with CSS floats there is a problem with the columns if they are not the same height.

              We can set a background or a border on the column element (eg: <section> ). However, if the columns are not the same height then the background will look strange. It will either be too long or too short.

              There are three different solutions to this problem.

               

              Solution One

              Adding a background image to the containing element.  

              If you have a containing block element around your columns, regardless of how many there are, then you can give it a background image. That image can be blank white with a single or multiple vertical lines. The vertical lines can be created to match the spaces between the columns. Now we can't be sure of the exact height of the content area and we don't want to have to create an image that is 2000px high just to cover off all possibilities. So, we will create an image that is only a few pixels tall and have it tile down the page. If the content area is only 50px tall then that is how much we see of those lines. If the content area is 2000px tall then the image will tile that many times.

              Sample image for a 960px wide content area with columns of 480px, 240px, 240px. - 

              Alternatively, we could create an image of the same dimensions that have different background colours behind the columns.

              Sample image - 

              The main backgrounds of these two images are white. You can right-click and save either image to view it in another application, like Photoshop.

               

              Solution Two

              Adding a background or border to the longest column but only if you can be guaranteed that that column will always be the longest.

              Doing this is just adding background-color to the column through css.

              .column2{ 
                background-color: purple; 
                float: left; 
              }

               

              This only works if you are guaranteed that the column you are colouring is always the longest. It will fail if you are trying to colour two columns which are different lengths.

              One way around the length issue is to set a min-height on one or two of the columns which is longer that the column will EVER be. We are assuming that one of the clearfix hacks is being applied to the container too.

               

              Solution Three

              Using a border and negative margins to create the background. 

              Let's say that we are building a two column layout which is 960px wide. The main column is 600px wide and the narrow column is 360px wide. The main column will always be longer than the side column.

              <div class="container">
                <section class="main"></section>
                <section class="side"></section>
              </div>

               

              What we are going to do is take advantage of the browser's ability to allow any elements to sit side-by-side as long as the total sum of all the margins, borders, paddings and widths is equal to or less than the container's width. We are assuming that one of the clearfix hacks is being applied to the container too.

              .container{ 
                width: 960px; 
              }
              .main{ 
                width: 600px; 
                float:left; 
                border-right: 360px solid #CCFF99; 
                padding:0; 
                margin: 0; 
              }
              .side{ 
                width: 360px; 
                float: left; 
                padding: 0; 
                margin: 0; 
                margin-left: -360px; 
              }

               

              The border on the right hand side of the main section will fill the remaining space inside the container. It totals 960px.

              The side section is 360px wide plus a negative margin of -360px. Add those two together and the browser sees the .side section as being zero pixels wide. Zero plus 960px is 960px. That means that the two of them will fit together side-by-side inside the 960px of the container.

               

               

               

              Previous Previous: CSS Floats and Columns Next Next: CSS Pseudo Classes

              CSS Pseudo Classes

              CSS Pseudo-classes (Links to an external site.) help bring the feeling of interaction to our buttons and links as well as more specific sets of styles for targeting other groups of elements. As we explore advanced selectors, we will use some of these pseudo-classes to help remove unwanted spacing, add some emphasis to the first of something, or style every second or third element.

              We can give our elements unique styles when the mouse is hovering over the element, and another set of styles when the mouse/touch is pressed down, or when a link has already been visited. 

              1. :link - Default Link Unvisited
              2. :visited - Default Link Visited
              3. :hover - On Mouse Over
              4. :active - On press
              5. :focus - On Tab/Active

              The default styling on the anchor and button element are quite a bit different but let's take a look at how each of these element's represent their pseudo states

              Or fancy fill in buttons.

              Previous Previous: CSS Column Backgrounds Next Next: CSS Pseudo Elements

              CSS Pseudo Elements

              CSS pseudo-elements are very similar to pseudo-classes.

              The pseudo-classes refer to a change in state of an element on the page. Eg: An anchor that is being hovered over. The element already exists as a piece of HTML.

              :link

              :active

              :hover

              :visited

              :target

               

              Pseudo-elements are pieces of content in your web page that either do not exist yet or that are a portion of the content in an element. The pseudo-elements get TWO colons in front of the keyword, as opposed to the one in front of pseudo-classes.

              ::after - creates a new element and inserts it after all other content inside the parent, immediately before the closing tag.

              //before the pseudo element is applied
              <p>The old content.</p>
              p::after{
                content: "THE END";
              }
              //after the pseudo-element is applied
              <p>The old content.THE END</p>

              ::before - works the same as the ::after pseudo-element except that the new content is inserted immediately after the opening tag.

              p::before{
                content: "START";
              }

              ::first-letter - Selects the first letter of the content and applies the style declarations to only that one character.

              h1::first-letter{
                font-size: 300%;
              }

              ::first-line - Selects the first line of content inside the element and applies the style declarations to that content. The amount of content receiving the styling will vary based on the width of the element's content box on the screen.

              p::first-line{
                line-height: 3;
                color: rebeccapurple;
              }

              ::selection - applies styles interactively based on the content being selected by the user.

              textarea::selection{
                background-color: goldenrod;
              }

               

              MDN Pseudo-Element Reference - https://developer.mozilla.org/en/docs/Web/CSS/Pseudo-elements (Links to an external site.)

              CSS-Tricks Intro Video for pseudo-elements - https://css-tricks.com/video-screencasts/94-intro-to-pseudo-elements/ (Links to an external site.) 

               

              Previous Previous: CSS Pseudo Classes Next Next: Advanced CSS Selectors

              Advanced CSS Selectors

              CSS Advanced Selectors (Links to an external site.) offer some more specific ways to target HTML elements with CSS.  Throughout the course we will be using a variety of these selectors primarily for layout.

               

              CSS Attribute Selector

              We've seen attributes on elements before. A class is an attribute, the source of an image is an attribute, and the href of an anchor is another attribute.  We can select any attribute inside the brackets.

               

              CSS Before/After

              We can attach stylistic attributes before and after the text content of an element.  This is commonly used to load icons with navigation elements.

               

              CSS :first-child/:last-child

              The first and last paragraph inside each .content-box will have the top and bottom margin removed. This is done so an even spacing can be provided with padding by the .content-box while the paragraphs inside retain their spacing between each other.

               

              CSS Adjacent Sibling Selector

              If there is a paragraph next to(below) a header 2 element, bold the paragraph.

               

              Debugging with the * Selector

              A common debugging practice is adding a border around ever element on your HTML document.  This helps show where content modules might be breaking your layout.

               

              Previous Previous: CSS Pseudo Elements Next Next: CSS Attribute Selectors

              CSS Attribute Selectors

               Any HTML element can have one or more attributes. These provide a great way to target elements. Let's say you wanted to find all the img tags that have alt attributes or you wanted to find all the Images whose source began with https://. Attribute selectors are how we do this.

              We've seen attributes on elements before. A class is an attribute, the source of an image is an attribute, and the href of an anchor is another attribute.  We can select any attribute inside the brackets.

               

              Either of these articles on CSS-Tricks shows all the different types of attribute selectors and how you can do pattern matching with the values of the attributes.

              https://css-tricks.com/almanac/selectors/a/attribute/ (Links to an external site.)

              https://css-tricks.com/attribute-selectors/ (Links to an external site.) 

              :not( )

              Another related selector is the :not( ) pseudo-class selector. We can use this to determine if things are missing from elements.

              https://css-tricks.com/almanac/selectors/n/not/ (Links to an external site.)

              <ul>
                <li class="abc">Some list item</li>
                <li>Some list item</li>
                <li>Some list item</li>
                <li class="abc">Some list item</li>
              </ul>

              li:not(.abc){
                font-weight:bold; /* this will target the middle two li elements */
              }

              The example above is a simple demonstration. It shows how you can place any CSS selector inside the parentheses following :not and then your styles will be applied to anything that matches what preceded the :not but also does NOT match the selector inside the parentheses.

              You could even put an attribute selector inside the parentheses to find elements that were missing that attribute. For example, images that were missing their alt attribute.

               

              Combining Advanced Selectors 

              When writing CSS Selectors remember that you can often combine different types of selectors to create interesting effects.

              a[href^="mailto"]:hover:after { 
                content: " > " attr(title); 
              }                

               Try the above CSS out to see the result with the HTML below.

              <a href="mailto:griffis@algonquincollege.com" title="Coordinator MAD&D">Steve Griffith</a>

               

              Previous Previous: Advanced CSS Selectors Next Next: Building Navigation Menus

              Building Navigation Menus

              A navigation pattern is a group of links. With a little CSS these groups of links can be very nice (Links to an external site.). Navigation elements primary purpose is to help guide the user to the content their looking for.  The better we describe and organize our navigation, the easier it will be to navigate for the user.

              Semantically HTML5 has a <nav> tag just for this purpose. Visually it's no different than a div, it's more of a behind the scenes grouping elements that we can describe with additional attributes for assisted technologies. In the example below we've added the role="navigation" (Links to an external site.) attribute to the <nav> element.

              The Basics

              It's more common to group our navigation elements in an un-ordered list to provide even more structure, but it's not necessary to.  The difference in structure also gives a difference in default styling. List items are block level elements, and anchors are inline.  Below the Anchors are already aligned beside eachother.  This isn't great on smaller devices and the navigation collapses not quite right. Depending on the size of the monitor you're looking at this article with, Nav Item 4, or Nav Item 5 maybe breaking to the next line.

               

              Max-width Breakpoint

              Up to the point where we have the available space for the navigation, make each navigation item on it's own line using display:block (Links to an external site.).

               

              Grouping with Unordered Lists

              In the example above we have a basic navigation that's accessible on all devices.  Like span tags in the article above (Links to an external site.), anchor tags are also inline elements.  The grouping of unordered lists is a slightly different way of thinking because the default styling on each list item will put them on their own line.  The default styling of list items have bullet points and spacing on the left caused by padding - we will want to remove these.

               

              Mobile First - Min-width breakpoint

              Another advantage to grouping the navigation items in unordered lists is the hierarchy the structure provides when we begin to add drop down sub menus to our navigation items. The benefits to the structure of our CSS is it allows us to maintain a mobile-first approach to our styles.

              Previous Previous: CSS Attribute Selectors Next Next: Building Image Galleries & Cards

              Building Image Galleries & Cards

              Grids of images or other content is a very common design pattern on the web. Whenever you have a series of elements with the same dimensions, that are lined up vertically and horizontally, you get a grid. Your grid could be composed of just images, which could be used to create an image gallery. Alternatively you can have a grid made up of small boxes of content. These boxes of content will each have a similar design and are usually referred to as cards.

              The pattern is the same for Image Galleries and Grids of Cards.

              Start with an unordered list.

              Each list item in your list becomes the container for the image or the card.

              Remove the bullets,

              Give them the same dimensions and spacing.

              Handle any extra spacing on the left or right side of your grid.

              Apply consistent styles to all the elements in your list items.

               

              Image Galleries

              This is a sample image gallery using images from http://fillmurray.com/ (Links to an external site.)

              Most of the CSS is fairly straight forward with the list items being floated to the left. The size of the images and the list items are all set to be the same 200 x 300.

              The <ul> has a fixed width and a border just to illustrate how the spacing is being made around the list items.

              The one thing I want to draw your attention to is how the margins on the list-items are being applied. We don't want to add the same margin on all four sides. If we did that we would double up on the left and right on either side of the middle column. To avoid this problem we are only adding margin on two sides. I chose the top and left side of each list item.

              Since there are three columns I only had to add a margin on the right side of every third <li>.

              .gallery li:nth-child(3n){
                margin-left: 10px;
              }

              Now we have even spacing on the top, left and right. The last issue is at the end of the gallery. Since we want to have some space across the bottom of the final row, I target the very last <li> and add a bottom margin on it.

              .gallery li:last-child{
                margin-bottom: 10px;
              }

               

              Cards

              Cards can be built with any HTML you want. They can have images if you want, many do. Borders or box-shadows or both are added to the containing element. All your content should consistently line up inside the card. All your cards should be the same size to help them form a uniform grid.

              The CSS is VERY similar to the image gallery. We just need to format the content inside each of the list items in the same way.

              Previous Previous Module: Week 6 Next Next: Single Column Layout and Mobile First Approach

              Single Column Layout and Mobile First Approach

              Mobile First

              Mobile First is a term coined by Luke Wroblewski back in 2009 to describe an approach to building websites using media queries. Here is the original article - http://www.lukew.com/ff/entry.asp?933 (Links to an external site.) 

              The term means, when you design your pages be sure to plan for the mobile version first. Make the mobile version the default layout. The media queries will make the changes required for larger layouts. This way, if for some reason the browser cannot use the media queries, like it being an older browser, then the mobile version will still work on every screen. It may not look perfect but it will be fully functional and at least usable.

               

              Single Column Layouts

              Our mobile layouts will be single column layouts. We need to make our navigation a vertical stack of links. The header, nav, and main sections will all be vertically stacked on top of each other. They will all fill 90% - 100% the width of the available space on the screen.

               

              Previous Previous: Week 7 Summary Next Next: Building Page Layouts

              Building Page Layouts

              The structure used to build most web pages is surprisingly similar.

              The initial layout, built using the mobile-first philosophy, tends to be quite simple. It is just a series of block elements stacked on top of each other.

              Once the defaults are created then we add the media queries to define which elements change with changes to our screen. We won't need to repeat anything. Just the things that change.

              Make sure that you give minimum and maximum ranges for each of your media queries. We don't want our smaller overwrites to impact our larger ones.

              Remember: You will build a set of media queries for your layout. Typically about 4 media queries can handle your layout changes. However, you are allowed to have as many media queries as you want to fix issues with font sizing, image sizing, changes in alignment, line-height, and all the other properties. You can even add on media queries for other properties than width - like aspect ratio, screen orientation, or  pixel density.

              CodePen HTML starter used in the video - http://codepen.io/mad-d/pen/xEqkdQ?editors=1100 (Links to an external site.)  

              This video tutorial takes the starter code from the CodePen and modifies it to turn the page into a Mobile First Responsive HTML Layout.

              https://youtu.be/QX-_j8J4D_Y (Links to an external site.)

               

              Key Points

              Here are four breakpoints that you can use in your CSS for your media queries. This is NOT an absolute unchangeable set of widths. Please adjust them to suit your own designs.

              @media only screen and (min-width: 25em) {
    /* small */
}
@media only screen and (min-width: 38em) {
    /* medium */
}
@media only screen and (min-width: 60em) {
    /* large */
}
@media only screen and (min-width: 90em) {
    /* extra large */
}

               This list just provides a good starting point for potential screen sizes and the breakpoints for updating your layout.

              Your defaults should represent the layout at a small screen width. Think about the 400px to 600px range. Make everything 90%-100% the width of your screen. No need for floating or columns.

              Using the box-sizing property will make it much easier to set up your column widths.

              nav{
        width: 20%;
        float: left;
    }
    .col-2{
        width: 40%;
        float: left;
    }

              In this example we wanted a left hand nav column that was 20% of our screen. Then the two main content columns were 40% each. The borders and padding that we added didn't hurt anything because those would both be calculated inside the width.

              For font-sizes we wanted to use a proper typographic hierarchy. That meant using a small list of possible font-sizes.

              5.063rem
3.375rem
2.25rem
1.5rem
1.0rem

              You can use the website Type-scale.com (Links to an external site.) to create your own values.

              By setting a different base size in the html element for each media query we can scale those values up and down equally.

              @media only screen and (min-width: 90em) {
    /* extra large */
    html {
        font-size: 130%;
    }

}

               Each media query break-point can get it's own base size. This prevents too many font-sizes from being on the page at any time, which can break your typographic hierarchy.

              Of course, we can always add more breakpoint media queries to handle unique edge cases when we have the actual text in place and we want to prevent things from jumping to the next line. Extra media queries for your headings are never an issue. There are only a few headings on the page and if we need to adjust a heading's font-size slightly to make the layout work then we can do this.

              @media only screen and (min-width: 70em) and (max-width: 73em) {
    /* special case to handle our large title */
    h1 {
        font-size: 5.1rem;
    }

}

               

               

               

              Previous Previous: Single Column Layout and Mobile First Approach Next Next: @media At-Rule

              @media At-Rule

              CSS @media Attribute

              Back in CSS version 2 there was a new attribute created called @media.

              This let us target specific output modes for our CSS. We could create stylesheets for print only, for tv, for screen readers or for general web browsers.

              <link href="main.css" rel="stylesheet" media="all" />
<link href="print.css" rel="stylesheet" media="print" />

               

              With those two link tags added we would have a stylesheet that applies to the web pages in the browser as well as in all other situations - main.css. We also have a stylesheet that would only apply when the pages are being printed.

              Print stylesheets are used to typically hide things that a user would not want to print. It can get rid of background image, remove advertisements, hide navbars and footers, or get rid of extra colours to save the end user ink.

              The possible values for the old media attribute were - http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS2/media.html (Links to an external site.)

              If you wanted, you could put the CSS for both values inside the same CSS file.

              Inside the main.css file we could keep the same content as before. Then, at the bottom of the file we would add this:

              @media print{ 
                /** all the css for print styles go inside the curly braces **/ 
              }

               

               

              CSS3 use of the @media attribute

              When CSS3 came out it meant that a collection of new values for @media were added. These values were all aimed at deploying websites for different devices and for different sized screens.

              We can still use the old values - all, screen, print, etc. but there are new ones that are more useful to us in creating layouts for different sized screens.

              min-width and max-width are the first two. Here is how we could use them inside a css file.

              @media all and (max-width: 960px) and (min-width: 500px){
  /* This css is only applied if the screen width is between 500px and 960px */
  .wrapper{
    width: 90%;
  }
  .main{
    float:left;
    width: 60%;
  }
}

               

               

              The widths for the wrapper class and main class are only going to be applied IF the width of the screen is between those two values.

              Great resource for media queries samples and explanations - http://learn-the-web.algonquindesign.ca/topics/media-queries/ (Links to an external site.)  

               

               

              Previous Previous: Building Page Layouts Next Next: Meta Tags and Meta Data

              Meta Tags and Meta Data

              HTML Meta Tags

              The <meta> tags have information about the webpage beyond what is displayed.

              The most important one is for setting the character set. The HTML5 version of that is

              <meta charset="utf-8" />

               

              There are a few which are specific to rendering webpages properly in a mobile browser.

              Meta Tags For Mobile

              There are some that can be used to refresh or redirect the current page.

              <meta http-equiv="refresh" content="30" />
              <meta http-equiv="refresh" content="30;url=http://www.google.ca" />

               

              For a full explanation of the meta tags please go to - https://developer.mozilla.org/en/docs/Web/HTML/Element/meta (Links to an external site.) 

               

               

              Meta Tags for Mobile

              There are a few <meta> tags that we need to add to every web page that we want to be able to display in a mobile browser. These tags prepare the web page to be rendered, optimized for a small mobile screen.

              We will definitely cover more about the viewport used by mobile browsers but for now, just remember to use these three meta tags on every webpage.

              <meta name="handheldfriendly" content="true" />
              <meta name="mobileoptimized" content="240" />

              <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width,initial-scale=1,target-densitydpi=device-dpi" />

               

              The first two meta tags were for early versions of Windows and Blackberry.

              The viewport meta tag is now the only one you need to use in your Responsive Websites, Web Apps, and Hybrid mobile apps.

              There is a long list of possible values that we can add as the content for the viewport meta tag. However, we can limit the properties that we put as the content for the viewport meta tag to only the width and initial-scale values and things should work well.

              <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width,initial-scale=1" /> 

               

              MetaData and More Semantics

              We have talked about using proper semantics in our HTML and that is still the single most important thing that you can do for your webpages.

              However, there are some other ways that we can add additional metadata to the content on our page. We can describe the purpose of tags that we add by using Microdata. We can explain our own personal relationship to other people online by classifying the links on our webpages with rel tags. We can use XFN, Twitter cards, or Facebook Open Graph.

              Here is a great resource for the META tags that Google understands - https://support.google.com/webmasters/answer/79812?hl=en (Links to an external site.) - improve your Search Engine Optimization.

               

               (Links to an external site.)

               

              Previous Previous: @media At-Rule Next Next: Media Queries

              Media Queries

              CSS Media Queries have a variety of uses.  They can serve specific styles to printers, specific styles to screens and specific styles to different screen sizes.

              There are four primary media queries we use when developing responsive websites.

              1. min-width
              2. max-width
              3. min-height
              4. max-height

              Two other queries we use for high resolution are:

              1. -webkit-min-device-pixel-ratio: 2
              2. min-resolution: 192dpi

              With these queries we can serve higher resolution images for devices with retina.

              As we start exploring media queries and learn more about web development, we're going to to always aim for a mobile up approach.  We're going to create our websites with mobile styles first and extend our designs as more space allows them to grow.

              Leveraging the cascade of CSS when we style the our web applications with mobile first in mind, this helps send only whats needed to the devices rendering them, and will also make our overall CSS architecture easier to work with.

              What we will notice is that the min-width media query will be our primary query.  We'll start with our styles, and once theres 600px or more in this example below, we'll make some changes to adapt our design.

              Please resize your browser OR toggle the CSS button for the remaining examples below.

              Larger text for larger displays

              Flexible designs at different breakpoints

              We're not limited to text, we can apply any styles at any breakpoint, like this square, where we change its shape, colour, and size.

              Serving Images

              We can also use media queries to serve different background images at different sizes.

              For the users who are using any device less then 650px they will see a tiny mouse thats only 8.42 KB in size. This tiny mouse turns into a gigantic group of elephants for any device that renders larger then 650px.  This image is much larger then the images served to what we are assuming are cell phones.  We cannot serve images by bandwidth yet, our best measurements are combinations of widths that change with the landscape of devices out there.

               As we progress with our layouts we will explore setting widths and floating sidebars against our content.  We will build navigation for smaller devices and expand them out for larger screens.

              Visual reference for media queries and screen sizes:

              https://learn-the-web.algonquindesign.ca/topics/screen-sizes-cheat-sheet/ (Links to an external site.)

               

              Previous Previous: Meta Tags and Meta Data Next Next: Understanding Viewports

              Understanding Viewports

              We have previously added those three <meta> tags to help mobile browsers render our webpages in a better manner.

              The one we need to focus on most is 

              <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width" />

               

              This meta tag was introduced by Apple in the mobile version of Safari for the iPad. Since then it has spread to the iPhone, webkit in general and on. 

              This page has a table that covers which browsers support this tag and which values for the content attribute - http://www.quirksmode.org/mobile/tableViewport.html (Links to an external site.)

              You can see by looking at the chart that there are many properties and support and implementation varies greatly.

               

              What is a Viewport

              There are two basic viewports on mobile devices - Layout viewport and Visual viewport.

              Layout viewport - this is the size of your webpage's content. Let's say that you are designing a webpage and the screen to display it was 8 feet across. You are never going to use 8 feet of space. You will set some kind of constraints on the size. Maybe your wrapper is 1200px. That is your layout viewport. You set this size in your CSS.

              Visual viewport - This is the amount of space that the phone is telling your webpage that is available to render your webpage. In the meta tag:

              <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width" />

              the device-width value is the visual viewport as reported by the device. width is what you want to set the layout viewport to.

              The device will try to scale your webpage so that 100% of its layout viewport matches 100% of the device-width reported by the device as the visual viewport.

              You can set the width as an actual number but then you lose the benefit of rendering the way the device manufacturer thinks is an ideal size.

              Peter-Paul Koch is an extremely well-respected researcher in web development and mobile development. He has written a series of articles about the viewports, device pixel ratios and the frustrating limitations of the device browsers. Read the first two articles. Then read them again. Read them repeatedly until you feel like you could explain these concepts to a six year old.

              A Tale of Two Viewports (part one) - http://www.quirksmode.org/mobile/viewports.html (Links to an external site.)

              A Tale of Two Viewports (part two) - http://www.quirksmode.org/mobile/viewports2.html (Links to an external site.)

              Lack of support for position:fixed on mobile browsers - http://www.quirksmode.org/blog/archives/2010/12/the_fifth_posit.html (Links to an external site.)

               

              Webplatform.org also has a good article on viewports

              http://docs.webplatform.org/wiki/tutorials/mobile_viewport (Links to an external site.)

               

              Media Queries max-width and min-wdith

              When you add a media query with a max-width or a min-width you are setting test values against the width of the HTML element. The viewport meta tag will let you set the layout viewport width to a number or to the device width. That value is then compared to the media query max and min widths. 

               

              Device pixels and CSS pixels

              Now, devices don't always tell the truth about their width, height or orientation.

              When you set a width on an element in your CSS file you are setting the width in CSS pixels. These are not necessarily the same as device pixels. You could have a phone with 960 physical pixels. The phone is telling you that its device-width is 480 device pixels. Your CSS width for your wrapper is 1200px. You have an image in the header that is set to width: 300px.

              The CSS pixels for the image are 300. 

              Our viewport meta tag is taking the 1200 CSS pixels for the layout viewport and scaling them to match 480 device pixels. Each of those pixels is actually two physical pixels. The device has a pixel density ratio of 2:1. 

              Our image is 300 CSS pixels (one quarter of the total layout width). One-quarter of the device-width is 120px. Those 120px are actually covering 240 physical pixels on the device.

              As the user pinches and zooms the number of CSS pixels remains the same but your number of physical or device pixels used to display the content changes.

               

              CSS Viewport Units

              There was a new set of units that was added to CSS in 2013 that take advantage of the viewport measurements.

              http://caniuse.com/#search=viewport (Links to an external site.)

              http://www.quirksmode.org/css/units-values/viewport.html (Links to an external site.)

              vw - viewport width

              vh - viewport height

              vmin - viewport min (use the smaller of the two measurements)

              1.0vw means 1% of the viewport width.

              2.8vh means 2.8% of the viewport height.

              For more information on these units see: 

              http://snook.ca/archives/html_and_css/vm-vh-units (Links to an external site.) - Article by Ottawa's own Jonathan Snook

              http://css-tricks.com/viewport-sized-typography/ (Links to an external site.) - by Chris Coyier

               

              Previous Previous: Media Queries Next Next: More Media Queries

              More Media Queries

              First semester we focus on using media queries based on min-width and max-width. There are actually a number of different properties that we can use with media queries.

              @media (min-aspect-ratio: 16/9){
                /* the ratio of width to height for the screen.
                   there is also a max-aspect-ratio */
              }

              The aspect-ratio is the ratio of the width to the height of the screen. This can be useful for different device screens if you want to create a different layout for a square screen than a rectangular screen.

              There is also a device-aspect-ratio version of this. Ref: http://www.w3.org/TR/css3-mediaqueries/#aspect-ratio (Links to an external site.) 

               

              @media (-webkit-min-device-pixel-ratio: 2), 
                     ( min--moz-device-pixel-ratio: 2), 
                     ( -o-min-device-pixel-ratio: 2/1), 
                     ( min-device-pixel-ratio: 2),
                     ( min-resolution: 192dpi), 
                     ( min-resolution: 2dppx)              {
                     /*  
                     The first four values are for older browser implementation
                     dpi - device pixels per inch
                     dppx - device pixels per pixel (read about layout viewport vs. display viewport)
                     */
              }

              Notice the commas in this media query. When you want the browser to implement the first query that it understands then you separate them with commas. If you want all the conditions to be tested and true then you put " and " between the brackets.

              min-resolution and max-resolution are measuring the device pixels per inch. If you want to load different background images based on the resolution of the device screen then this is the best way to accomplish this.

              Last semester we covered the <picture> element and how to add the <source> elements with inline media queries. That is the way to load different images into the content. If you want alternate background images then the media queries with min-resolution and max-resolution is the way to handle it.

               

              @media (orientation:portrait) {
                /* or orientation:landscape */
              }

              Another great way to change your layout is to look at the device orientation. You can completely change your layout depending on which way the device is oriented.

              There are a few other properties for @media including color, color-index, monochrome, and grid - http://www.w3.org/TR/css3-mediaqueries/ (Links to an external site.) however these do not have as much impact on layout. They are much more specialized.

              Testing

              If you want to find out which media queries are supported in your current browser or device then use this site - http://cssmediaqueries.com/ (Links to an external site.)

              It gives you a visual display of each possible query and what is and is not supported.

              CSS nth-child

              The nth-child CSS selector allows us to target patterns of elements on the page. We could highlight every third menu item or alternate rows of a data table. Here are a few samples of how this would work.

              nth-child(#)

              Select element #.

              nth-child(odd)

              Select every odd number:  (Note there is also an "even" keyword)

              nth-child(#n + #)

              Every # of Elements Starting at #. (Every third element starting at the third element).

              nth-child(n + #)

              From # Down:

               

              Here are lots of different examples of nth-child - https://css-tricks.com/useful-nth-child-recipies/ (Links to an external site.) 

              Previous Previous: Media Query Cheatsheet Next Next: CSS Border Radius

              CSS Border Radius

              The border-radius property lets you round the corners of any box. The rounded corners will impact background colours, background images and, of course, borders.

              Like the other border properties, there are a number of ways that you can write the values for the border radius.

              border-radius: 12px;
              border-radius: 12px 24px 12px 24px;
              border-radius: 50px/5px; 
              border-top-left-radius: 12px;
              border-top-left-radius: 50px/5px;
              border-radius: 10px 3px 5px 2px / 20px 1px 2px 1px;

              Using the property border-radius you can provide 1, 2, 3, or 4 values. They will be applied in the order top-left, top-right, bottom-right, and bottom-left. Clockwise starting with the top left.

              If you provide two numbers separated with a forward slash then the first number will be applied to all the horizontal radii and the second number to all the vertical radii. You can also provide 2, 3, or 4 pairs of numbers separated by a single forward slash and they will be applied to the 4 sides in order. The first four are the horizontal values. The last four, after the slash, are the vertical values.

              Lastly, you can apply a single number or a pair of numbers, separated by the forward slash, to one of the properties that target a specific corner.

              border-top-left-radius
              border-top-right-radius
              border-bottom-right-radius
              border-bottom-left-radius

               

              The Radius

              So, you know now how to write out the values for border-radius but what does this mean?

              The horizontal radius is the distance from the side edge that you measure to place the center of your circle. For a big number the center of your circle will be far away from the side edge. That means a very gentle curve. A small number means a very small circle and a sharp curve. In the image below we have a horizontal value that is half the vertical one.

              The vertical radius is the distance from the top/bottom edge to put the center of the circle that will be used for the curve going from the top/bottom edge to the side edge. In the image below the vertical radius is 20px.

              border-radius: 10px/20px; 

               

              https://css-tricks.com/almanac/properties/b/border-radius/ (Links to an external site.)

               

              Previous Previous: CSS nth-child Next Next: CSS Shadows

              CSS Shadows

              box-shadow

              If you want to add a shadow behind the content, padding, and border-box of an element then box-shadow is how you achieve this. If there is no padding or border on the element then the shadow starts at the edge of the content-box. If you add padding then the shadow appears on the edge of the padding. If there is a border then the shadow is on the edge of that. The margin is always outside the shadow.

              .msgBox{
                box-shadow: 2px 3px 4px black; 
              } 

              The example above would have the shadow extend 2px to the right of the edge, 3px down from the edge and give it a 4px blur radius. The last property is the color.

              The first number is the horizontal offset and the second is the vertical offset. If you want a shadow to the top and left you can use negative numbers. 

              You can add multiple shadows, just separate the lists of properties with commas.

              .msgBox{
                box-shadow: 2px 2px 4px black, -2px -2px 4px white;
              }

               

              text-shadow

              The text-shadow property works the same way as the box shadow, in that there is a list of 4 properties - horizontal offset, vertical offset, blur radius, and color.

              The difference with text-shadow is that it applies a shadow on the shape of every single letter.

              h1{
                text-shadow: 1px 1px 2px black, -1px -1px 2px red;
              }

              Some Text With The Above CSS Applied

              The one note of concern is the possibility to make it hard to read the text if you have too large a shadow or if the colour combination makes it hard to read the text. Notice how blurred the above text appears with the shadow added?

              This CodePen talks about text over background images - http://codepen.io/mad-d/pen/grPGmm (Links to an external site.)

              The same ideas apply when adding shadows.
