              Viewport Units for Fonts & Layout

              Up to this point we have been using REM and PX as our two font-units. The PX value is being set on our HTML element and the REM units for everything else.

              When you start to do more responsive design and more mobile websites there is another unit that we need to consider. The Viewport units allow us to use the size of the viewport and size fonts and layout elements based on a percentage of that.

              10vw - 10 percent of the width of the viewport
              20vh - 20 percent of the height of the viewport
              10vmin - 10 percent of the smallest dimension of the viewport
              30vmax - 30 percent of the largest viewport dimension

               

              Here is a short article that gives more details about the viewport units - http://css-tricks.com/viewport-sized-typography/ (Links to an external site.)

               

              Previous Previous: Week 8 Summary Next Next: Font Classifications

              Font Classifications

              Classifying Fonts

              Fonts can be grouped in lots of different specialty classifications. Typically there are two main groups of fonts - Serif and Sans-Serif. All the others are grouped into very specialized categories and it depends on which graphic designer or font designer what the other categories are.

               

              In CSS there are only a few defaults that we can use for the font-family property: serif, sans-serif, cursive, fantasy, and monospace.

               

              Serif

              The Serif fonts have decorative tips on the ends of the lines that make up the glyphs.

               

              Sans-Serif

              The sans-serif fonts are missing the decorative serifs at the end of the line segments that make up the glyphs. They are also more consistent in the thickness of the line segments. 

              Cursive

               Cursive fonts are ones that look like hand writing. They could appear to be printed or written. They are more decorative and have a more personal feel. While they can be more appealing when used for titles and headings or image captions you should avoid using these for body text. Too much of a cursive font can make it difficult for the user to read.

              Fantasy

              The Fantasy fonts are very specialize and cover off all the fonts that do not fit into the other four classifications for CSS. While they add a very distinctive feel to your page they can also quickly become difficult to read if used for body text.

              Dingbat fonts fall into this category. These can be a great way to create icons without using graphics. You can have a single webfont that contains all the icon glyphs and then you add a single letter for each icon. 

               

              Monospace

              Monospace fonts are typically used to display things like code samples. They are called monospace because each letter takes up exactly the same amount of space on the screen. A lowercase i and an uppercase W both have the same width on the screen. With the first computer displays, all fonts were monospace. Use this for your code samples or if you want a very retro feel to your pages. Like cursive and fantasy fonts these ones can reduce the readability of your pages.

               

              More Typography Concepts

              Here are a few more concepts to keep in mind when working with fonts.

              Typography Concepts.pdf 

               

              Previous Previous: Viewport Units for Fonts & Layout Next Next: Icon Fonts

              Icon Fonts

              Web Icon Fonts

              Icons are traditionally bitmap images that you can add to webpages as background images through your CSS or as HTML img tags. With the advent of CSS Web Fonts we now have the ability to create font sets that include icons.

              Two great things about this:

              1. Fonts are vectors that scale wonderfully through the font-size property.

              2. All your icons can be wrapped inside of a single file, the font file, and downloaded with a single HTTP request.

               

              Icon Font Tools

              There are a number of great tools online that will help you to create your own set of icons as a single font file. Two of the most popular are http://fontello.com/ (Links to an external site.) and http://icomoon.io/app/#/select (Links to an external site.) 

              Both of these will let you pick and choose which icons you want to include in your set and then download the font file.

              With each icon glyph that you download you will be able to set the character number within the character set that you want to use for that glyph. 

               

              Let's say that I downloaded an icon set that included an icon for a quill. To use that image I need to have an HTML tag that will hold the image. I will give two class names to the HTML tag. One that loads the proper font family and size and the second to select the proper glyph.

              <span class="icon quill"></span>

               

              Then in the CSS I will create the content from the font.

              Had I used an iconmoon set then my sample files would include some CSS that import the font with the @font-face command

              @font-face {
                font-family: 'icomoon';
                src:url('fonts/icomoon.eot');
                src:url('fonts/icomoon.eot?#iefix') format('embedded-opentype'),
                url('fonts/icomoon.ttf') format('truetype'),
                url('fonts/icomoon.woff') format('woff'),
                url('fonts/icomoon.svg#icomoon') format('svg');
                font-weight: normal;
                font-style: normal;
              }

               

              Then I would associate the class name from the HTML with a single font from within that set.

              .icon{ 
                font-family: icomoon; 
                font-size: 1.6rem; 
              }
              .quill{ 
                content: '\e603'; 
              }

               

              The value that is inside the quotation marks is the Hexadecimal number for the character position within the character set that was created by my font. Anytime you want to refer to a character in your CSS content you can start the value inside the quotation marks with a \. The four characters after that refer to a position within the page's character set.

              As an example - go to http://unicode.org/charts/ (Links to an external site.) and find the code charts for Cyrillic. Click the Cyrillic heading ( http://unicode.org/charts/PDF/U0400.pdf (Links to an external site.) ). On that PDF you can get the code for any Cyrillic letter. Let's say we want to write out the Russian letter for "shch". On the code chart beneath each letter is a four-digit number. 0429 is the number for Щ. So, in our HTML we could write &#x0429; and it would display that character on our web page or in our CSS content we could write content: '\0429'; to write out that letter.

              If I wanted to write this out in the HTML I could do that instead of the .quill class in the CSS.

              <span class="icon">&#xe603;</span>

               

              The number starts with &# and ends with ;

              We need to put a lowercase x at the start to indicate that the number is being written in HEX. Finally, add the same number as in the CSS. 

              Try out both Fontello and IcoMoon to build your own icon sets.

              IcoMoon is actually referencing a number of other open source free icons sets including one called Meteocon, a set of weather icons. - http://www.alessioatzeni.com/meteocons/ (Links to an external site.)  

               

              Previous Previous: Font Classifications Next Next: Character Sets, Character Encoding, Font Faces, and Font Families

              Character Sets, Character Encoding, Font Faces, and Font Families

              There are some important concepts that every developer should understand for them to be able to properly build applications and web pages that work anywhere in the world. You don't need to know every language but you do need to understand how computers and browsers deal with text written in different languages.

              Character Encoding

              Decades ago when programming languages like C were being invented code was being written in isolated places and distributed to very few computers. Most people didn't have to worry about whether or not the program being written to work on a computer in Texas could understand how to display Cyrillic. Now we do have to handle that.

              The first concept you need to understand is that computers only deal with ones and zeros. Everything they do is with numbers. They don't actually store letters in memory. It's all ones and zeros.

              Those ones and zeros are called bits and they get grouped together in bunches of eight. Each eight is called a byte. One byte could store every combination of ones and zeros and those values represented the numbers 0 - 255. That meant that each byte could represent one of up to 255 different characters. An early standard for doing this was the ASCII standard. Characters 0 to 128 were largely agreed upon. All the upper and lowercase English characters were here. What happened in the last 127 positions was a little more unpredictable.

              With the appearance of the world wide web there was an urgent need to support characters from all the languages around the world. The solution to this problem became Unicode. A single character encoding system that would work for all languages, even Klingon.

              So, there is a single character encoding to represent all letters in every language, plus a bunch of common symbols (Math, Music, etc). Everyone just needed to agree on what constituted a letter. Different languages deal with accents, shapes, and word endings differently. In English, if you think of a uppercase "A" and a lowercase "a", those are two distinct characters. It doesn't matter which font family you are using, we are only talking about the generic shape used to represent either. Each character has its own number in Unicode. These numbers are known as code points. They are generally written as the letter U followed by a plus sign and then a four digit hexadecimal number.

              Each character in Unicode is using two bytes.

              Hello
              would be represented in Unicode as:
              U+0048 U+0065 U+006C U+006C U+006F

               

              UTF-8

              You will notice that the first two digits of all those letters is zero zero. English characters never need the other byte. That is a lot of wasted memory holding spaces for characters that are beyond position 255. This is where the idea for UTF-8 came from. If your character was within the first 127 code points then only one byte (8 bits) would be used to represent your character in memory. If you needed something from a higher code point then you could use two, three, four, five, or six bytes for each character.

              The advantage of this system is, in addition to saving memory, that it is backward compatible with ASCI and other older character standards.

              When what you are trying to display includes a code point that has no match then what you will get is one of those black diamonds with a question mark or an empty square.

               

              ISO 8859-1

              Unicode and UTF-8 are not the only encoding schemes out there. There are lots of other standards too. This is why you can sometimes end up with a page that looks like gibberish. If a web page was encoded using the ISO 8859-1 (Latin) encoding (code points) and then the browser tries to use UTF-8 to render it, you are likely going to have numbers that do not match. This will lead to text on the page that does not make sense.

               

              Applying the Lesson to Web Pages

              When building a web page we need to specify which encoding we want to use. The defacto standard that we use for encoding is UTF-8. So, inside the head of our web page we need to add this meta tag.

              <meta charset="UTF-8">

               

              Character Sets

              While the terms Character Set and Character Encoding are often used interchangeably there is actually a distinction between them. A character set is a group of characters. Unicode is a character set.

              A character encoding is a specific character set with a specific set of code points used with each character. UTF-8, UTF-16, ISO 8859-1 are all character encodings. 

               

              HTML Character Entities

              Sometimes you will be creating a web page and need to represent a special character that might not be on your keyboard. To store these in your HTML we can use character entities. These are special sequences of characters that together represent the single special character.

              For example, let's say we wanted to add a copyright symbol to our page.

              &copy;

              This is the HTML Character Entity for the copyright symbol. All the HTML Character Entities start with an ampersand and end with a semi-colon. The letters in between are a short representation of which character you want. 

              Here is a list of the HTML character entities - http://dev.w3.org/html5/html-author/charref (Links to an external site.) 

              There is actually a character entity for every character in your character encoding. The HTML character entities are the nickname versions. If you need a more common character though you can use the other format.

              &#38;    &amp;

              Both of these represent an Ampersand. 38 is the code point for an ampersand in utf-8.

              When it comes to working with text there are actually a lot of characters that have specific meanings. There is actually a difference between a hyphen, an m-dash, and an n-dash. When you are writing someone's height in feet and inches you shouldn't use an apostrophe and a double quote. There are characters called prime and double-prime which should be used. 

              Here is a great reference to the character entities for these and how to properly use them - http://www.typewolf.com/cheatsheet (Links to an external site.) 

               

              Fonts, Font Families, Type Faces, and Glyphs

              Once you have all of your text delivered to the browser, wrapped up inside an HTML file that came from a web server, the browser will look for the character encoding meta tag and then have a list of code points. Each character on the page is simply a code point.

              Now those code points need to be turned into Glyphs. A glyph is a graphical representation of a single character.

              A font is a collection of glyphs. Each glyph represents a single code point.

              A typeface is a traditional typography term meaning a specific font family at a specific size, weight and style. When printing was done with actual metal blocks for each letter you had the family - Times New Roman, for example, and then you would use the appropriate set of blocks for the size, weight, and style (eg: italic or regular) when type setting your page. This doesn't mean much on the web except that we should think of a font family as a collection of fonts. The font is your typeface - eg: Arial Bold.

              We should try to use fonts that include the normal, bold, and italic versions. We could have three or four different fonts in our font-family.

              If you only include the normal version font then the browser will try to simulate the bold and italic versions of the font. However, these will NEVER look nearly as good as the properly designed versions.

              Sizes don't matter because the font glyphs are vectors that can scale to any size.

              Inside the font file will be a mapping to tie each glyph to a specific letter / character.  How does the shape get connected to the appropriate letter? Remember that Unicode stuff above? That's it. There is a Unicode code-point assigned to each glyph in the font.

              If you want to display a unicode character and there is no glyph inside your current font file for that particular unicode code point then you get the diamond with the question mark or the empty square.

               

              Summary

              So, if you want to display things in multiple languages then you should use UTF-8 as the encoding on your web page AND choose fonts that have lots of unicode character representative glyphs.

               

              Further Reading

              If you want to learn a little more about what makes a good typeface, try this article - http://www.frerejones.com/blog/typeface-mechanics-001/ (Links to an external site.)

              Here is some great information about special characters in HTML and how to work with them in different fonts - http://www.typewolf.com/cheatsheet (Links to an external site.)  

               

               

              Previous Previous: Icon Fonts Next Next: Smart Quotes in Many Languages

              Smart Quotes in Many Languages

              Multilingual websites and web pages are becoming more and more common. 

              Proper typography requires an understanding of the use of Smart Quotes. Dumb quotes are the one or two vertical lines that you see on the keyboard - ' or "

              When you are typing, as a developer, these are the quotes that end up in your web pages. However, they are not the correct quotation marks, and when you starting adding content in multiple languages the actual marks used change.

              Here is a reference page about which are the primary and secondary quotation marks used in different countries

              https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quotation_mark#Summary_table (Links to an external site.)

              HTML quote and blockquote Elements

              In HTML we can wrap the inline <q> element around some text and the browser will automatically add quotation marks.

              A larger chunk of text (the size of a paragraph) will use a blockquote element, which is a block level element. It does NOT get quotation marks added.

              We can also add a lang attribute inside any HTML element to tell the browser what language the content of that element is written in.

              <body lang="en">

              This tells the browser that all the content in the <body> is written in English.

              Here is a site that you can use to look up the language codes - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_ISO_639-1_codes (Links to an external site.) 

               

              CSS Quotes property

              In your CSS, we can control which quotation marks get used by either element by using the CSS quotes property.

              Here we have an example of a page that is loading different types around the different <q> elements based on the language attribute of their parent elements. 

               

              Some of the characters used we will have keyboard shortcuts for. Others... Not so much.

              So, when you don't have a way of typing the character you want then you need to resort to the Unicode value for that character. In CSS we would write a unicode value starting with a backslash character and then wrap the whole value in double or single quotes.

              quotes: "\201D" "\201E";

              This is telling the browser to use the unicode character number 201D as the opening quote and 201E as the closing quote.

              The letters can be upper or lower case.

               

              Here are a couple sites that you can use to look up the unicode values.

              http://unicodelookup.com/#quotation (Links to an external site.)

              http://www.unicode.org/charts/ (Links to an external site.) 

               

              Previous Previous: Character Sets, Character Encoding, Font Faces, and Font Families Next Next: C.R.A.P.

              C.R.A.P.

              C.R.A.P. stands for Contrast  Repetition  Alignment  Proximity

              • Contrast
                Elements that aren’t the same should be very different so they stand out, making them “slightly different” confuses the user into seeing a relation that doesn’t exist. Strong contrast between page elements allows the user’s eye to flow from one to another down the page instead of creating a sea of similarity that’s boring and not communicative.
                 
              • Repetition
                Repeat styles down the page for a cohesive feel, if you style related elements the same way in one area, continue that trend for other areas for consistency.
                 
              • Alignment
                Everything on the page needs to be visually connected to something else, nothing should be out of place or distinct from all other design elements.
                 
              • Proximity
                Proximity creates related meaning: elements that are related should be grouped together, whereas separate design elements should have enough space in between to communicate they are different.
                 

               

              The C.R.A.P. principles are good ways to double-check your design work.

               

              Useful Links

              https://www.glidedesign.com/website-design-crap/ (Links to an external site.)

              Building Web Pages for Fast Loading

               

              The tips based upon common knowledge and experimentation.

              Reduce page weight

              Page weight is by far the most important factor in page-load performance.

              Reducing page weight through the elimination of unnecessary whitespace and comments, commonly known as minimization, and by moving inline script and CSS into external files, can improve download performance with minimal need for other changes in the page structure.

              Tools such as HTML Tidy can automatically strip leading whitespace and extra blank lines from valid HTML source. Other tools can "compress" JavaScript by reformatting the source or by obfuscating the source and replacing long identifiers with shorter versions.

              Minimize the number of files

              Reducing the number of files referenced in a web page lowers the number of HTTP (Links to an external site.) connections required to download a page.

              Depending on a browser's cache settings, it may send an If-Modified-Since request to the web server for each CSS, JavaScript or image file, asking whether the file has been modified since the last time it was downloaded.

              By reducing the number of files that are referenced within a web page, you reduce the time required for these requests to be sent, and for their responses to be received.

              If you use background images a lot in your CSS, you can reduce the amount of HTTP lookups needed by combining the images into one, known as an image sprite. Then you just apply the same image each time you need it for a background, and adjust the x/y coordinates appropriately. This technique works best with elements that will have limited dimensions, and will not work for every use of a background image. However, the fewer HTTP requests and single image caching can help reduce pageload time.

              Too much time spent querying the last modified time of referenced files can delay the initial display of a web page, since the browser must check the modification time for each CSS or JavaScript file, before rendering the page.

              Reduce domain lookups

              Since each separate domain costs time in a DNS lookup, the page load time will grow along with the number of separate domains appearing in CSS link(s) and JavaScript and image src(es).

              This may not always be practical; however, you should always take care to use only the minimum necessary number of different domains in your pages.

              Cache reused content

              Make sure that any content that can be cached, is cached, and with appropriate expiration times.

              In particular, pay attention to the Last-Modified header. It allows for efficient page caching; by means of this header, information is conveyed to the user agent about the file it wants to load, such as when it was last modified. Most web servers automatically append the Last-Modified header to static pages (e.g. .html, .css), based on the last-modified date stored in the file system. With dynamic pages (e.g. .php, .aspx), this, of course, can't be done, and the header is not sent.

              So, in particular for pages which are generated dynamically, a little research on this subject is beneficial. It can be somewhat involved, but it will save a lot in page requests on pages which would normally not be cacheable.

              More information:

              1. HTTP Conditional Get for RSS Hackers
              2. HTTP 304: Not Modified
              3. HTTP ETag on Wikipedia
              4. Caching in HTTP

              Optimally order the components of the page

              Download page content first, along with any CSS or JavaScript that may be required for its initial display, so that the user gets the quickest apparent response during the page loading. This content is typically text, and can therefore benefit from text compression in transit, thus providing an even quicker response to the user.

              Any dynamic features that require the page to complete loading before being used, should be initially disabled, and then only enabled after the page has loaded. This will cause the JavaScript to be loaded after the page contents, which will improve the overall appearance of the page load.

              Reduce the number of inline scripts

              Inline scripts can be expensive for page loading, since the parser must assume that an inline script could modify the page structure while parsing is in progress. Reducing the use of inline scripts in general, and reducing the use of document.write() to output content in particular, can improve overall page loading. Use modern AJAX (Links to an external site.) methods to manipulate page content for modern browsers, rather than the older approaches based ondocument.write().

              Use modern CSS and valid markup

              Use of modern CSS reduces the amount of markup, can reduce the need for (spacer) images, in terms of layout, and can very often replace images of stylized text -- that "cost" much more than the equivalent text-and-CSS.

              Using valid markup has other advantages. First, browsers will have no need to perform error-correction when parsing the HTML (this is aside from the philosophical issue of whether to allow format variation in user input, and then programmatically "correct" or normalize it; or whether, instead, to enforce a strict, no-tolerance input format).

              Moreover, valid markup allows for the free use of other tools which can pre-process your web pages. For example, HTML Tidy can remove whitespace and optional ending tags; however, it will refuse to run on a page with serious markup errors.

              Chunk your content

              Tables for layouts are a legacy method that should not be used any more. Layouts utilizing <div> (Links to an external site.) blocks, and in the near future, CSS3 Multi-column Layout (Links to an external site.) or CSS3 Flexible Box Layout (Links to an external site.), should be used instead.

              Tables are still considered valid markup, but should be used for displaying tabular data. To help the browser render your page quicker, you should avoid nesting your tables.

              Rather than deeply nesting tables as in:

              <table>
  <table>
    <table>
          ...
    </table>
  </table>
</table>

              use non-nested tables or divs as in

              <table>...</table>
<table>...</table>
<table>...</table>

              See also: CSS3 Multi-column Layout Spec and CSS3 Flexible Box Layout

              Minify and compress SVG assets

              SVG produced by most drawing applications often contains unnecessary metadata which can be removed. Configure your servers apply gzip compression for SVG assets.

              Specify sizes for images and tables

              If the browser can immediately determine the height and/or width of your images and tables, it will be able to display a web page without having to reflow the content. This not only speeds the display of the page but prevents annoying changes in a page's layout when the page completes loading. For this reason, height and width should be specified for images, whenever possible.

              Tables should use the CSS selector:property combination:

              table-layout: fixed;

              and should specify widths of columns using the COL and COLGROUP HTML tags.

              Choose your user-agent requirements wisely

              To achieve the greatest improvements in page design, make sure that reasonable user-agent requirements are specified for projects. Do not require your content to appear pixel-perfect in all browsers, especially not in down-version browsers.

              Ideally, your basic minimum requirements should be based on the consideration of modern browsers that support the relevant standards. This can include recent versions of Firefox, Internet Explorer, Google Chrome, Opera, and Safari.

              Note, however, that many of the tips listed in this article are common-sense techniques which apply to any user agent, and can be applied to any web page, regardless of browser-support requirements.

               

              Useful Links:

              https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Guide/HTML/Tips_for_authoring_fast-loading_HTML_pages (Links to an external site.) (Links to an external site.)

              http://www.smashingmagazine.com/2013/04/03/build-fast-loading-mobile-website/ (Links to an external site.)

              Design versus Style

              Design and Style are two very different things.

              Style

              Style is the colour or font that you pick because you see other people using it.

              Style is the current flavour of the month.

              Style is choice to use clip art for all your graphics or to use high quality photography for all your imagery.

              Style is deciding that you want to use shadows on your site.

              Style is what you choose to wear on any given day.

               

               

              Design

              Design is making sure that all your font choices belong together.

              Design is making sure that your fonts and colours send the right message to match your content.

              Design is using a method, not random preferential choice, to pick the combinations of colours you need.

              Design is creating a Typographic Hierarchy that allows people to quickly identify the most important elements on your pages.

              Design is deliberately measuring where you are going to place your elements, not letting browser defaults determine the locations.

               

              Good Design

              Here are ten guidelines that you can apply to your own designs to be more effective in your design.

               

              Good Design Is Innovative : The possibilities for innovation are not, by any means, exhausted. Technological development is always offering new opportunities for innovative design. But innovative design always develops in tandem with innovative technology, and can never be an end in itself.

              Good Design Makes a Product Useful : A product is bought to be used. It has to satisfy certain criteria, not only functional but also psychological and aesthetic. Good design emphasizes the usefulness of a product while disregarding anything that could possibly detract from it.

              Good Design Is Aesthetic : The aesthetic quality of a product is integral to its usefulness because products are used every day and have an effect on people and their well-being. Only well-executed objects can be beautiful.

              Good Design Makes A Product Understandable : It clarifies the product’s structure. Better still, it can make the product clearly express its function by making use of the user’s intuition. At best, it is self-explanatory.

              Good Design Is Unobtrusive : Products fulfilling a purpose are like tools. They are neither decorative objects nor works of art. Their design should therefore be both neutral and restrained, to leave room for the user’s self-expression.

              Good Design Is Honest : It does not make a product more innovative, powerful or valuable than it really is. It does not attempt to manipulate the consumer with promises that cannot be kept

              Good Design Is Long-lasting : It avoids being fashionable and therefore never appears antiquated. Unlike fashionable design, it lasts many years – even in today’s throwaway society.

              Good Design Is Thorough Down to the Last Detail : Nothing must be arbitrary or left to chance. Care and accuracy in the design process show respect towards the consumer.

              Good Design Is Environmentally Friendly : Design makes an important contribution to the preservation of the environment. It conserves resources and minimizes physical and visual pollution throughout the lifecycle of the product.

              Good Design Is as Little Design as Possible : Less, but better – because it concentrates on the essential aspects, and the products are not burdened with non-essentials. Back to purity, back to simplicity.

              UPDATE:

              In the HTML starter file there are two sections that have the same classes - "col first". The second section can have a different class (like "second").

              <main class="main">
              <section class="col first">
              </section>
              <section class="col second">
              </section>

              Like the above. This is NOT mandatory, just something you can change if you want.

              ***********************************************************

              This project is to build a responsive webpage.

              Use the attached HTML and CSS to start your project.

              Create your own body content for the paragraphs with some type of Lorem Ipsum text. Here are a few sites you can use to generate the text:

              http://www.lipsum.com/ (Links to an external site.)

              1. The background for the Header (make sure you cover the whole area.

              2. The image inside the first column <img> element.

              The images should be of the same theme. Eg: Robots, Mountains, Mars, Kittens, Mobile Devices, etc. Pick one theme for both images. Here are some image generators that you can use:

              https://placehold.it/ (Links to an external site.)
              https://placeimg.com/ (Links to an external site.)

              Edit your heading text to match the theme you picked for your image. There are THREE headings to edit.

               

              Your website needs four versions of the layout built with media queries based on different screen widths.

              Here is a diagram to show the four different versions of the layout. The media queries can be done with pixels or ems. Example:

              @media screen and (min-width: 1200px){ }

              @media screen and (min-width: 80em){ }  

              When you are building the different layouts we want to use the following widths 

              extra large

              header - 100%
              nav - 30%
              links - 100% of nav
              main - 70%
              columns - 50% of main
              column image - 55% of column width
              footer - 100%

              large

              header - 100%
              nav - 90%
              links - 20% of nav
              main - 90%
              columns - 50% of main
              column image - 50% of column
              footer - 100%

              medium

              wrapper - 100%
              header - 100%
              nav - 90%
              links - 20% of nav
              main - 90%
              columns - 50% of main
              column image - 60% of column
              footer - 90%

              small

              wrapper - 95%
              header - 100% of wrapper
              nav - 100% of wrapper
              links - 100% of nav
              main - 100% of wrapper
              columns - 100% of main
              column image - 100% of column
              footer - 100% of wrapper

              Typography 

              You need to have one Serif font for your headings and one Sans-Serif font for your body text and navigation links. Get the fonts from Google fonts - https://fonts.google.com/ (Links to an external site.) - CHANGE THE DEFAULT FONTS IN THE CSS STARTER FILE

              REMEMBER to resize your text in your headings, links, and body content to appropriately fit the space provided by your layout.

              https://abcd0001.github.io/midterm-9013/ (Links to an external site.)

              HTML5 Audio

              HTML5 Audio

              Only a few years ago, if you wanted to play audio on a webpage, you had to create a Flash music player to stream the sound. While this was great for those of us with Flash and Actionscript skills, the fun times were not to last. With the arrival of THOUSANDS of different phones on the market, Adobe could no longer keep up with the pace of change and the need for a Flash Player to run inside each browser on each phone. Adobe saw the writing on the wall and stopped working on mobile Flash Players.

              Within a few months, as mobile browsing grew exponentially, Flash became something you would no longer use to develop a website. Flash has become something that you use to prototype games, build desktop apps, and build cross-platform mobile applications. 

              The fading away of Flash as an audio delivery platform meant that all the browsers had to quickly start supporting the HTML5 audio tag. Thus began the internet audio and video codec wars. The was much debate and the people grew tired.

              Currently here are the Audio Codecs that are used by the audio players across different browsers

              PCM audio

              MP3

              AAC

              Ogg Vorbis

              Ogg Opus

              WebM

              Wav

              If you want to see the support list for which browsers support each - http://html5doctor.com/html5-audio-the-state-of-play/#support (Links to an external site.)

              Want to see what your browser supports? - http://html5test.com/ (Links to an external site.)

               

              There is no one format supported everywhere. So, if you want your audio to be heard in all browsers on all devices (that support HTML5 Audio) then you need to convert your files into multiple formats. The same rule applies to HTML5 video.

               

              HTML <audio> tag

              Once you have your audio files converted into the formats you need then you will need to add the HTML to the page to play them.

              <audio src="audio.ogg" controls autoplay loop>
<p>Your browser does not support the audio element </p>
</audio>

               

              This would try to load the ogg audio file in the browser. It would should whichever controls it could display. It would start playing automatically and it would loop each time it reached the end.

              If the browser did not support the HTML audio element then the paragraph of text would appear. If your browser did support the audio tag but NOT the .ogg format then the user sees a blank box and doesn't know what is going on.

              This is why we can use <source> tags inside the <audio> tag instead of a src attribute.

              <audio controls autoplay>
                <source src="audio.mp3" type="audio/mpeg" />
                <source src="audio.ogg" type="audio/ogg" />
              </audio>

               

              We can even use Javascript to create our own controls and control the playback of the audio - http://html5doctor.com/html5-audio-the-state-of-play/#properties (Links to an external site.)

               

              Previous Previous: Week 9 Summary Next Next: Further Research into HTML5 Audio

              Previous Previous: HTML5 Audio Next Next: HTML5 Video

              HTML5 Video

              HTML5 Video

              The same thing happened with Video as happened with Audio. Flash was the primary choice for delivering video on the web. With the loss of the Flash Player as an option for delivering video on mobile devices came the need for the HMTL5 video tag.

              There is a limited number of video formats supported across different browsers.

              However, with <video> on the web we need to understand that there are three things that need to be supported by each browser.

              1. The container - this is the file that holds the video file and the audio file.

              2. The video codec - the compression / decompression algorithm used to save and read the video file.

              3. The audio codec - the compression / decompression algorithm used to save and read the audio file.

               

              Some containers can mix and match their audio and video files. Some can only hold a specific type of file.

              Here is a list of the main containers

              Mpeg 4 - .mp4 file extension. Evolution of the .mov format. Uses H.264 video codec (sometimes called mpeg-4 part 10).

              Ogg - .ogg or .ogv file extensions. Typically has Ogg Theora video codec and Ogg Vorbis audio codec. Open Source.

              Flash Video - .flv or .f4v file extensions.

              WebM - .webm file extension. Open Source format created by Google. (Variation of the Matroska open source container). Uses the VP8 video codec. VP8 is considered to be on par with H.264.

              Audio Video Interleave - .avi file extension. Older Microsoft format.

              ASF - .asf file extension. Microsoft format.

              MOV - .mov file extension. Apple Quicktime format. 

               

              The three main audio codecs in use are:

              Mpeg-1 - Files with .mp3 file extension. Technically a patented technology and not open source. However, very widely supported.

              AAC - Advanced Audio Codec .aac file extension. Flash can play .mp3 and .aac files.

              Vorbis - the Audio portion of the OGG format. Ogg vorbis audio files can have a .ogg or .oga file extension.

               

              Looking to find support for the various video formats?

              http://caniuse.com/#search=video (Links to an external site.) - This shows support for the HTML5 <video> tag as well as the browser support for the different formats - H.264+MP4, WebM+VP8, and Ogg Theora+Vorbis.

              Here is a compatibility table for all the formats and all the browsers - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Supported_media_formats#Browser_compatibility (Links to an external site.)  

              If you want to get more technical about these then here is a good place to start - http://diveintohtml5.info/video.html (Links to an external site.)

               

              HTML <video>

              Now that we have discussed the various formats we can look at the HTML to use in delivering video.

              <video src="video.mp4" controls poster="movie.png">
                <p>Your browser sucks</p>
              </video>

               

              This would build the video player with controls and display an image called movie.png until the user hits play.

              If the user's browser supports <video> but not the .mp4 format then they get a grey box and don't know what is going on. That is why we have to add the <source> tags the same way we did for the <audio> tag.

              <video controls poster="movie.png" >
                <source src="movie.mp4" type="video/mp4" />
                <source src="movie.ogg" type="video/ogg" />
                <source src="movie.webm" type="video/webm" />
              </video>

               

              If a browser supports multiple available formats, it will play the first one it understands.

               

              Flash Fallback

              Older browsers that don't support HTML5 <audio> or <video> should include a fallback option of a Flash audio / video player. This is not an issue for mobile browsers as they do not support Flash. You need to be aware of this solution if you ever have to support sites that need to run on IE 8 or earlier.

              That code would be placed inside the <video> or <audio> tag after all the <source> tags instead of the <p> with the sorry message.

              <object classid="clsid:d27cdb6e-ae6d-11cf-96b8-444553540000" width="425" height="344" codebase="http://download.macromedia.com/pub/shockwave/cabs/flash/swflash.cab#version=6,0,40,0">
                <param name="allowFullScreen" value="true"/>
                <param name="allowscriptaccess" value="always"/>
                <param name="src" value="movie.flv"/>
                <param name="allowfullscreen" value="true"/>
                <embed type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="425" height="344" src="movie.flv" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true">
                </embed>
              </object>

               

              The built-in video formats for flash are .flv and .f4v.

              For more information and for Javascript examples see - 

              https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Guide/HTML/Using_HTML5_audio_and_video (Links to an external site.)

               

              Here is a sample page showing a video player that is using a data URI for the poster image. - http://codepen.io/mad-d/pen/vEyvyw?editors=100 (Links to an external site.) 

              A dataURI is a base 64 string version of a binary image.

               

               

              Previous Previous: Further Research into HTML5 Audio Next Next: HTML Video Closed Captions

              HTML Video Closed Captions

              Video Closed Captioning

               If you need to add closed captioning to your video, you can do that now! W3C nows supports the WebVTT format for closed captioning inside your HTML5 Video tag. Just add a <track> element after your <source> elements inside your <video>. Here is the official spec for the WebVTT format - http://dev.w3.org/html5/webvtt/ (Links to an external site.)

              There are two formats currently in use across browsers - .vtt and .ttml. TTML is an XML-based format that has just recently begun to gain support in the browsers. VTT is an older format with much better support. http://caniuse.com/#search=video (Links to an external site.) - only shows the support for VTT.

              The TTML format was added because it provides more functionality. You can actually add styling information in the XML to style your captions. - http://blogs.msdn.com/b/mediastuff/archive/2014/03/05/closed-captioning-it-s-not-just-for-accessibility-texttrack-in-html5-video.aspx (Links to an external site.) 

              Here is a sample VTT file.

              WEBVTT  
              1 
              00:00:13.000 --> 00:00:16.100 
              <strong>ARNE DUNCAN:</strong> I'll start and then turn it over to you.  

              2 
              00:00:16.100 --> 00:00:20.100 
              It's so critically important that parents be actively engaged

               

               

              Here is a sample TTML file

              <tt xmlns="http://www.w3.org/ns/ttml" xml:lang="en">   
                <body>
                  <div>
                    <p begin="00:00:13.00" end="00:00:16.10">        ARNE DUNCAN: I'll start and then turn it over to you.      </p>
                    <p begin="00:00:16.10" end="00:00:20.10">        It's so critically important that parents be actively engaged      </p>
                  </div>
                 </body> 
              </tt>

               

              Here is a code sample that shows an HTML Video tag along with the track tags for English and French versions of the closed captions.

              <video controls poster="buymebeer.png">
                <source src="buymebeer.mp4" type="video/mp4" />
                <source src="buymebeer.webm" type="video/webm" />
                <source src="buymebeer.ogg" type="video/ogg" />
                <track src="beer.vtt" srclang="en-ca" kind="captions" label="Buy Me Beer" default />
                <track src="beer-fr.vtt" srclang="fr-ca" kind="captions" label="Achetez-moi une biere" />
                <object ..... >
                  <param name="src" value="beer.f4v" />
                </object>
                <p>Your Browser Can't Even... </p>
              </video>

               

               

              Previous Previous: HTML5 Video Next Next: Converting Between Formats

              Converting Between Formats

              In order to support all the browsers, we need to be able to make our audio and video files available in multiple formats, each through its own <source> element.

              There are many tools that are available online. This page has a good list of tools - http://thenewcode.com/458/Format-Conversion-Tools-For-HTML5-Audio-and-Video (Links to an external site.) 

              From that list:

              http://www.mirovideoconverter.com/ (Links to an external site.) - Miro ( will convert to many formats )

              https://handbrake.fr/ (Links to an external site.) - Handbrake (will convert to mp4 or mkv with a variety of codes)

              http://easyhtml5video.com/ (Links to an external site.) - Easy HTML5 Video (will convert to many formats) is free for non-commercial use. The non-paid version will display a watermark.

              https://www.ffmpeg.org/ (Links to an external site.) - Extremely powerful command line audio and video converter and much more:

              Windows version:
              https://ffmpeg.zeranoe.com/builds/ (Links to an external site.)

              Mac version:
              http://www.ffmpegmac.net/ (Links to an external site.)

              Sample conversion script to convert a video from mp4 to webm:

              ffmpeg -i myvideo.mp4 -acodec libvorbis -aq 5 -ac 2 -qmax 25 -cpu-used 7 -threads 8 myvideo.webm

              Sample conversion script to convert an audio file from mp3 to ogg:

              ffmpeg -i input.mp3 -c:a libvorbis -q:a 4 -threads 8 output.ogg

                

              All are free and are available on Mac and Windows.

              Beware that the download site for Miro has been known to have adware and spyware.

               

              Different projects will have different requirements for video conversion. However, if you are targetting modern browsers from the last few years then really you just need TWO FORMATS - webm and mp4. 

              For a little broader support, without Flash, we should include OGG video too. There are fringe devices that run Palm WebOS and Firefox OS which only support ogg video. Older versions of Opera and Firefox browsers started supporting HTML5 video with the ogg format only. (reference: http://camendesign.com/code/video_for_everybody/test.html (Links to an external site.) )

               

              This WikiPedia page has a great list of all the video file formats plus their video and audio codecs based on the container.

              https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Video_file_format (Links to an external site.) 

              Previous Previous: HTML Video Closed Captions Next Next: HTML Video Backgrounds

              HTML Video Backgrounds

              A design trend, that has been happening quite a bit in recent years, is the use of HTML5 video as a background element.

              To create a background video we need a <div> element which contains a <video> element. It will be positioned as fixed and will fill the screen, or desired portion. 

              <div class="fullscreen-bg">
                <video autoplay loop muted class="video-bg" poster="img/poster.jpg">
                  <source src="video/big_buck_bunny_1080p_stereo_hd.webm" type="video/webm">
                  <source src="video/big_buck_bunny_1080p_h264.mp4" type="video/mp4">
                  <source src="video/big_buck_bunny_1080p_stereo.ogg" type="video/ogg">
                  <!-- only the first two are really needed -->
                 </video>
               </div>

              There is CSS to make sure the div fills the screen.

              .fullscreen-bg{
    width:100%;
    height:100%;
    position:fixed;
    top:0;
    left:0;
    right:0;
    bottom:0;
    padding:0;
    margin:0;
    overflow: hidden;
    z-index: -1;
}

              And CSS to make sure the video fills the width of the screen too.

              .video-bg{
                 width:100%;
                 height:auto;
              }

              Sometimes it is better to have the video fill the screen in both directions or to be sized differently based on the aspect ratio of the screen. We can add media queries to handle this different sizing. The above value becomes the default.

              @media (min-aspect-ratio: 16/9) {
                .video-bg {
                   height: 300%;
                   width: auto;
                }
              }

              @media (max-aspect-ratio: 16/9) {
                .video-bg {
                   width: 300%;
                   height: auto;
                }
              }

              Next comes another div with some small amount of content that will sit on top of the video. This div will have a patterned background image which is tiled and covers the video. Here is a link to some free patterned overlays that you can download - http://html5backgroundvideos.com/pattern-overlays/ (Links to an external site.).

              <div class="overlay-bg">
                <h1>An Awesome Title</h1>
                <!-- this content appears over the video background -->
              </div>

              Then we will have the rest of the content for the page with a solid background colour.

              <section class="content">
                <h2>Some other title</h2>
                <p>Lorem Ipsum</p>
              </section>

              To make sure that our video area with the title and the content area are always covering our screen we will use the vh unit to describe the heights.

              .overlay-bg{
                 height:50vh; /* amount to show for the title */
                 padding:20vh 50px;
                 font-size: 7vh;
                 line-height: 10vh;  /* 20vh + 10vh + 20vh = 50vh height */
                 /* tile a background overlay here **/
                 background: url(../img/black-fly-screen.png) repeat;
              }

              .content{
                 /* fill this area with white or some colour to cover extra video that drops below */
                 min-height: 60vh; /* plus the 50 means always taller than the screen */
                 background: #d4d4d4;
              }

               

              Here is a CodePen with the code for you to copy as a demo - http://codepen.io/mad-d/pen/MKJKeE?editors=110 (Links to an external site.) 

              The CodePen does not actually link to the images. Here is the link to a working demo. - http://griffis.edumedia.ca/mad9013/video-bg/ (Links to an external site.)  

              The last part of the CSS is to fall back on just an image when loading on a small mobile screen. You can adjust the value for the max-width to a higher value if you want to hide the video on more screens.

              @media (max-width: 600px) {
               .fullscreen-bg {
                   /* instead show the poster image stretched to fill the screen */
                   background: url('../img/poster.jpg') center center / cover no-repeat;
               }

               .video-bg{
                   display: none;
               }
              }

              Keep in mind that this video has a LOT of motion and the videos have not be optimized. They are really large files. Not, what you would typically want for a background.

               

              Design Considerations

              The video used in the example for this page uses the Big Buck Bunny sample video. It is a LOOONG video with lots of motion. Neither of which are good for background video.

              Background videos should have seamless loops.

              Background videos should have simple motion that is easy to tune out. Don't let your video distract the user from the content. Think enhance not distract.

              Background videos should be short, to keep their size down, which allows browsers to download them faster.

              With the addition of an overlay we can actually reduce the quality of the video in order to reduce the download time. The overlay will help to hide the reduced quality of the video.

              Be sure to set the video to loop, autoplay, and to be muted.

              Include a poster image to be displayed while the video downloads enough to start playing. This poster image will likely be the same one that gets used in place of the video on mobile screens.

               

              Mobile Considerations

              If you are building something that targets mobile only or primarily, video is probably not the best choice for a background, due to the large file size. Use a background image instead of the video.

               

              Further Study about HTML Video 

              A great series of articles having to do with HTML5 Video and the many things you can do with video now as well as the technical details on how to achieve these things - http://thenewcode.com/759/Web-Development-Reading-List-Multimedia (Links to an external site.) .

               

              Previous Previous: Converting Between Formats Next Next: Conditional Comments

              Conditional Comments

              Sometimes you will be building websites that need to support older versions of Internet Explorer. Sometimes you would like to be able to load different versions of a CSS file based on the version of IE that the user has. In situations like this Conditional Comments come to the rescue.

              They are a feature that is supported by Internet Explorer only. They allow you to write content that will be interpreted by all browsers except IE as a comment. IE will read the contents of the conditional comment and, based on the syntax of the comment render the content based on the IE version.

              Here is a sample of a conditional comment which will load a CSS file for any version of IE. 

              <!--[if IE ]>
  <link href="iecss.css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css">
<![endif]-->

              All other browsers will view this as a comment.

              If you want to target a specific version of IE you can write comments like this:

              <!--[if IE 7 ]>
  <p>Only IE 7 will see this</p>
<![endif]-->

              This will write that paragraph only if the user is using version 7 of IE.

              <!--[if gte IE 6 ]>
 <p>Only  IE 6 and greater will see this</p>
<![endif]-->

              This will write the paragraph if the user is using version 6 or higher of IE.

               

              Here is a couple reference sites:

              http://www.sitepoint.com/web-foundations/internet-explorer-conditional-comments/ (Links to an external site.)

              http://www.quirksmode.org/css/condcom.html (Links to an external site.)

              Picture, Figure, Figcaption, Img

              For the first twenty years of HTML the only tag we had to display images was <img>. Then along came HTML5, lots of debate, and then finally, the <figure>, <figcaption>, and <picture> elements.

              Figure

              The <figure> and <figcaption> elements are intended to be used with the <img> element to provide the same type of functionality and semantics as you would have in a printed resource. If you want add a label to your image the <figcaption> element will wrap around the details. Then the <figure> element wraps around both.

              <figure>
                <img src="./img/lake-como.jpg" alt="Beautiful lake Como" />
                <figcaption>Fig. 1.2 A photo of Lake Como at midday</figcaption>
              </figure>

              Now, because of the <figure> element, we have a semantic way to connect the image to the description.

               

              Picture

              The <picture> element was created to solve the problem of needing to load different sizes and resolutions of images for different devices with different screen sizes and network connections.

              <picture>
                <source srcset="" media="" />
                <source srcset="" media="" />
                <source srcset="" media="" />
                <img src="default.jpg" alt="description" />
              </picture>

              This is the basic syntax for the <picture> element. We add multiple <source> elements inside the <picture>. Each one of them has two attributes - srcset, and media. The srcset element points to a specific version of an image file on the server. The media attribute holds a media query with the specific conditions of when that element should be loaded.

              The last part is the <img/> element. It exists as a fall back when the browser doesn't understand the <picture> or <source> elements or none of the media queries have conditions that are met.

              It is important to understand that this is NOT a replacement for the media queries in your CSS. The media attribute in the <source> elements should work in conjunction with your CSS file. The CSS file will control the layout of the page and what happens around and behind the picture PLUS the rendered size of your image.

              The media attributes are only controlling which version of the image to load. The media attributes are helping you control the quality, resolution, and filesize of the specific image being loaded.

              <picture>
                <source srcset="hugePic.jpg" media="(min-width: 1200px)" />
                <source srcset="normalPic.jpg" media="(min-width: 800px) and (max-width: 1200px)" />
                <source srcset="smallPic.jpg" media="(max-width: 800px)" />
                <img src="default.jpg" alt="description" />
              </picture>

              Here are some notes from the Mozilla Developer Network about the srcset attribute:

              A list of one or more strings separated by commas indicating a set of possible images represented by the source for the browser to use. Each string is composed of:

              1. one URL to an image,
              2. a width descriptor, that is a positive integer directly followed by 'w'. The default value, if missing, is the infinity.
              3. a pixel density descriptor, that is a positive floating number directly followed by 'x'. The default value, if missing, is 1x.

              Each string in the list must have at least a width descriptor or a pixel density descriptor to be valid. Among the list, there must be only one string containing the same tuple of width descriptor and pixel density descriptor.
              The browser chooses the most adequate image to display at a given point of time.
              The srcset attribute has an effect only when the <source> (Links to an external site.) element is the direct child of a <picture> (Links to an external site.)element.

              SRCSET

              So, why do we use srcset instead of src in these <source> elements?

              The reason is that we can actually list multiple possible images inside each source element. srcset can be a comma separated list of images. After each image we would add a "x" modifier to provide the pixel density that best matches each image. 

              So, in addition to using multiple <source> elements with media queries to determine the size of the image being loaded, we can use the "x" modifier to also choose a best version of the image based on screen density.

              <picture>
                <source srcset="img/small.jpg 1x, img/small@2x.jpg 2x, img/small@4x.jpg 4x" media="(max-width: 600px)" />
                <source srcset="img/med.jpg 1x, img/med@2x.jpg 2x, img/med@4x.jpg 4x" media="(min-width:600px)" />
                <img src="img/med.jpg" alt="the medium image with 1x screen density is our default" />
              </picture>

              This example has six different images that it can load based on the screen width and the screen pixel-density. First, based on the screen width it will choose either the first or the second <source> element. Then it will look at the pixel density on the screen that will load the image. Based on that it picks a different version of the image that we created.

              Keep in mind that with @media queries that we put in the media attribute, we can also use things like 

              (orientation: landscape)
              (max-aspect-ratio: 16/9)

              to choose a more appropriate image.

              It will mean more work for the person who is working with the images but in the end it will produce a better user experience... which is what will bring your users back.

              One Final Note

              In the first <picture> example, the <img> element looks like a fallback only.

              Picture is the parent element, the element doing all the heavy lifting here is the <img>. The <img> uses its <picture> parent and its elder <source> siblings to pick a resource to load, but eventually it is the <img> that is used to display the resource. That means that the <img> must be there, otherwise, no image will be displayed on screen. That’s also good for fallback purposes: the <img>needs to be there in order to provide a fallback for older browsers, so it should be there anyway, but regardless, if the <img> is not there, nothing will display.

               

              References and Resources

              https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2014/05/responsive-images-done-right-guide-picture-srcset/ (Links to an external site.) (Links to an external site.)

              https://dev.opera.com/articles/native-responsive-images/ (Links to an external site.) 

              https://www.html5rocks.com/en/tutorials/responsive/picture-element/ (Links to an external site.)

              http://caniuse.com/#search=srcset (Links to an external site.)
