              CSS Transitions

              CSS3 Transitions

              A CSS transition will let you change one or more CSS properties from one value to another. The change can be triggered through a pseudo-class like :active or :hover. The change can be triggered by dynamically adding a new class name to an HTML element through Javascript.

              Unfortunately, IE 10 is the first version of IE to support them - http://caniuse.com/css-transitions (Links to an external site.) 

              There were prefixed versions of the transition property for Opera, Firefox, and Chrome | Safari.

              So, while transitions let you add some very cool effects to your webpages, you should never rely on them for a critical part of your design.

              Think of transitions as an enhancement that you are adding to your pages or apps.

               

              Syntax of Transitions

              Let's say that you have a button with the background color of black and you want it to gradually change to more of a silver grey colour when the user hovers over the button. Here is the HTML.

              <button class="clicker">Please Click Me</button>

              Old CSS

              .clicker{ 
                background-color: #000; 
              }
              .clicker:hover, 
              .clicker:active{ 
                background-color: #d5d4d3; 
              } 

               

              The old CSS lets you set two different colours for the button. There is one for the standard and another for the active/hover state.

              Now, with transitions we need to add a new property "transition" into the default style. The change between the two styles will now be managed by the properties of the transition.

              New CSS

              .clicker{ 
                transition: background-color 0.4s ease; 
                background-color: #000; 
              }

               

              This transition now belongs to all elements with the class "clicker". The transition looks to the property background-color and will make the transition between the two values over the space of 0.4 seconds using the ease timing function. There is an optional fourth parameter that lets you set a delay before the transition occurs. This transition will apply to both directions from the non-hover to the hover and from the hover to the non-hover.

              If you want to set multiple transitions you can. Just add one transition property and values list for each transition you want to create. Optionally, you can use the keyword all as the first value. When you use the keyword all you will be telling the browser to apply the same transition for ALL properties that are different between the two styles. 

              For some basic info see - http://css-tricks.com/almanac/properties/t/transition/ (Links to an external site.) 

              For a little longer tutorial - http://www.webdesignerdepot.com/2010/01/css-transitions-101/ (Links to an external site.) and http://css3.bradshawenterprises.com/transitions/ (Links to an external site.) 

               

              Cool Use for Transitions

              Because we can add transitions with any pseudo-class it means the new CSS3 pseudo classes with forms like :checked can be used to help style and animate some effects.

              Check out this article about using Transitions in combination with SVG animations to animate transition effects in a form.

              http://tympanus.net/codrops/2013/10/15/animated-checkboxes-and-radio-buttons-with-svg/ (Links to an external site.)

              Here is the link to the demo - http://tympanus.net/Development/AnimatedCheckboxes/ (Links to an external site.)

               

              Samples

              http://codepen.io/larrygeams/pen/dBDLh (Links to an external site.)

              http://codepen.io/hugo/pen/teGmr (Links to an external site.)

              http://codepen.io/benkadev/pen/Ggrxd (Links to an external site.)

              These are just a few codepen with transition and transform examples.

               

              Previous Previous: Picture, Figure, Figcaption, Img Next Next: CSS Transforms

              CSS Transforms

              CSS3 Transforms

              CSS Transforms are changes in position for HTML elements that can occur in 2D or 3D space. The CSS transform property has a function name as its value.

              2D Transforms

              The 2D transforms functions are rotate, scale, scaleX, scaleY, skew, and translate.

              transform: rotate( 27deg );  //rotate around the top left corner by 27 degrees.
              transform: scale( 1.5 );  //stretch the horizontal and vertical
              transform: scaleX( 2 );  //stretch by 200% in the horizontal
              transform: scaleY( 3 );  //stretch by 300% in the vertical
              transform: skewX( 15deg );  //change the angles of the left and right edges by 15degrees clockwise.
              transform: skewY( 30deg );  //change the angles of the top and bottom edges by 30 degrees down. keep the vertical lines the same.
              transform: translate( 20px, 50px ); //move horizontally 20px right, vertically 50px down

               

              Add any of all of these properties inside a style to change the location and appearance of an element. The translate function is similar to making the object position:relative and applying a top and left value.

              Go here to experiment with the 2D Transforms - http://www.westciv.com/tools/transforms/index.html (Links to an external site.)

               

              3D Transforms

              Along with the 2D transforms is a set of 3D Transforms. Basically, we are applying the same sorts of changes as we do in the 2D Transforms but we are applying them in three dimensions.

              One of the best things about the 3D Transforms is that we can use the 3D Transform functions to make 2D changes but this will trigger hardware accelerated performance on your machine. Any device that has a GPU and is capable of hardware accelerated performance will use it IF you use a 3D Transform. So, combine your 3D Transform with a cool transition and you get hardware accelerated animations on your web page / web app.

              The method names basically have a "3d" at the end of the name and expect an additional parameter for the z-axis.

              http://css3.bradshawenterprises.com/ (Links to an external site.) - great resource with examples for Transitions and Transforms.

              And another - http://24ways.org/2010/intro-to-css-3d-transforms/ (Links to an external site.)

               

              When you rotate an object in 3D it means that you could end up with the front facing away from you and you would see the backwards text and background colour. For this reason there is a backface-visibility property to let us hide the front-facing content. http://css-tricks.com/almanac/properties/b/backface-visibility/ (Links to an external site.)

              *** Opera support is limited or non-existant in the versions before they switched to the webkit engine.

               

              Previous Previous: CSS Transitions Next Next: CSS Animations

              CSS Animations

              CSS3 Animations

               CSS Animations are similar to transitions except that we can set up key frames for the animation. These are basically small break points during the animation where we decide which properties change, by how much, and how long it takes. 

              With an animation you create your CSS styles as you normally would to set the starting point for the visual appearance. Then you add a property called "animation". the animation property defines the name of your animation, how long it takes, and how many times it loops.

              .mystyle{ 
                background-color: #abc;
                 font-size: 2.0rem; 
                animation: cool 3s infinite; 
              }

               

              Once you have the animation property inside the style we need to create an animation to run.

              @keyframes cool{ 
               0% {
               transform: scale( 1 );
               }
               50% {
               transform: scale(2);
               }
               80% {
               transform: scale(1.8);
               }
               100% {
               transform: scale(1);
               }
              }

               

              The animation uses @keyframes to define the whole animation. Inside the curly braces we define the breakpoints. The first one is usually called "from" and the last one is called "to". The ones in the middle use percentages. You can also use 0% and 100% as the first and last breakpoints.

               

              Here are a few tutorials on animations that provide more specific details - 

              http://docs.webplatform.org/wiki/tutorials/css_animations (Links to an external site.)

              http://develop-a-website.com/simple-css3-animation-tutorials/ (Links to an external site.)

              https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Guide/CSS/Using_CSS_animations?redirectlocale=en-US&redirectslug=CSS%2FTutorials%2FUsing_CSS_animations (Links to an external site.)

               

              Previous Previous: CSS Transforms Next Next: CSS Gradients

              CSS Gradients

              CSS now lets you use gradients, either linear or radial, to set backgrounds behind elements. http://caniuse.com/css-gradients (Links to an external site.). IE10 can use the standard ones. IE6 had a filter property that could be used back in 2001.

               

              USE THIS SPARINGLY. It is very easy to create too many gradients or gradients that do not work well together.

               

              Here is a quick CSS Gradient generator (there are lots of them online) - http://www.colorzilla.com/gradient-editor/ (Links to an external site.). Have a look at the syntax generated by this page.

              Here is some sample CSS that shows how you would add a background colour for old browsers, then the gradients for newer browsers, then the proper w3c approved syntax for gradients, and finally the old IE syntax for adding gradients with the filter property.

              background: #1e5799; /* Old browsers */

              filter: progid:DXImageTransform.Microsoft.gradient( startColorstr='#1e5799', endColorstr='#7db9e8',GradientType=0 ); /* IE6-9 */
              background: -moz-linear-gradient(top, #1e5799 0%, #2989d8 50%, #207cca 51%, #7db9e8 100%); /* FF3.6+ */
              background: -webkit-gradient(linear, left top, left bottom, color-stop(0%,#1e5799), color-stop(50%,#2989d8), color-stop(51%,#207cca), color-stop(100%,#7db9e8)); /* Chrome,Safari4+ */
              background: -webkit-linear-gradient(top, #1e5799 0%,#2989d8 50%,#207cca 51%,#7db9e8 100%); /* Chrome10+,Safari5.1+ */
              background: -o-linear-gradient(top, #1e5799 0%,#2989d8 50%,#207cca 51%,#7db9e8 100%); /* Opera 11.10+ */
              background: -ms-linear-gradient(top, #1e5799 0%,#2989d8 50%,#207cca 51%,#7db9e8 100%); /* IE10+ */

              background: linear-gradient(to bottom, #1e5799 0%,#2989d8 50%,#207cca 51%,#7db9e8 100%); /* W3C */

               

               

              There are prefixed versions for webkit, firefox, and opera. There were quite a few changes to the syntax used by the gradients while this was under development. CSS Tricks has a nice introductory tutorial on gradients. - http://css-tricks.com/css3-gradients/ (Links to an external site.)

              Here is a slightly more advanced tutorial from the Mozilla folks - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Guide/CSS/Using_CSS_gradients (Links to an external site.)

              And another older but still useful and easy to read tutorial on gradients - http://webdesignerwall.com/tutorials/cross-browser-css-gradient (Links to an external site.)

               

               

              Previous Previous: CSS Animations Next Next: Grid Systems

              Grid Systems

              There have been many different methods to create page layouts on various grids. Most HTML Frameworks are based on some type of Grid.

              A grid is simply a structure that can be repeated that lays out your page in columns and rows. Alignment is extremely important for layout. Alignment is one of the qualities that your brain uses to group objects on a page. People will make decisions about how easy your site will be to navigate, in a fraction of a second, based on the alignment of your elements OR lack of alignment.

              Gutters

              When we create our columns we don't just want to have equal widths. We need to have gutters too. Gutters are the space between the content in the columns. 

               

              Twelve Columns

              Most grid systems are based on 12 columns.

              Why 12?

              Because 12 can be split into even groups of 2, 3, 4, or 6 elements. That's a lot of flexibility. There may be parts of your page where you want to use 3 columns and other parts you will be using 2, 4, or 6. 

              We will want to use the same spacing for the gutters in most cases. When you want to deviate from your standard widths it is best to use a multiple of your base number.

              Eg: Using 2rem for the gutter between columns. You want to create a larger margin between a couple elements. So, use 4rem or 6rem or 8rem. A multiple of the base amount is a good size to use for additional margins or offsets.

               

              The CSS

              Here is the CSS we could use to create our column classes. Notice the names used for the classes. They imply how many columns are in the current row.

              *{
  box-sizing: border-box;
}
.row{
  width: 100%;
  padding: 1rem 2rem; /* the gutter on the outside edges of the row */
  clear:both;
  background-color: #ddd;
  overflow: auto;
}
.col{
  background-color: #bbb;
  float:left;
}
.col-1{
  width: 100%;
  padding:0;
}
.col-2{
  width: 50%;
  padding-right: 2rem;
}
.col-3{
  width: 33.3333333%;      /* 100/3   */
  padding-right: 2rem;
}
.col-4{
  width: 25%;              /* 100/4    */
  padding-right:2rem;
}
.col-6{
  width: 16.666666667%;    /* 100/6    */
  padding-right: 2rem;
}
.col-12{
  width: 8.3333333333%;    /* 100/12   */
  padding-right: 2rem;
}
.col-2:last-child,
.col-3:last-child,
.col-4:last-child,
.col-6:last-child,
.col-12:last-child{
 padding-right: 0;
}
p{
  padding: 1rem;
  background-color: #999;
  font-size: 2rem;
  line-height: 3rem;
}

              Then in our HTML we apply these CSS classes for the rows and columns.

              <body>
               <div class="row">
               <div class="col col-3"><p>content</p></div>
               <div class="col col-3"><p>content</p></div>
               <div class="col col-3"><p>content</p></div>
               </div>
               <div class="row">
               <div class="col col-4"><p>content</p></div>
               <div class="col col-4"><p>content</p></div>
               <div class="col col-4"><p>content</p></div>
               <div class="col col-4"><p>content</p></div>
               </div>
               <div class="row">
               <div class="col col-4"><p>content</p></div>
               <div class="col col-2"><p>wide content</p></div>
               <div class="col col-4"><p>content</p></div>
               </div>
              </body>

              This would create a layout with three rows.

              The first row would have three equal columns.

              The second row would have four equal columns.

              The third row would have three columns. Two of them taking up 25% of the width and one taking up 50% of the width. 

               

              This is NOT the only way to create columns and it is not an absolute list of values that you need to use, just an example of how you could create a GRID system.

               

              Previous Previous: CSS Gradients Next Next: CSS version 4 Preview

              Previous Previous: Grid Systems Next Next: CSS Filters

              CSS Filters

              CSS3 also introduced a filter property which allows you to apply effects to elements on your page.

              .something{
                filter: blur(2px);
              }

              Here is a list of possible values for the filter property.

              • blur( )
              • brightness( )
              • contrast( )
              • drop-shadow( )
              • grayscale( )
              • hue-rotate( )
              • invert( )
              • opacity( )
              • saturate( )
              • sepia( )
              • url( ) - for applying SVG filters

              Each of these properties has slightly different requirements. For example, blur takes a pixel value for the amount of blur radius.

              grayscale, sepia, saturate, brightness, contrast, opactiy, and invert take a number between 0 and 1 as the percentage of the filter to apply.

              hue-rotate takes an angle in degrees.

              url takes a url for an SVG filter.

              This page has a description and a codepen example for each type - https://css-tricks.com/almanac/properties/f/filter/ (Links to an external site.) 

               

              https://css-tricks.com/color-filters-can-turn-your-gray-skies-blue/ (Links to an external site.) 

              http://webcodetools.com/css-generator/ (Links to an external site.)

              • Submitting a website url

              Create a HTML file and an external CSS file that shows responsive images using the <picture>, <source>, and <img> tags combined with a responsive layout driven by CSS media queries.

              As the user adjusts the size of your page two things will happen:

              1. The media queries in your CSS file will be altering the layout and the number of columns that appear on the page.

              2. The media queries in your HTML <source> elements will be choosing the most appropriate size image file to load and display.

               

              To create a proper image grid that expands as the page is adjusted, use an HTML <ul> plus an <li> element for each picture.

               

              Images

              Download these images - raw-images.zip 

              Each image needs to be resaved and optimized for the web. Crop and convert each image into three sizes:

              Large: 800px width x 600px height - to be used when the page width is greater than 1500px.

              Medium: 600px width x 450px height - to be used when the page width is between 700px and 1500px

              Small: 400px width x 300px height - to be used when the page width is less than 700px

              These sizes should be used in your <source> elements.

              Use the medium size as the default for your <img> elements. 

              All your <picture> and <img> elements should be given a default max-width of 90% so that they can resize to fit their container.

               

              Image Attribution

              Be sure to add the attribution to your images as a comment in either your CSS or HTML.

              All images used belong to:

              Markus Spiske - https://500px.com/markusspiske (Links to an external site.) 

              Yinan Chen - https://500px.com/webmaster85 (Links to an external site.) 

              Fahim Akhter - https://500px.com/fahimakhter (Links to an external site.) 

               

              Layout

              In your webpage there will be 3 layouts. Use percentages to control the width of the <li> elements and the margins between them.

              1. Less than 600px - one column layout

              2. Between 600px and 1200px - two column layout

              3. Above 1200px - four column layout

               

               

              Submission

              Create a GitHub Repository called "responsive-images".

              Add the gh-pages branch to the responsive-images repo.

              Save your HTML file as index.html

              Put your CSS file in a CSS folder and link to it from the HTML file.

              Put your resized images in a folder called "img".

              Add the HTML, CSS, and images to your gh-pages branch of your repo.

              Submit the link to your gh-pages rendered site.

              Eg:  https://abcd0001.github.io/responsive-images/index.html (Links to an external site.)

              (Change the abcd0001 to your own username)

               

              TEST your link to make sure it works before submitting the link.

              Links that return a 404 error are worth zero.

                CSS PreProcessors

                By this point you are very familiar with CSS and its syntax and can appreciate that, at times, the styles you write are repetitive. CSS Preprocessors are programs that can take a "shorthand" version of CSS and write the finished CSS for you.

                There are a number of different solutions for this

                SASS - http://sass-lang.com/ (Links to an external site.)

                LESS - http://lesscss.org/ (Links to an external site.)

                Stylus - http://learnboost.github.io/stylus/ (Links to an external site.)

                Compass - http://compass-style.org/ (Links to an external site.)

                There are others too. There are also preprocessors that help to minimize the Javascript that you write (Compass and Coffeescript).

                This section will be talking about the basics of these tools so you can try them out and see if any of them appeal to you.

                With practice, any of them can save you time in your development work.

                 

                Even better is the fact that they all represent another group of acronyms that you can add to your resume. Remember that larger companies have HR people who know nothing about the magic that we do. All they see is the list of acronyms on the job requirement sheet.

                 

                Previous Previous: Week 11 References Next Next: Intro to SASS

                Intro to SASS

                SASS CSS Preprocessor

                Syntactically Awesome StyleSheets (SASS) allows you to create .scss (Sassy CSS) files which remove much of the repetition and inflexibility of the CSS syntax. These .scss files are then translated into .css files with a Ruby program.

                If you are using a Mac then Ruby comes preinstalled.

                If you are using Windows then you need to download and install Ruby. This only takes a couple minutes and only needs to be done once. Go to http://rubyinstaller.org/ (Links to an external site.) and click the download button. Once downloaded, install Ruby at the default location. Make sure you click the option to add Ruby to your Path Environment variable.

                 

                Installing SASS

                Once you have Ruby installed, go to the command window (or Terminal app on Mac) and enter the following.

                gem source -a https://rubygems.org/

                gem install sass

                Done. You now have SASS installed and can use it.

                 

                Using SASS

                Once SASS is installed we just tell it which folders to watch and convert. Let's say that you are putting all your .scss files for your current project at this location:

                c:\Users\<username>\Documents\Code\mad9013\my-project\sass

                And we want SASS to watch that folder and translate any .scss files in that folder into .css files inside this folder:

                c:\Users\<username>\Documents\Code\mad9013\my-project\css

                Then from the command line we would type this:

                > sass --watch c:\Users\<username>\Documents\Code\mad9013\my-project\sass:c:\Users\<username>\Documents\Code\mad9013\my-project\sass

                Of course, that is alot of typing. We could just change directories so we are typing the command from the css folder first. Then we would type this instead.

                > cd c:\Users\<username>\Documents\code\mad9013\my-project
                > sass --watch sass:css

                Done.

                Now any time you have a .scss file inside the sass folder it will be monitored. Each time you make a change a new or updated .css file will be saved.

                 

                Output Styles

                When telling SASS to compile your CSS to SASS or telling it to watch a folder and continually update the CSS, we can also tell it what style to use when generating the CSS.

                sass --watch sass/:css/ --style compressed

                The --style option at the end of that line tells SASS to use the "compressed" version.

                The four different values for style are: expanded, nested, compact and compressed. 

                Expanded is the normal way you would write CSS. Nested allows for some additional indenting but still very readable. Compact is making each selector and its' styles appear on one line. This has less whitespace but is not as readable. Compressed removes all extra whitespace.

                 

                Basic Syntax

                The cool thing about SASS is that you don't have to know anything except standard CSS to use it. You can take a CSS file and change its file extension to .scss and you're done. 

                Now there are of course things we can do in SASS to simplify our css. We can use indenting and nesting.

                nav{ 
                  margin: 5px 20px; 

                  ul.mainnav{ 
                    overflow:hidden; 

                    li{ 
                      float:left; 
                    } 
                  } 
                }

                The SASS code above would be translated into the following CSS.

                nav{ 
                  margin: 5px 20px; 
                }
                nav ul.mainnav{ 
                  overflow:hidden; 
                }
                nav ul.mainnav li{ 
                  float:left; 
                } 

                Notice how the nesting creates the longer selectors in the final css?

                 

                We can also use variables in our CSS with SASS. Here is a simple example with colors.

                $color-main: #333; 
                $color-light: #999; 
                $color-accent: #ea4c89;
                p{ 
                  color: $color-main; 
                  background-color: $color-light;
                }
                h3{ 
                  color: $color-accent; 
                }

                 

                There are many other cool features like mix-ins and functions that can be used to dynamically calculate things and create stylesheets with less time spent writing repetitive code and more time spent on the actual design. Go http://sass-lang.com/guide (Links to an external site.) to learn more about the basics.

                To see the full documentation go here: http://sass-lang.com/documentation/file.SASS_REFERENCE.html (Links to an external site.) 

                 

                 

                Previous Previous: CSS PreProcessors Next Next: SASS Features

                Re-submit Assignment

                • Submitting a website url

                You will be taking an original site with all the required fonts, images, CSS, and HTML from a GitHub Repo by forking it into a repo of your own.

                Once you have forked a copy of the repo on GitHub then you need to clone your own local copy of the repo.

                Original Repo: https://github.com/prof3ssorSt3v3/sass-conversion/ (Links to an external site.) 

                View the Website: http://prof3ssorst3v3.github.io/sass-conversion/ (Links to an external site.) 

                With your own local copy of the site your job is to create the SASS file that will generate the new version of main.css and main.css.map.

                In your SASS files you need to meet the following requirements:

                1. Three partials _variables.scss, _mixins.scss, _queries.scss which get imported into your main.scss file.

                2. Only one CSS file created - main.css

                3. Use SASS variables for colours and fonts.

                4. Use SASS parent selector - &

                5. Use SASS @extend

                6. Use @content with your media queries.

                7. Use Nesting in your SASS.

                8. Use @include with your @mixin s.

                9. Use a @mixin to calculate the sizes of your columns.

                 

                Things to Watch 

                Make sure that you replicate all the changes in font-size, color, background-color, font-weight, column widths, icon sizes, padding, floats, and alignment.

                Use the original CSS file from the "raw-css" folder in the repo as your reference to get the specifics for all the changes that you see. Make sure you don't overwrite the raw-css/main.css file. Use SASS to overwrite the css/main.css file.

                  HTML Tables

                  HTML Tables

                  Back in the 1990s, before CSS existed, the only way to create a webpage layout was to use HTML tables. 

                  Using tables to create layout leads to an inflexible page that cannot be changed through CSS. A table layout change requires direct changes to the HTML on every page in your entire website.

                  Table based layout also leads to bloated pages with larger filesizes. When ESPN switched from table based layout to CSS layout with floated divs they saved 3GB of bandwidth in the first month alone.

                  NEVER use tables to build a webpage layout.

                  Tables are for displaying tabular data like price lists, schedules, or calendars.

                   

                  How to Build a Table

                  Tables are quite simple to create. There is a single <table> tag. Inside that you have <thead>, if you have headings across the top, followed by <tbody> to contain the main data section of the table. There is an optional <tfoot> tag that would contain any headings that you want at the bottom of the table. However, the <tfoot> tag should be placed between the <thead> and the <tbody>.

                  For each row in your table you have a <tr> table row tag.

                  Inside your rows you have either <th> table heading cell tags, or <td> table data cell tags.

                  There is also a <caption> tag that displays a label for the table.

                  Example:

                  <table>
  <caption>This is a schedule</caption>
  <thead>
    <tr>
      <th>Monday</th>
      <th>Tuesday</th>
      <th>Wednesday</th>
    </tr>
  </thead>
  <tbody>
    <tr>
      <th>8am</th>
      <td>MAD9013</td>
      <td>MAD9014</td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <th>10am</th>
      <td>MAD9111</td>
      <td>MAD9010</td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <th>12pm</th>
      <td>&nbsp;</td>
      <td>CST8300</td>
    </tr>
</tbody>
</table>

                   

                  While we are in the practice of not adding many attributes to HTML tags because we want to make sure that CSS is controlling the appearance of our tags, there are two attributes that you need to be aware of. These two attributes can be added to any <th> or <td> tag. 

                  <td colspan="3">
                  <td rowspan="2">

                   

                  We can take any cell and expand it so it fills more than one column and/or more than one row. If a cell expands to fill multiple cells then you would omit the <td> tags where another cell is filling in.

                  This example shows a table that has two rows and three columns - six cells. The first cell is going to occupy four cell spaces. It will fill the first two columns for both rows. 

                  <table>
<tr>
                    <td colspan="2" rowspan="2"> four cells </td>
                    <td>row-one column-three</td>
                  </tr>
<tr>
                    <td> row-two column-three</td>
                  </tr>
</table>

                   

                   

                   

                  Previous Previous: Week 12 Summary Next Next: CSS for Tables

                  CSS for Tables

                  Styling Tables

                  There are several components that we are working with when we style tables.

                  1. The caption

                  2. The table as a whole

                  3. The headings

                  4. The rows

                  5. The individual data cells 

                   

                  The Caption

                  The <caption> tag used to give a label to the table can be styled like any paragraph. You would use font properties, color, padding, and alignment.

                  The other part of styling a caption is where you would place it. This property is set through the style on the table.

                  table{
                    caption-side: top; 
                  }

                   

                  The possible values are top, bottom, and for some browsers, left and right.

                   

                  The Table

                  The table is a block element and wants to fill up the width of it's container. However, it will dynamically size itself based on the amount of content inside its cells. It will try to balance the size of the columns and keep their width equal by taking the size of the biggest piece of content as the min width. The table will continue to grow until the entire width of the container is filled. Then it will start to take space away from the columns which do not need as much width.

                  All this to say, you can set a width on the table as a whole.

                  When you set a border on the table you are only talking about the outside edge around the table. If you want borders around each cell then you set that in the styles for the td and th.

                  Sometimes you will have an empty cell inside a table. By default a browser will typically hide this cell. Padding and borders will not appear. You can change this by using the empty-cells property and setting it to show or hide.

                  table{ 
                    caption-side: bottom; 
                    empty-cells: show; 
                    border:1px solid grey; 
                  }

                   

                  The Headings

                  The <th> cells can be across the top of your table or down one or both sides. Occassionally, you will have a row of <th> tags in the middle of your table if the content gets long. By default, headings are bold and horizontally centered inside their cells.

                  You can vertically align contents inside any table cell with the vertical-align property. This example shows the default values.

                  th{ 
                    font-weight: bold; 
                    vertical-align: top; 
                    text-align: center; 
                  }

                   

                  If you set a width on a <th> which is in the first row then you are effectively setting a width for the entire column.

                   

                  The Rows

                  If you want to set a border around a row or a background colour on a row then use the tr tag in your css.

                  tr{ 
                    background-color: #e4e4e4; 
                  }

                   

                  When using multiple background colours then it is important to understand that the styles on the tags are applied in this order

                  1. table
                  2. row
                  3. cell

                  You also need to understand how browsers use Css Specificity

                   

                  The Data Cells

                  The data cells are the <td> tags. If you have no <th> in the first row then the width that you set on the <td> tags in the first row will set the width for each column.

                  You can set the same styles on a <td> as you do on a <th>. The <td> tags do not have the default bolding and centering that <th> tags have. They are font-weight: normal and text-align: left by default.

                   

                  Columns and Where to Go Next

                  Now you have a basic understanding of tables and their styling.

                  Next is understanding how to create columns and style those.

                  This is a great article that you will be able to skim partly until you get to some of the more advanced table features and the <colgroup> and <col> tags. - http://css-tricks.com/complete-guide-table-element/ (Links to an external site.)

                   

                   

                  Previous Previous: HTML Tables Next Next: HTML Basic Form Elements

                  HTML Basic Form Elements

                  HTML Forms

                  When you want to collect user information then you need a form. When you try to buy something online then you are filling out a form. When you search a website for content then you are filling out a form.

                  The <form> is the mechanism we use to collect the information and send it to the server. What gets done with the information is handled in a server-side script written in another language like PHP or Ruby.

                  The HTML part is the interface that the user sees. Validation of the contents of the form should be done twice - once in Javascript and again on the server.

                  <form action="process.php" method="POST" >
                  </form>

                   

                  The form tag needs to have an action attribute and a method attribute. The action is the name of the page where you will be sending the contents of the form. The method is how we want the browser to package the data. We can use GET or POST as the value for the method but for our purposes we will always use POST.

                  Inside the <form> are all the <label>s plus <input>, <select>, and <textarea> tags that let us collect information.

                  The majority of form elements are created with <input> tags. The tag has a type attribute that lets you determine what interface is shown. MDN HTML Form reference - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Guide/HTML/Forms_in_HTML (Links to an external site.) and HTML input Element reference - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/input (Links to an external site.) 

                   

                  <input type="text" name="firstname" id="firstname" value=""  />
                  <input type="password" name="pass" id="pass" maxlength="40" />
                  <input type="hidden" name="refnum" id="refnum" />
                  <input type="radio" name="flavour" id="chocolate" checked />
                  <input type="checkbox" name="spam" id="spam" checked />
                  <input type="reset" name="btnClear" id="btnClear" value="Reset Form" />
                  <input type="button" name="btn" id="btn" value="Click Me" />
                  <input type="submit" name="btnSubmit" id="btnSubmit" value="Submit Form" />
                  <input type="file" name="resume" id="resume" />

                   

                  The type="text" is the default for an input tag. If you create an input tag without a type then text is what is displayed.

                  type="password" will display its value as stars, circles, or asterix. 

                  type="hidden" is user for data that you need included in the form but you don't want the user to edit it.

                  type="radio" displays the round buttons. Users have to choose ONE of the options.

                  type="checkbox" displays the square box for each possible answer. Use this when you want users to "choose all that apply".

                  type="reset" will set all the form fields back to what they were when the page loaded.

                  type="button" when you need a button to click inside a form that will run some Javascript

                  type="submit" sends the form data to the page indicated in the form action attribute

                  type="file" lets you upload an attached file. In order to use this the <form> must have a enctype="multipart/form-data" included inside.

                   

                  The <select> tag is used to create lists for a user to choose from. The <option> tag lets you display one item inside the dropdown list. If you want you can nest groups of <option> tags inside <optgroup label="Canada"></optgroup> tags.

                  <select name="province" id="province">
                    <option selected value="">Please choose</option>
                    <option value="AB">Alberta</option>
                    <option value="ON">Ontario</option>
                  </select>

                   

                  The <textarea> tag is used to let users write multiple lines of text.

                  <textarea name="comments" id="comments">Please enter your comments here.</textarea>

                   

                  Finally, we need to add a <label> for each form element. We add a for attribute to the label to connect it with a specific form element.

                  <label for="firstname">First Name</label>
                  <input type="text" id="firstname" name="firstname" value="" />

                   

                  The for attribute in the label connects with the id attribute inside the input, select, or textarea tag.

                   

                   

                  Previous Previous: CSS for Tables Next Next: HTML5 Form Elements

                  HTML5 Form Elements

                  HTML5 Forms

                  Along with HTML5 came a number of improved form features that front-end developers had been waiting for for a long time. There are new types for <input> tags and new attributes to be added to form elements.

                  HTML Form Guide from MDN - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Guide/HTML/Forms (Links to an external site.) 

                   

                  Here are some of the cool highlights.

                  New attribute for <input> tags - placeholder. Let's you put some default text inside the text field that will appear when the page loads but disappears when the user tabs to or clicks on the input element.

                  New attribute - required. Let's you mark a form element that must be completed by the user before submission.

                  New attribute - placeholder. Let's you have some instructional text or example shown inside the input which disappears as the user clicks or tabs into the form input.

                  <input type="email" required placeholder="name@domain.com" />

                  New <input> types:

                  - email - for entering email addresses. On mobile devices shows a virtual keyboard that includes "@"

                  - color - can show an OS specific colour picker

                  - date 

                  - datetime

                  - time

                  - month - Shows the months of the year

                  - search - to be used for search forms. Automatically removes line breaks

                  - number - Restricts input to floating-point numbers

                  - range - A stepper with up and down arrows or a slider showing one value from a range. Uses step attribute for amount of each step between the min and max.

                  - tel - Restricts or validates input in phone format. 

                  - url - Restricts or validates input for urls.

                   

                  The <input type="file" /> now has an accept attribute that lets you restrict which types of files can be uploaded. 

                  <input type="file" name="avatar" id="avatar" accept="image/*" />

                   

                  autocomplete can be added to use the browser's cache to fill in form elements or can be set to "off" to prevent that (think credit cards).

                  autofocus can be used to set the cursor inside a form field as soon as the page loads.

                  max and min attributes can be added to the numeric, range, date, and time fields.

                  pattern attribute lets you add a regular expression to validate a field against. See - http://www.lynda.com/Regular-Expressions-tutorials/Using-Regular-Expressions/85870-2.html (Links to an external site.) for more about Regular Expressions

                   

                   

                  Not all browsers support all these features.

                  See - http://caniuse.com/#feat=form-validation (Links to an external site.) and http://caniuse.com/#feat=forms (Links to an external site.) for more information about which browsers support these features.

                   

                   

                  Previous Previous: HTML Basic Form Elements Next Next: Styling Forms with One or Two Columns

                  Styling Forms with One or Two Columns

                  Styling Forms

                  When styling forms you can do lots of cool things to make them look like other paper forms. However, the bottom line with forms is making them usable.

                  Aligning and grouping elements properly so people can quickly scan them and fill them out should be your primary focus.

                  I will post a couple of code samples here showing an example of a one-column form and a two-column form.

                   

                  One Column Forms

                  The keys to creating one column forms are:

                  1. Keep your labels and inputs vertically aligned.

                  2. Make sure there is less space between the label and its own input than between the label and any unrelated input.

                  Here is the sample on CodePen - http://codepen.io/mad-d/pen/oGtLf (Links to an external site.)

                   

                  Two Column Forms

                  With 2 column forms we are creating a column of labels and a column of inputs. The labels need to be vertically aligned. The labels can be left or right aligned as long as they are vertically aligned against one edge. The inputs also need to be vertically aligned. 

                  We also want to keep the text inside the inputs horizontally aligned with the labels.

                  Here is the sample on CodePen - http://codepen.io/mad-d/pen/IEdJi (Links to an external site.)  

                   

                  Fun with Form Design

                  Once you have the basics of your form layout created then you need to work on an appealing style. You can create forms that look like paper forms. You can apply all the fonts and colours that you are using in the rest of your design. You can have fun with the design. Be mindful of your audience. Are you designing a form for a bank or an online forum for cosplayers?

                  Read these few articles to get some inspiration of how to design your forms.

                  http://www.smashingmagazine.com/2008/04/17/web-form-design-modern-solutions-and-creative-ideas/ (Links to an external site.)

                  http://uxdesign.smashingmagazine.com/2008/07/04/web-form-design-patterns-sign-up-forms/ (Links to an external site.)

                  http://www.smashingmagazine.com/2011/06/27/useful-ideas-and-guidelines-for-good-web-form-design/ (Links to an external site.)

                   

                  Eventually, we will be adding Javascript to our web pages and validating the information in the forms. HTML5 has pseudo-classes for forms that fail internal validation. :invalid can be added to your CSS. http://html5doctor.com/css3-pseudo-classes-and-html5-forms/ (Links to an external site.)

                  Here is a good article to get you thinking about how to design your responses to validation

                  http://uxdesign.smashingmagazine.com/2012/06/27/form-field-validation-errors-only-approach/ (Links to an external site.)

                   

                  Another article that talks about styling Contact Forms - http://www.hongkiat.com/blog/creative-contact-pages/ (Links to an external site.)

                   

                   

                   

                  Previous Previous: HTML5 Form Elements Next Next: CSS Form Input Pseudo-Classes

                  CSS Form Input Pseudo-Classes

                  Form inputs have a variety of additional state-based functionality. Inputs can have the following states (pseudo-classes):

                  :disabled - The disabled attribute has been added to the input element

                  :checked - The radio or checkbox has been checked. This can be combined with :not( )

                  :valid - The element has passed validation

                  :invalid  - The element has failed validation

                  :required  - The element has the required attribute and was left empty by the user

                  :placeholder  - The element has placeholder text

                  :placeholder-shown  - The placeholder text for the input is currently being shown

                  :focus  - The input element currently has focus

                  These attributes can be applied to change the way these inputs collect data.  We still cannot trust data coming from these inputs when it comes to security, but we can use these states to improve usability overall to the user.

                  Disabled

                  The input becomes disabled and you can no longer interact with it. The first of each input has the disabled attribute on it.

                  Focus

                  The focus state can be used to help the user identify what input they are currently on. This also highlights the input on tab focus. In this example we change the background color to red and the text color to white on focus.

                  Checked

                  Allows us to pre-selected a select menu, checkbox, and radio input types.

                  Previous Previous: Styling Forms with One or Two Columns Next Next: Favicons

                  Favicons

                  Favicons are those small icons that you see on the tabs in your browser or in the bookmarks menu.

                  They are small .ico, .gif, or .png images (16 x 16 pixels) that you point to using a <meta> tag in the <head> of your webpage. If you skip the meta tag, the browser will still look for a file called favicon.ico at the default location for your webserver:

                  http://www.example.com/favicon.ico (Links to an external site.)

                  If you have a website that is missing any favicon then look at the console or network output in the developer tools and you will see the 404 error.

                  Here are a few pages that talk about the details of the <meta> tag and the icon images:

                  The basics - http://www.dwuser.com/education/content/quick-tip-adding-a-favicon-to-your-website/ (Links to an external site.)

                  When you start talking about mobile support for favicons, there are a lot more options. Here is a good StackOverflow discussion of the possibilities - http://stackoverflow.com/questions/23849377/html-5-favicon-support (Links to an external site.) 

                  This website - http://www.favicon.cc/?action=icon&file_id=336336 (Links to an external site.) lets you build your own .ico files or convert .gif or .png images into .ico files.

                    Introduction to BootStrap

                    Bootstrap 3

                    Bootstrap is a framework for creating webpages / websites. That means that it is a collection of HTML, CSS, and Javascript files that give you a "framework" for building your site. By using a collection of pre-built CSS class names you can quickly construct a Responsive Layout.

                    Version 3 of Bootstrap contains the CSS needed to create Responsive Grids.

                     

                    Go here to download version 3 of Bootstrap - http://www.getbootstrap.com/ (Links to an external site.)

                    And the official notes on getting started - http://getbootstrap.com/getting-started/ (Links to an external site.)

                    Additional Files

                    For version 3, you will also need to download a copy of jQuery (Links to an external site.) and Respond.js (Links to an external site.). 

                     

                    Bootstrap 4 

                    The Alpha version of Bootstrap 4 came out in August 2015. We will be using version 4 for our final project. However, the vast majority of resources that you find which talk about Bootstrap CSS and HTML will work for both version 3 and 4.

                    The current site for version 4 of Bootstrap - http://v4-alpha.getbootstrap.com/ (Links to an external site.) 

                    With version 4 you will also need jQuery. In addition to the jQuery JS file, you will need the Bootstrap JS file and the Bootstrap CSS file.

                     

                    Internet Explorer Considerations

                    If you want to support versions of IE less than 9 then you will have to download version 1.x of jQuery. Version 2.x of jQuery is for IE9 and up.

                    Respond.js must be added inside the head of your HTML but only if you want to support Internet Explorer versions 6 and 7. 

                     

                     

                     

                    Example Sites

                    Here are a couple sites that provide examples of sites built using Bootstrap.

                    http://expo.getbootstrap.com/ (Links to an external site.)

                    http://lovebootstrap.com/ (Links to an external site.)

                    Here is the demo page for version 4 of Bootstrap

                    http://v4-alpha.getbootstrap.com/examples/ (Links to an external site.) 

                     

                    New in Version 4

                    Version 4 of Bootstrap has dropped the glyph icons.

                    As a good alternative to using the Bootstrap icons, I recommend using Font Awesome - https://fortawesome.github.io/Font-Awesome/ (Links to an external site.) 

                    Bootstrap 4 also supports the use of Flexbox for building your responsive layout.

                    Bootstrap 4 has introduced Cards as components - http://v4-alpha.getbootstrap.com/components/card/ (Links to an external site.) 

                    Bootstrap 4 now comes with a Themes - http://themes.getbootstrap.com/ (Links to an external site.) - these are designs created by the people who created Bootstrap (Twitter).

                    Bootstrap with Bower

                    As you start to do more work with websites and web apps you will find that your projects are getting larger and you end up with more and more dependencies. You can be relying on multiple CSS frameworks and multiple JavaScript libraries to make your site work. While this makes creating the site you want easier, it does mean that you end up having to download and maintain all those dependencies. Maintaining the correct versions of those frameworks and libraries and be a time consuming task.

                    This is what Bower is going to help you with. http://bower.io/ (Links to an external site.) 

                    Bower is a JavaScript based tool that will help you download and maintain all those dependencies.

                    Bower requires that you have Node JS (and NPM) installed already.

                    Assuming that you have those, you can use NPM to install Bower globally. 

                    npm install -g bower

                    Next, with Bower you can navigate to your project folder, on the command line, and run the bower commands to download the libraries and frameworks that you want.

                    bower install jquery
                    bower install bootstrap#4.0.0-alpha

                    Notice how you can add a hashtag followed by the exact version you want? Without the version modifier, Bower will just fetch the latest stable version of the library or framework that you requested.

                    Bower will have created a "bower_components" directory. Inside this directory will be a folder for each dependency you asked for.

                    Once you have all the dependencies you want, you can run the bower command to create your bower.json file. This is the file that will let you maintain the versions of each library.

                    bower init

                    Now, you can build the rest of your project referencing the local versions of each library . Every dependency has a "dist" folder with the expanded and minimized versions of the dependency.

                    For example, if we wanted to use jquery in our project we would do the following from inside our project folder:

                    bower install jquery 
                    bower init

                    Then we would add the following to our HTML page:

                    <script src="bower_components/jquery/dist/jquery.min.js"></script>

                     

                    Another cool thing about Bower is that it knows when a library depends on another library.

                    Bootstrap depends on jQuery. So, if you use Bower to install Bootstrap, it will also download and install jquery for you.

                     

                    Bower Components Folder

                    If you are like me then you probably hate the fact that the folder name is "bower_components" and it takes so long to type. We can change this by adding a config file into our root folder before we add any libraries.

                    .bowerrc

                    This is the file name. It's contents just need to have a JSON object with a directory name.

                    {
                      "directory": "libs"
                    }

                     Now, when you add things with Bower, the directory name will be "libs" instead of "bower_components". **Drops mic**

                     

                     

                    Previous Previous: Introduction to BootStrap Next Next: Bootstrap Layout - version 4

                    Bootstrap Layout - version 4

                    Our First Page with Bootstrap

                    Hopefully you have already created a project folder and used Bower to install the Bootstrap and jQuery CSS and JS. So, all those files are already inside a bower_components folder. See - Bootstrap with Bower for more details.

                    Create an index.html file as your home page in the root of your project folder. Here is the basic code that you will have to start your page.

                     

                    Now, we need to create the basics of a layout.

                    There are two CSS classes that are used for any structural element in your web page .container and .container-fluid.

                    Both are responsive. 

                    .container is a fixed width layout that uses max-width:100% to constrict itself if the page shrinks.

                    .container-fluid is always 100% of it's parent. So, if you are making your header, nav, main, and footer all full-width of the screen then .container-fluid is what you would use. 

                    Inside your container(s) you will place your rows. Use the CSS class ".row".

                    Inside your .row element will be your columns. The CSS will only work properly if you have the columns as direct children of the row. Nothing else should be immediately inside the row except the column elements.

                    The naming convention of the column classes will tell you how things will be divided on the page.

                    The one key to remember is that each row can be divided into 12 parts.

                    Notice how the four columns in this example are .col-sm-6, .col-sm-1, .col-sm-1, .col-sm-4.

                    The 6 + 1 + 1 + 4 add up to 12. These column widths will always be proportional to each other. The width of the column will be broken up into 12 equal parts and you get to decide how much of the row is assigned to each column part.

                    See the Pen bootstrap-grid (Links to an external site.) by Mobile Application Design-Development (@mad-d (Links to an external site.)) on CodePen (Links to an external site.).

                    If your numbers add up to more than 12 then the extra numbers will spill into the next line/row. If I used .col-sm-12 for all four columns then they would end up being stacked vertically, like 4 rows.

                    All the classes for the columns start with "col-". The final part of the name is the portion of the 12 that you want it to occupy. The middle part is associated with the media-queries. there are five values xs, sm, md, lg, and xl. They correspond with the following sizes:

                    xs - under 34em
                    sm - min-width: 34em
                    md - min-width: 48em
                    lg - min-width: 62em
                    xl - min-width: 75em

                    So, this part sometimes get a bit confusing.

                    We can assign different classes to each column so that they behave differently depending on which media query is affecting them currently.

                    Eg:

                     

                    Each class is an instruction on how the column width should behave under a different media query. If you only provide one size then it will behave that way under all conditions.

                    It is also possible to create different versions of your layout and have one version hidden under certain media queries. You could, if you desired, create five different versions of your columns inside a row and then hide four of them based on the current media query.

                    More details - http://v4-alpha.getbootstrap.com/layout/responsive-utilities/ (Links to an external site.)  

                     

                     

                    Previous Previous: Bootstrap with Bower Next Next: Bootstrap Navigation - version 4

                    Bootstrap Navigation - version 4

                    Navigation is key to any website. Bootstrap comes with different components to help you build your navigation menus - navs  (Links to an external site.)and navbars (Links to an external site.).

                    Navs

                    The .nav class is attached to the basic element for your navigation. Typically this is a <ul> element. Inside the <ul> will be your <li> elements. Give them each the class .nav-item.

                    That is the basic nav menu. It will still render as a vertical list but the links look more like buttons.

                    You can add your own CSS to make the links float horizontally if you like.

                    Another way to make the links line up horizontally is by adding either the .nav-tabs or .nav-pills to the <ul>

                    When you want to make the current links stand out just add the class .active to the current <li>.

                    If you want a link to look disabled add the class .disabled to the <li>. Note that this will not actually disable the link. You will need JavaScript to do that.

                     

                    Navbars

                    A Navbar is a wrapper around your <ul>. Typically this will be your <nav> element and it will get the class .navbar.

                    Here is a basic example of a full navbar that includes a company link on the left, a horizontal nav, and a search form on the right.

                    Additional classes that can be added to your .navbar element will be appearance/color classes like .navbar-dark and .bg-inverse.

                    Note the navbar-brand class that is added to the first link. This is used to make the text larger. It is intended for your Company name - Branding.

                    Also note the classes added to the <form> 

                    class="form-inline navbar-form pull-right"

                    These are used to make the form elements: line-up horizontally, style the form with a box around it, and float it to the right.

                    See the reference page for many other examples - 

                    http://v4-alpha.getbootstrap.com/components/navbar/ (Links to an external site.) 

                     

                    Buttons

                    Closely linked to navigation are buttons. Bootstrap comes with a bunch of classes which will turn several different elements into buttons that look the same. All the better to style with.

                    <a href="#" class="btn btn-primary">Link</a> 
                    <button type="button" class="btn btn-primary">Button</button> 
                    <input type="submit" class="btn btn-primary" value="Send" />

                    All three of these elements will look exactly the same to the user. 

                    The difference is in the semantics behind the element and the behaviour attached to each element. Anchors are for navigating. Buttons are typically for calling on some Javascript behaviour, and input type="submit" elements are for submitting a form.

                    The btn class is the class that manages the basic appearance.

                    The second class manages the colours of the buttons. The choices are btn-primary, btn-success, btn-secondary, btn-warning, btn-danger, and btn-link. You can likely guess the associated colours based on the name. If not, here is the reference - http://v4-alpha.getbootstrap.com/components/buttons/ (Links to an external site.) 

                    Previous Previous: Bootstrap Layout - version 4 Next Next: Customizing Bootstrap - version 4

                    Customizing Bootstrap - version 4

                    So, by now I hope you see how easy it is to create an interface with the building classes that come with the Bootstrap CSS file.

                    But, after you build a couple websites with the stock CSS people are going to start questioning you about if you know how to build anything else. They'll want to know if you can use a background other than blue, white, or grey. 

                    The answer is an emphatic YES!

                     

                    We can extend any of the bootstrap classes that we want.

                    Inside the head of our Bootstrap site we are typically going to have four <links>, in this order.

                    1. The link to the font-awesome minimized css.

                    2. The link to your Google font CSS.

                    3. The link to the Bootstrap minimized css.

                    4. The link to our own custom CSS.

                     

                    It is inside our custom CSS file where we will override the bootstrap or font-awesome CSS.

                    If the specificity of our CSS selector is the same as the one inside their files then our file should win out because it is further down the line. 

                    However, it's better to not take chances and try to create a higher specificity. Let's start with this plain vanilla version of the Bootstrap CARD component.

                    <div class="card">
  <img class="card-img-top" data-src="holder.js/100px180/" alt="Card image cap">
  <div class="card-block">
    <h4 class="card-title">Card title</h4>
    <p class="card-text">Some quick example text to build on the card title and make up the bulk of the card's content.</p>
    <a href="#" class="btn btn-primary">Button</a>
  </div>
</div>

                    Their .card class has a white background and a grey border by default.

                    We want a beautiful lavender background with a darker shade of purple for the border colour. So, we alter the HTML like this:

                    <div class="card lavely">
  <img class="card-img-top" data-src="holder.js/100px180?bg=8C4BE8" alt="Card image cap">
  <div class="card-block">
    <h4 class="card-title">Card title</h4>
    <p class="card-text">Some quick example text to build on the card title and make up the bulk of the card's content.</p>
    <a href="#" class="btn btn-lavely">Button</a>
  </div>
</div>

                    Now, with our aptly named .lavely class in place beside the class .card and the .btn-lavely added to the button at the bottom, we head over to our custom CSS file and add this.

                    .card.lavely{
                     background-color: lavender;
                     border-color: rebeccapurple;
                    }
                    .btn.btn-lavely{
                     background-color: rebeccapurple;
                     color: #E9D9FF;
                    }

                    Placing both class names together with no spaces means that the browser will be looking for elements that have BOTH classes.

                    Here is the resulting appearance of our card.

                     

                    Font Awesome

                    One final note about customizing. The same type of rule applies when overriding  the styles for the Font Awesome icon font.

                    Whatever class you are using, just combine two class names and you can override the properties.

                    .fa.fa-shield{
                      font-size: 7rem;
                      color: rebeccapurple;
                    }

                    This will override the default size and colour for the .fa-shield icons on your page.

                     

                     

                    Previous Previous: Bootstrap Navigation - version 4 Next Next: Bootstrap 4 - Font Stack

                    Bootstrap 4 - Font Stack

                    When designing your font stacks up until this point we have largely been using a web font, followed by some OS fallback fonts and then a generic font type.

                    The names that we use for the OS fallback fonts should represent the name of the font on an operating system. Sometimes those names can be a bit cryptic and hard to discover. Bootstrap version 4 actually has a built in font-stack in its SASS variables. (_variables.scss file) 

                    // Safari for OS X and iOS (San Francisco)
  -apple-system,
  // Chrome for OS X (San Francisco)
  BlinkMacSystemFont,
  // Windows
  "Segoe UI",
  // Android
  "Roboto",
  // Basic web fallback
  "Helvetica Neue", Arial, sans-serif

                    This is the font stack that they use in their CSS for anything built with Bootstrap version 4. (This is different than version 3).

                    Effectively, what bootstrap is doing is creating a font stack that goes through a series of names trying to locate one of the current operating system. If you are on Safari or Chrome on OSX or iOS then you will get the "San Francisco" font. If you are on Windows you will get the "Segoe UI" font, if you are on Android then you will get the "Roboto" font.

                    If, for any reason you can't load one of those three then you will get one of the last three in the stack.

                    So, this is the font-stack that exists by default on all elements in Bootstrap 4. 

                    font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, "Segoe UI", "Roboto", "Helvetica Neue", Arial, sans-serif;

                    You can, like everything in Bootstrap, override this with your own CSS font stack.

                    Bootstrap Website

                    Re-submit Assignment
                    • Due Dec 14 by 1pm

                    • Submitting a website url

                    Using the Bootstrap Framework, build a three page RESPONSIVE website about Climate Change and what people can do to help prevent it. This will be a website for a ficticious organization that you invent. Come up with a name for the organization and it's main focus in fighting climate change.

                    Use Bootstrap version 3 or 4. (3 - http://getbootstrap.com/ (Links to an external site.) ) (4 - https://v4-alpha.getbootstrap.com/ (Links to an external site.) ). As long as you are using Bootstrap properly for your layout then your website will be responsive.

                    Use a serif & sans-serif Google Font pair. One serif font for all your headings and one sans-serif font for all your body text and links. If you decide to use a third font, it must be only for your main heading on the home page, or the company name branding in the nav bar.

                    Use an Analogous Colour Scheme. http://color.adobe.com/ (Links to an external site.) 

                     

                    UPDATE About JavaScript

                    If you want to use some of the components they require JavaScript. Some need no script, some need jQuery plus the bootstrap JS, and others require jQuery, tether.js, and the bootstrap JS file.

                    The jQuery JS file and the tether JS files can be loaded from a CDN (Content Delivery Network)

                     <script src="https://ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/3.1.1/jquery.min.js"></script>
                     <script src="https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/tether/1.3.7/js/tether.min.js"></script>
                     <script src="js/bootstrap.min.js"></script>

                    This is the code that would go at the bottom of the body. You can choose to comment out the tether script if you are not using it.

                    The Hamburger toggle for the main nav uses the jQuery and the bootstrap JS files. These notes are the details for version 4 of Bootstrap. version 3 also uses jQuery but not tether JS.

                    There is also an alternate script that you can use in place of the jQuery and Bootstrap scripts -

                    <script src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/bootstrap.native/1.0.4/bootstrap-native.js"></script>

                    Home Page (index.html)

                    If using Bootstrap 4, use http://v4-alpha.getbootstrap.com/components/card/ (Links to an external site.) cards.

                     

                    Contact Page (contact.html)

                    Contact page for the ficticious organization that owns the website. There should be a map image using the Google Static Maps API - https://developers.google.com/maps/documentation/static-maps/ (Links to an external site.) , as well as a contact form that asks users for their name, email address, and allows them to write a message in a textarea.

                    Footer

                    Every page should have the same footer. There should be a copyright notice, as well as at least four links to different social media sites. Eg: Facebook, Instagram, Twitter.  The Social Media links should use the icons that represent each site. Each of the icons should change colour when you hover over the link.

                    You can use the social media icons from this set - Iconic - https://useiconic.com/icons/ (Links to an external site.) 

                    This is a licenced font set. I own a copy but have permission for you to use it for educational projects. Here is the zip file for the latest version - iconic-everything-1.9.0.zip. It includes the CSS and JS and fonts for using the iconic set in a variety of different ways. Here are the guides on how to use the icons https://useiconic.com/guides/ (Links to an external site.) in custom ways. 

                     

                    Now, Bootstrap 3 comes with a default set of icons called Glyphicons. You can use those - http://getbootstrap.com/components/#glyphicons (Links to an external site.) on your page too.

                    Bootstrap 4 does not come with a set of default icons or icon-fonts.

                     

                    Colour Scheme and Fonts
